先不说好坏，说一下一个很要命的BUG。
打完京都BOSS的时候一直黑屏没法继续的话，你要这么做：1.找到游戏所在文件夹，右击“game.exe”选属性   2.选择兼容性，把那个禁用全屏优化和以管理员身份运行选上   3.进入游戏，用窗口运行    我就是这么弄好的，有同样问题的大家可以试试

author: 964b3286bbef505c81c041d00fcb95a5
content:
Prone to crashes on this port in v1.0.0, so take ATLUS' advice and update the game to "Hotfix 1" in the betas section to fix the majority of them. 

Genuinely Fantastic gameplay that feels exemplary of the "Dynasty Warriors" Style of games. The art direction is, as usual for the Persona 5 games, absolutely gorgeous with somehow even MORE stylish menu designs that incorporate the other members of the phantom thieves. 

The level design, while linear, is pretty par for the course when it comes to a "Warriors" game, with large, linear maps that offer decent amounts of challenge. But this is where Strikers diverges from the usual formula, as the team behind the game has put a lot of effort into blending the gameplay style of the warriors games with the RPG elements of Persona 5, as instead of a single instanced map with objectives to defend, Strikers instead opts to thrust players into a large dungeon-like map with multiple instanced rooms, each filled with roaming symbol encounters that will drop the player into a small-scale "1 v 100" battle.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Persona 5 Strikers to pretty much anyone, be they fans of Persona, Dynasty Warriors-Style Games, or even neither of those. Easy 9/10 game for me.

content:
Went in being pretty good at games like this and understood the mechanics. Had some decent challenge and some b.s. here and there until the damn Alice fight. Took all her weaknesses into Battle, was dodging everything and STILL got one shot with level 15 and 16 characters. Had to turn it down to easy and ONLY THEN was the fight achievable. 

I don't recommend this for casual players or people that think they might want it because they want to dip their toe into the Persona series. 

This game also reeks of poor design and can get REALLY tedious at times. I spent an entire 5 MINUTES in a dialogue after leaving an area, only to enter another, walk LITERALLY one step and then enter into ANOTHER dialogue with a mini-boss and then dialogue after that for another minute. This game really tries to make it hard to be refunded since they waste so much of your time in dialogues and back and forth walking simulators for no other purpose other than "because we can make you".

author: f6dc1f6bccd05d3982f02abef34de8fc
content: A true sequel to Persona 5. As others have said, the combat is highly engaging and incorporates so many elements that we love from Persona 5's combat (all out attacks, one mores, technicals) seamlessly into the Musou format. Much, much more story than I was expecting. It's such a cozy feeling travelling on summer vacation with your closest friends. Many have complained that there are no social links / confidant levels, but I find the Bond mechanic to be perfectly simplified for the type of game this is. Being able to exit and reenter the dungeon all on the same day also makes this a perfect game to pick up and enjoy in short bursts, unlike the original Persona 5. In short, play this game!

author: 7420797308675605aad0face8f4bdbd2
content:
This isn't P5S despite the name. This is Persona 5 - 2. Despite the change in gameplay style it's really just a follow up to P5 in both story and scope. It's a great excuse to have some more fun with the lovable cast of P5 this time on PC. Honestly, Despite what was said by the devs, I don't think this is too much fun for most people who haven't played the original P5 or Royal. Consider playing P5 before this to really get the most out of it. PS3's are pretty cheap nowadays, and if not it's pretty stable on RPCS3 *wink*. If you've played P5, It's an easy 10/10. If not please play P5 and then come here. If there's really no way for you to play P5 then maybe hold out for a sale cause the combat's still fun but honestly this game is more fun if you already love the cast. It goes down to like a 6/10 if you don't know the cast and past events. It doesn't spoil anything from P5 too big and you can still switch up the order but it's not recommended.
Unlike this game. For me it's one of the few bright spots of this whole lockdown and an easy recommendation.

author: eba09199facf5af8affe494bb3c88bbb
content:
I'm impressed at how well they were able to implement the style of persona from an action jrpg into a hack and slash, especially since this is the series' first dive into the genre. Characters are consistent with their portrayals in base p5, though it stands to note that this game follows a story where persona 5 royal never happened. This game absolutely lives up to the legacy of the series, and the new characters I really enjoyed. Music was incredible, definitely enough to stand on its own. Setting was incredible. Plot progression was incredible. If anything at all, I feel like the writing in this game did feel a little on the nose and cheesy at times, but not at all enough to affect my overall opinion.

[h1]SPOILERS [/h1]
[spoiler]The final boss was easy. Like, really easy. Throughout my entire playthrough, I pretty much exclusively stuck with Joker (for obvious reasons), Haru (for heat riser and the fact that killing enemies with her rocket launcher was funny), Sophia (because she had a great moveset), and Yusuke (though I switched him out with Zenkichi during the Kyoto jail). While they were hovering in the mid level 70s by the final boss, my other team members ended under level 60. When you had to split up and fight the meatballs on the towers, I had no trouble spamming their moves and made it out without a single person dying. Even when you get all the meatballs and Joker has to kill EMMA, I just spammed Maeigaon and killed it without taking any damage. Honestly the Archangel in the room right before EMMA was more challenging in my opinion. The hardest boss of the entire game was Shadow Joker, and that's only because you do such little damage to him. I only got out of that boss fight by spamming health and sp healing items and wailing on him for a solid 10 minutes. Finally, I want to bring attention to Zenkichi. He absolutely stole the show in the entire game. There was so much passion that went into his performance, and, when paired with the writing of his character, made him the best part of the entire game. Also, as a temporary musical nerd, seeing Valjean appear in the awakening scene was an out of body popoff experience. The portrayal of Valjean as a persona was perfect (it even had the 24601 on his chest). But seeing Valjean specifically as the persona of Zenkichi was the most incredible thing because Valjean fits so perfectly with Zenkichi's character. AND it drew the parallel of Akane being Zenkichi's Claudette like oh my god that was absolutely genius.[/spoiler]

Honestly, it's astounding to me what they were able to accomplish with this game, and it absolutely gave me the same feeling of unending emptiness of the mainline persona games when it ended (which is crazy because no social links and also half the playtime wow).

author: 4ff97406574d5e378bb576ea57fce649
content:
This is my first game from the Persona-series. I have watched a bit of Persona 5, but that was it. I also haven't watched any content to P5Strikers, or better, P5Scramble. This is why I was surprised that it was a Hack-n-slash game, however, it works really well with the setting. And the story, oh boy, good characters, good plot and overall a great experience. Every character has its onw playstyle, be it the allrounder Joker who has really save moves, Ryuji who has massive burst-options that leave him wide open for attacks or Makoto or Morgana who specialize in buffing and healing their teammates. If you like the Persone-style and look for a good hack-n-slash, play this, it's like a 40-hour game and worth every single cent. The only downside to this game is its instability, it sometime crashes, not often, but often enough for you to start saving all the time, however, you can't save during cutscenes or textboxes, you have to wait till cutscenes are over and just pray. If there is a hot-fix, ill give it a perfect score of 10/10, but till now it is a 9.5/10.
Music is, as expected from the Persona-games, great. I can't choose between "Life will change", "Aria of the soul" and "Anti-HERO".

content: If you like Hack and Slash and love the Persona 5 characters, it's more of them. BEWARE the game crashes still often enough to cost progress, so save very often.

完美的续作！怪盗团集结再次踏上旅途，到处旅游超级开心，配乐也是特别好听，贴合不同城市的风格。足不出户游日本 太欢乐啦！

战斗上给每个成员都设计了一套华丽炫酷的招式表，原本只能站桩回合现在每个角色都有一套炫酷连招和SHOW TIME 这样的改动谁不爱啊！

反派也设计的很好，每个反派的经历都对应相应主角的故事。如果主角团里的队友们没有遇到JOKER，说不定就会变成这些反派的样子吧，正是因为遇到joker得到了救赎，所以才彼此缔结了现在的羁绊。

对话文本也写的相当打动人心，尤其是近卫明，索菲亚和一之濑吐露心声，以及最后回到涩谷 告别前的对话，太打动人了！ 心中满满的感动！跳结局动画时更是感动的热泪盈眶 缓了好几天才走出来 有这样一群伙伴在身边才是人生中最大的秘宝！

无论剧情配乐文本还是战斗 都是满分啊!更何况这些优点还都凑到了一起。

这部真的是完美续作 ！

author: b0ce9d48fc4c5d45a5dd3dfae7e4e0b0
content:
I'm going to preface this review by saying that there have been a lot of technical issues reported by many people and I personally experienced some frequent crashes around the third Jail of this game. However, with the new beta patch applied, those issues seem to be resolved and I have had a crash free experience! So make sure you opt into the beta up until the patch goes live properly. 

Also, this game does use Denuvo Anti-Temper, which is controversial for many reasons including proven performance impacts as seen by games that have had the middleware removed. Some people very much dislike Denuvo, so it's only fair to make sure you're aware that is is there in case that is something that would impact your purchase. In that case, you may wish to consider either not purchasing the game, or seeking out its PlayStation 4 and Nintendo Switch ports if you own those systems.

With that out of the way, I can talk about how I actually feel about the game itself.

Persona 5 Strikers is a spin off of...Persona 5, funnily enough. It's by Koei Tecmo, the developers of the Warriors games. I personally am not a fan of those games, so I was pretty relieved when I found that Strikers is actually not a Warriors game. While it shares some of the base components e.g. controlling a party of heroes fighting large groups of enemies, the similarities pretty much end there.

In terms of combat, the game is a lot more focused on keeping your party alive, managing your HP/SP, and taking advantage of your enemies' weaknesses to gain control over the battle. In that regard, those tactical elements make the game feel strangely a lot like a Persona game in execution even with the change to real time action combat. Like many of the other Persona games, you also visit the Velvet Room to acquire and fuse new Personas throughout the game to give you more powerful tools to deal with the enemies. Social links are not in this game, but are replaced with a 'bond' system where you gain points to spend on upgrades for your party by interacting with them, cooking new recipes, and completing requests.

The ways these mechanics compliment each other help to make this feel a lot different from other spin offs and make it feel much more like a companion to the main Persona games rather than just another cash grab. Added to this, this isn't another dancing game, or non-canon 'it was all a dream' type spin off, but an actual direct sequel to Persona 5. However, this does mean that the game will spoil the events of Persona 5.  This makes this game kind of a strange choice to release considering that game is not on PC, but it was likely easier to port a game that was already in active development. 

If you have only played the original Persona 5, you will not be spoiled for the events of Royal as this game started development before Royal. Atlus likely also did not share any of the new plot elements of the re-release with Koei Tecmo, so Royal is not referenced at all in this game.

I cannot recommend this game much if you're a newcomer to the series, but if you are a Persona fan that enjoyed the hell out of 5, this feels pretty much like more Persona 5. In terms of story, it does retread some elements from the previous game and lift some elements into the new story and many of the 'twists' of the game's story are pretty easy to see coming. If you've played other Persona games, or are just generally familiar with the tropes of these types of games, you'll see where the story is going pretty easily. That being said, it is still a well executed and enjoyable story even if predictable.

Lastly...the music. Yeah. This a Persona game. It's got pretty great music.

Why are you still reading this and not playing Persona 5 Strikers?!

content:
P5S me ha sorprendido gratamente, la verdad solo esperaba un spin off corto con poca historia pero que fuera un "pretexto"para volver a reunir a los personajes. Nada más lejos de la realidad, este juego tiene una historia interesante, un buen sistema de combate y una duración bastante aceptable. 

Sin duda recomendado para los fans de la serie, aunque si no han jugado P5 el juego tiene muchas referencias al original que contienen spoilers.

PROS:
- Buena historia
- Buena duración
- Sistema de combate donde cada uno de los personaje tiene una jugabilidad distinta

CONTRAS:
- El compendio de personas es reducido
- El sistema de combate tiende a hacerse repetitivo al final si es que no usas todos los personajes
- Algunos personajes pueden quedar sin usarse debido a la cantidad que hay
- Los enemigos especiales tienden a ser muy "esponja"

author: 0ae23575596055ef9286f2931b4b226d
content:
Persona 5 Strikers, Persona 5 serisinin en son oyunu, Steam'deki de ilk Persona 5 oyunu. Oyun, Persona 5 Royal ile alakasiz, yani aslinda Vanilla surumunun devami.
Ilk girisi yaptigima gore once oynanisa deginmek istiyorum. Mainline Persona oyunlarinin aksine, oyun sira tabanli degil; hack n slash. Bond point sistemi ile partinizi guclendirebiliyorsunuz. Oyun oynanis olarak gayet zevkliyken, bir yerden sonra az da olsa tekrara dustugunu hissetmedim desem yalan olur.
Oynanisa az biraz degindim, simdi en sevdigim kisim: Sanat dizayni ve Soundtrack. Son Persona oyunlarinda oldugu gibi yine konsept cizimler Shigenori Soejima urunu. Harika bir gorsel solen. Muzikler mi? Her Persona 5 oyununun sarkilarini seslendirmis olan Lyn yine harika bir is cikarmis. Sarkilarin sozleri oyunla o kadar alakali ki, dinlerken gercekten mest oldum. Oyuna ayri bir zevk katiyor muzikler, ayrica Persona 5'ta olup da Strikers icin remix edilmis sarkilar da hosuma gitti, nostalji olmus oldu.
Hayalet hirsizlar tekrardan kalpleri calmak icin is basinda!

author: 54668ffc693c553b812a52a2fa191632
content: Interesting experience for fans of dynasty warrior type games, disappointing experience for a persona fan. Graphics for the game even on the max graphics settings are OK at best. The models in persona 5 are so much more crisp while the models in persona 5 strikers are blurry and hard to look at when far away. After playing persona 5, I have to admit that the characters have gotten stale for me. All of the arcs that the characters went through in persona 5 are pretty much just reused in this game, making it seem very lazy to say the least. A character that really grinds my gears is Sophia. Her character development is pretty much a sh*tty version of a certain someones character development in persona 3. No social links is also a real bummer. It was one of the main reasons why I enjoyed persona 5 and without them the game really feels like its missing something. Another thing I would like to point out is the fact that they make you go back into the real world and sit through two loading screens just to recover your SP. And its not like there's any incentive to go back to the real world. There's no social links, the day doesn't change, and the area your in remains exactly the same until you manage to drag yourself through the jail. Every time you try to do a persona attack it freezes time disrupting any natural flow the game could have had. As for the soundtrack, there's a few soundtracks I like and a few that are pretty terrible. The soundtrack I found most enjoyable was the soundtrack to the first jail, Love te Wonderland. Otherwise, it mostly goes downhill from there. Overall, the games not terrible and may be enjoyable to fans of the hack and slash genre, but to everyone else I wouldn't recommend it.

author: ee9592d7701751c582bcdc2da805d706
content:
[h1]El regreso de los Ladrones Fantasma[/h1]
Excelente. Al contrario de lo que me esperaba, se siente como un ARPG de Persona mas que un juego generico de Warriors reskineado. La jugabilidad es excelente, cada personaje se siente diferente en jugabilidad al otro, las dungeons son bastante entretenidas y el sistema de combate es casi catártico. Me sorprendió lo bien que se tradujo la jugabilidad de P5 a este juego, teniendo una importancia fundamental la explotación de las debilidades, críticos y técnicos, suponiendo literalmente la vida o muerte. Relacionado a esto, el juego tiene una dificultad que castiga demasiado, que hace que no sea demasiado dificil si dominas el estilo de combate del personaje que usas y haces una estrategia acorde al enemigo enfrente tuyo, pero que te destruye en el momento en el que te distraés. 
La banda sonora es excelente (generalmente al nivel del juego original, y teniendo varios remixes que le pasan el palo a las canciones originales), aunque algunas canciones de dungeon se sienten extremadamente genéricas (despues de la 4ta dungeon en adelante esto deja de pasar, teniendo temas bastante memorables). 
El apartado gráfico al principio me traía dudas, ya que zonas que son comparables con P5 como puede ser Shibuya no se ven mal pero se ven distintas, aunque en el momento en el que dejás de comparar el apartado gráfico con el juego original, Strikers empieza a brillar por su cuenta, teniendo generalmente un estilo gráfico bastante distintivo y que sabe adaptar perfectamente el estilo gráfico del juego original. 
En cuanto a la performance, no noté nada malo mas allá de un crasheo a las 20hs de juego (que mucha gente parece tener), pero el antialasing de este juego DESTRUYE la UI, dandole un aspecto a la fuente del juego como si estuviera a 144p.
La historia del juego está completamente a la altura, manteniendo las personalidades originales del cast del juego sin reducirlas a dos caracteristicas ridiculas e infumables (cosa de la que suelen pecar MUCHISIMO los spin-offs de la saga Persona), y la trama es generalmente buena, dejandole tiempo a la mayoría del cast para que pueda brillar por su cuenta (aunque ven venir todos y cada uno de los giros argumentales del juego desde 4 kilometros a la redonda). Me encantaron todos los personajes agregados, y se siente que tienen un buen desarrollo que les permite brillar. 

En conclusión, si te gusta Persona 5 y los ARPG, posiblemente te encante este spin-off/secuela/loquesea, pero si no te jugaste/viste/leiste P5 no te lo puedo recomendar. No vas a entender absolutamente nada, y el juego no se sienta a explicar los conceptos principales que ya se tocaron en el juego original (lo cual me parece excelente, porque si me explican una vez mas lo que es un palacio voy a hacer una masacre). 

8/10

author: b0c6ed6757ec55d0ad39893f945944d9
content:
I wasn't sure if I want to pick yes or no but decided to go with no, since I had a kinda hard time really enjoying it. Let me explain why.

Battles
The controls in the battles are awful! Yes it is based on DW, but feels way worse. The lock on isn't working properly, sometimes you don't see anything because it's too colorful. Some enemies left the battle area to a point where my characters couldn't go, so I had to wait for them to come back.

Genre
For me it feels like they just mixed up all current popular genres to make money out of it. Platformer, Hack'n'Slash, RPG, just put it together, it will work somehow. But it feels so out of place and especially the platformer parts are super annoying for me.

Chracters&Story
The characters are amazing as always, the story feels like a copy from Persona 5.

Graphics
Are amazing, BUT it's way too colorful in some parts, even with the third eye it was hard to find the way and I haven't even played till harder levels yet.

Bugs
The game crashed a few times on me, not only this, but enemies leave the arena. Was a no no.


In my opinion not worth the full price.

author: 9033a33765d855d8a5d00f49551868eb
content:
Same great cast from the base game. Fairly engaging plot of a decent length. The new characters are all fantastic. As usual from P5 the presentation in terms of audio and voice acting as well as the visual presentation is crisp and to an really high standard. 

The gameplay is that of a warriors game though with the RPG elements of persona fitting in in a really natural way. If you don't like the gameplay of other warriors games then you probably wont enjoy this one, though if you want more of the P5 cast and story then i can still recommend playing on easy mode and it may surprise you.

I can make that recommendation since this is one of the best warriors style games out there. All of the characters are fun to play and the combat is so satisfying, it tones down a lot of the warriors series main features to allow for the new content but that rounds off the experience really well to make for a game thats just fun to play.

TLDR

If you liked the base P5 or are a fan of good warriors games then give this a go. If you don't like the genre then perhaps its worth skipping. But everything this game does it does really well.

author: e83c2f6712865a8fb153bd1b631fe520
content:
Un juego muy recomendable... si has jugado a Persona 5/Royal, que a día de hoy tristemente no está disponible en PC.

Tenía ciertas dudas sobre si me iba a gustar el juego, porque nunca he sido un gran fan de los Musou/Dinasty Warriors, si tenéis la misma duda compradlo sin miedo, el sistema de combate tiene mucho, pero que mucho de Megaten, y se hace muy disfrutable.

Como RPG no está mal, la historia continúa dónde lo deja Persona 5 (la versión base, no Royal), y la verdad que es mejor de lo que me esperaba, se nota que los guionistas quieren seguir el hilo y no hacer un borrón, hay referencias a eventos pasados y no se siente para nada fuera de lugar. El nivel es más bajo, desde luego, pero es entretenida e interesante, aunque bastante más predecible también. Hay sistema de equipamiento, no hay social links (natural, se supone que ya han tenido lugar en el transcurso de su precuela) pero hay un sistema poco más o menos equivalente pero con progreso común para todo el grupo. La dificultad está bien ajustada, con el nivel más alto solo disponible al terminar el juego (lógico, porque los enemigos empiezan a nivel 70, sería inviable empezar en estas condiciones por muy hábil que sea el jugador), está bien para dar otra vuelta y terminar los logros que queden pendientes.

Si no has jugado P5... aparte de los spoilers enormes que vas a comerte, pienso que se pierde mucha de la gracia de este juego, que es el "fanservice SFW" de ver muchos personajes a los que tienes cariño otra vez, en una aventura con un poco de miga.

La banda sonora, una chulada. Remixes de canciones de P5, con alguna incorporación nueva de la mano de Lotus Juice y Lyn Inaizumi. Una pena que el juego de baile no haya salido después de este título, se pierden varios temas muy curiosos.

La traducción al castellano no está mal. Con algún gazapo inexplicable aquí y allá, pero no es lo peor que he visto, y el juego tiene bastante texto. Las voces están disponibles en inglés y japonés, y se puede cambiar en cualquier momento.

Edito: Sobre los cuelgues, sí, he tenido algún crasheo, en torno a 5-6 en 60 horas de juego que me parece... bastante, la verdad. Me alegra ver que los desarrolladores están en ello, de hecho hay una beta a fecha de marzo de 2020 (consultar los foros, es abierta) y desde que la he instalado no he tenido ningún cuelgue en las últimas 10h, aunque por lo que dicen aún puede pasar, aunque bastante menos. Guardando frecuentemente como el juego te invita a hacer tampoco es insoportable, sobre todo con el último hotfix. El rendimiento es bueno con buen PC, y las opciones gráficas bastante completas.

author: 7a75b6b51c5158a28461ba34b4f4d39a
content:
Despite being a much shorter game than your typical Persona game, Strikers still manages to tell a very compelling story that allows for characters to shine and really let their personalities steal the show. Once I started playing, I'll admit a part of me wasn't totally sold on the concept as a whole yet. I had never played a Musuo/Dynasty Warriors game before but knew that I had to see what the next chapter for the Phantom Thieves had in store for us. Sure enough, the further I progressed, the more the game grew on me and the more I bought into the transition Persona 5 went through to become a game like this. In reality, the essence of what makes Persona 5 such a compelling and lovable game was really what shined through in the end. The cast was full of life, love, fantastic personalities and unforgettable moments. Every character had moments that really let them take center stage and remind us all of what it means to overcome our own struggles and once again stand up on our own two feet. Personally, I wan't to give a special shout out to Haru, who was the final character to join the team in Persona 5. One of the things I wished we had in P5 was more time to spend with Haru and more opportunities for her to shine and that is exactly was Strikers gives us. This goes for all characters as well. I enjoyed getting to tag along with the Phantom Thieves for another journey through the human heart that resulted in some strong and powerful character moments that empowered the story to really hit home for myself and I'm sure for plenty of people, especially after everything we've been through and are still going through with COVID. It's crazy to think how towards the beginning of the pandemic we were graced with Persona 5 Royal and now a year later, we're given a worthwhile next chapter for the Phantom Thieves of Hearts. A few things to touch on before wrapping this up.

[h1] Music [/h1]
The entire Persona series is known for its exceptional soundtracks and Strikers is no slouch in that department. Whether its the remixes of classic P5 tunes or the newcomers to the party making you stop what you're doing and groove in your chair, this game has no shortage of tunes for all manor of situations to aid you in your Phantom Thief duties! I plan on adding this soundtrack to my collection of Persona tunes that I already listen to on a daily basis.

[h1] Crashes [/h1]
Throughout my roughly 45 hours of game time, I had 3 total crashes happen while playing on PC. Thankfully, none of these crashes happened at crucial moments but it is something I've seen people write about in other reviews so make sure to save as often as possible!

[h1] Story Continuation from Persona 5 [/h1]
While ultimately not super important for the overall story, this game definitely assumes that you have played P5 before and are familiar with it's story so be mindful if you haven't played P5 before and are considering getting this game!

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
Any opportunity to team back up with the Phantom Thieves is easily one worth taking and Strikers does a great job delivering on a worthy sequel to what was already my favorite game of all time. Hopefully the overwhelming amount of positive feedback will encourage Atlus to keep releasing Persona games on steam since its clear that the Phandom, old and new, are eager for more! P5 fans will adore this game but ultimately, any fans of good storytelling and meaningful character development will fall in love just as easily! Thanks for everything, Phantom Thieves <3

author: 55850e846ce557438c2e305d62321c30
content:
It's quite excellent.

If you really enjoyed Persona 5, you probably already picked this up.  If you haven't yet, definitely do so, it's an excellent follow-up.

The story, characters, Persona Fusing, weakness-exploiting, all of it feels like an excellent continuation from Persona 5, just wapped up in an Action Game format instead of a turn-based JRPG, while ALSO giving you ways to pause the action (summoning personas and pulling out the guns) to assess the situation and respond thoughtfully.

Despite the marketing and the combo system, this is NOT a Warriors/Musou game.  It may use the basic button combo system from one, but it's far more deliberate.  There are very few enemy hordes, with most encounters being small gangs of enemies that are mostly all a threat (even the mooks).

Finally, I like that once the lengthy tutorial is over, the game TRUSTS the player.  You get a huge party of 8, with all their combos unlocked the minute you enter the first dungeon for real, with all further unlocks either being powerups, or critical game-changing abilities.  There's very little unlocking required to access your core essential abilities and you can start doing cool and awesome stuff from the word go.

author: d1df6fa317715a55b724ba56639f34aa
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is the 2nd Persona game to make it onto the Steam store and is the sequel to Persona 5.  It brings with it a compelling story, engaging combat and amazing music.  While technically a musou game, the game plays very much like a Persona game in most respects.  The majority of this review compares the differences between this game and Persona 5 and Musou games to give you a good sense of what you are getting yourself into.  

[h1] Whats Changed [/h1]

[b] Combat [/b]
Combat is by far the biggest difference between Persona 5 in this game.  The Combat has changed from a Turn Based System to an Active Time System, though it executes this spectacularly.  All of the iconic features of Persona are still present in this new combat system such as Weakness exploitation, All Out Attacks, and Stat/Ailment effects.  You also initiate combat just like you would in any other Persona game, by attacking an enemy on the field which sends you into a real time battle on the map.  

While this is labeled as a Musou game, the only thing it really has in common with them is the number of enemies present on the screen usually consisting of a large number of trash mobs and a few enemies that actually pose a threat.  In addition, since it is Real Time, enemy attacks are now telegraphed and nearly all attacks are preventable by dodging out of the way or interrupting the enemy.  While this might be a bit hard to execute in trash mob fights with tons of enemies, this really shines in boss fights where there is one major threat to focus on.  

Overall, this new Combat System is intertwined excellently with the Persona series, making you wonder why they have never done this before.  

[b] Confidant System [/b]

The next big difference between this game and Persona 5 is the Confidant System, which was replaced with Bond Levels.  Unfortunately, this new system is quite limited as a whole, as it comprises only of party member interaction and lacks any NPCs to interact with and gain confidant levels with.  In addition, the time management system is all but gone as a result.  However, this new system still allows you to gain the benefits of the Confidant System by giving you Bond Exp with interactions, which you can use to buy perks very similar to what you would gain from Confidants.  

[h1] The Good [/h1]
 
[b] Story [/b]

The story is compelling as ever and while not quite as good as the main Persona series, still holds its own quite well, especially for a Musou game which typically don't have great stories. 

[b] Music [/b]

The Music remains a strong point of the game and the series as a whole, with a number of remixed pieces from Persona 5 as well as plenty of new additions.  

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

[b] Crashes [/b]

In 50 hours of this game, I've had the game crash 5 times.  Each of these crashes occurred at either entering or exiting a dungeon, so often not much progress was lost.  However, since this game does not auto save, you have to be careful to save often to prevent losing significant progress.  

[b] Lack of Prequel Explanation [/b] 

This game absolutely expects you to have played Persona 5 prior to playing this game, as there is little explanation of character's backstories or prior events.  Often times, the game references major plot points of the previous game but does nothing to even mention what happened, leaving people who haven't played the previous game confused.  While normally not too much of a problem, it is not even possible to play Persona 5 on Steam as of this review.  

[h1] Summary [/h1]

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is an extremely strong spinoff of Persona 5 with compelling gameplay and story.  However, it lacks some of the major features that some Persona fans love so much and also requires you to have played the first game in order to properly enjoy the story.

author: a3e21bc86e8c58a5b0aefec41a8f3459
content:
Great gameplay, awful writing. The dialogue is really uninspired and just seems like it was thrown at the wall to see what sticks. There's no real character or moral development from Persona 5, just more of the same. Our main heroes act like they've never had any life experiences outside of what the game shows you, as if they're just actors in a show. Regardless, the game is fun, I just find myself cringing at the rather second-rate plot points and superficial character development.

EDIT: After completing the game, and likely going on to 100% it, I'll change my review to recommend. The writing and storytelling is still quite sub-par, but the gameplay is still exponentially fun, even as a musou-style.

author: e0042f8bfa8853b196abdb78f9e39c16
content:
Let me first say: IF YOU HAVE NOT PLAYED YET PERSONA 5 OR PERSONA 5 ROYAL, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, THIS IS A DIRECT SEQUEL TO THOSE GAMES. 
It´s very hard for me to make a objectively review of this game because Persona 5 Royal is my N° 1 favorite game of all time. When I first listened that we were going to have a new Persona experience with a new battle system which replace the turn based combat, it was really exciting news, but I also thought that it was going to be just a musou/warriors game with a persona art style, and hoo boy how I was wrong about that assumption.
 From the music to the art style,  and to the story and the combat, it really felt like a Persona 5 game. The implementation of some of the previous games combat system mechanics to this new musou/warriors style combat fitted perfectly. Each of the phantom thieves combat skills are unique and different from each other. About the music, they never cease to amaze me. Each of the music tracks are phenomenal and outstanding. If they release a Persona 5 Farming Simulation game with new music like this and the previous games, I´ll keep giving them my money.
 The visual novel story part is still in this game and very well adapted, and although the social link aspect of the previous game is replaced with this new bond level system, I think it adapts really well to the format of this game. The story and new characters in my opinion are very well written, and it is really easy to attach to them, as usual.
 If I had to criticize something, perhaps it would be that some of the characters from the previous game are not in this one, either way, the main roaster is here. 
To conclude, if you have previously played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, definitely you have to play this game without any doubt. I repeat, if you have not played those games, then go play them first. THIS IS A SEQUEL. Let´s pray that Atlus release Persona 5 Royal and the other Persona games on Steam soon.

author: 0d539044b4865c04b6659ea219fde935
content: Honestly I'm not a huge fan of musou combat, but there's so much more to this game and the combat is decently well-done, just takes some getting used to coming from your mainline Persona games. If you liked Persona 5, you'll like this too because it's essentially more P5. Stylish, fun team interactions, great music, a decent story (especially for a spin-off), and just the all-around polish that I've come to expect. My main takeaway from this and the fact that the SMT Nocturne Remaster is coming to Steam (announced yesterday as of writing this) is that Atlus is on PC to stay, and that's what I really love about this. These games coming to PC means that P4G made them realize they can print money by giving games to people on the platform they want, and I'm all for it.

author: 8156a73f37295902a05035f21b0f1de4
content:
the games uhhhhh, fine? but not worth the price at all if you cut out padding.
i'd describe it as one of those DBZ games, where its kinda garbage but theres enough there to satisfy you.

they tried to do more than just Persona 5 Warriors and it works out on a surface level, but when you get down to the nitty gritty aspects of the game it feels stretched out extremely far and much less inspired (in some points just being unfinished too)

SPOILERS:
[spoiler]The 2nd "Jail" is a parody of lazy writing in fiction, the problem is thats all it is, theres no story to it other than a single joke that runs its course 5 minutes into a several hour story arc.

The third Jail uses the exact same assets with an ice filter, and the aesthetic is tied to a really really really actually lazy story (so far, yet to complete it), so while the game is making fun of lazy tropey writing, it turns around and falls to that problem without realizing it.[/spoiler]

The combats genuinely very fun, but then the game forces itself into persona 5 mechanics and kneecaps itself due to it.

First off, like persona 5 you "ambush" enemies and that starts the actual encounters and this is cool and allows for fast grinding later on, it also means theres a short cutscene and waiting period every time you try to start combat. It feels super bad to play, especially if you are trying to do the constant backtracking side missions which just require you grind X enemy in Y dungeon Z times.

Again from the original game, abilities use HP/SP but unlike the original game there isnt a ticking clock that makes you want to get as far through the palace as possible in one go. In strikers you can leave the dungeon at any checkpoint (which are very common) and instantly return with full stats. So unless you like fighting health spongey bosses with no stats youl be jumping in and out of dungeons often early on when you dont have many tools/items.

Tonnes of the game (especially the shibuya areas) feel fake, the attention to detail and things you can do are significantly limited, while this is understandable it just makes it feel strange to have 7 different shops next to each other that all sell 2 things when you have no real reason to actually touch them at all outside the cooking mechanic (which isnt a mechanic as much as a way to make a shitload of items quickly, if you bought ingredients earlier)

In the end the game just feels like the people making it liked persona 5 (and probably previous SMT games) but didnt really like the downtime aspects of persona 5, or had no idea how to implement it with the road trip aesthetic.

I really wish it was just a lazy Persona 5 Warriors game, because im having fun in extremely quick bursts followed by worse handholding than original p5.

content: This game is kinda low for persona standards overall , The game is a bit buggy by the time I write this (still playable tho), The pacing of the story was off , the plot was kinda meh & predictable (it feels like I'm watching a bunch of filler anime episodes) , The combat system is what you'd expect from a musou game, It's a nice change of pace from your regular turn based combat (tho I still preferred the classic). author: f61af2b6a75b519598ce020ff4f30033
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is exactly what I was hoping for as a Persona 5 spinoff/sequel. It continues the story of P5 in a similar, yet new way and continues to build the characters of P5.

I found the gameplay very enjoyable, with it's unconventional turn-based RPG mechanics mixed in with the action gameplay. The action felt just right, you're able to dash around and attack just like in devil may cry but at the push of a button every stops and it becomes much more like a turn based rpg.
I don't think they could have implemented this much better, so kudos.

Just like the original the soundtrack is great. I personally prefer it to the original P5, but this is just my style of music. They even added in some Remixes of the original games music.

Lastly the story. I find it very good. It has been streamlined with story progression now being tied to your in-game progression, since there is no calendar system. I'm sure it would have been nice to see all characters from P5 return, but think it's better this way. The new additions fit in well too (mostly).
The real crime with the story of this game is a PC and switch exclusive problem. The original games aren't on these platforms and therefore many people are most likely going to be out of the loop when starting the game. Therefore they may miss some of the more subtle things, not understand everything or just not care. 

In terms of the port, I did not have any big issues. Some framedrops when things got heated. I did have a few crashes, but only about six or seven in 70+ hours of playtime. Sidenote: This was also within the first two weeks of the games release. I have not tried 1.02 but I assume that is even better. 

Overall I recommend this game. It's really great. My biggest issue with it is that the NG+ difficulty might as well be called BS mode, so yeah. Great game. Worth your money.
...
But there's a catch.
I recommend you at least have basic knowledge of the previous game. I got through just fine knowing the base plot of the P5 and having watched the anime(yes the anime does cover most of the important things). Let's just hope that Atlus do eventually port Persona 5 (Royal) to PC, but I think it's basically a given at this point. :)

author: 3d2edd1d8072523cacc05986380fdde8
content:
[b] Pros: [/b] 
- Continues the story from Persona 5, with new themes. Leads to an engaging, although familiar, experience. Seeing the Phantom Thieves hanging out and having fun in different locales is a treat.
- The UI is still as stylish as ever. 
- Music is awesome and varied. The new rock-infused tracks fit right in with the jazz music from the original game.
- Sophia and Zenkichi are great additions to the cast, both having great characterizations and deep and complex backstories.
- Gameplay is action-packed and hectic. Puts a spin in the typical Musou-formula. Each character have their own unique fighting styles, allowing for different experiences.

[b] Cons: [/b] 
- The gameplay is rather repetitive. You'll be mowing down enemies again, again and again with no signs of stopping. 
- Bossfights are tedious and will test your patience. It will take quite a while to whittle down a boss's health to even half-health. Even mini-bosses aren't exempt from this. 
- Crashes and long loading times happen but are rare. Save often to prevent loss of progress.

All-in-all, as a Persona 5 fan, I love the game and enjoyed most of it. Love the story, the interactions between the crew, and the new characters. The gameplay is fun enough, although I'm not the biggest fan of it.

author: 18f1e26ad23351d38b782de32e35b314
content:
Review - Persona 5 strikers fue una fantástica combinación de juego de rol y acción. Una arriesgada propuesta por parte de Koei Tecmo que busco adaptar un juego de Mushou a partir de un JRPG clásico y por turnos y el resultado fue excelente. Me atrevo a decir que no se trata de un mushou si no mas bien de un action rpg, donde la estructura del persona 5 original esta intacta por sus mas de 40 horas de juego. Si bien no tiene la profundidad de los lazos del persona 5 base, strikers tiene una buena cantidad de diálogos y una historia atrapante que te mantendrá enganchado durante toda la aventura, sobre todo los últimos capítulos del juego con increíbles giros en la historia, fiel al estilo de la saga. Compra obligada para todo que haya disfrutado con persona 5 original o royal (recordar que este continua después del persona 5 original y personajes como kasumi o maruki nunca existieron aquí) y para el que no jugo el persona 5 original? bueno, te va a gustar y lo vas a poder disfrutar pero te vas a perder de muchas referencias, mi consejo es que juegues el original antes.

Para mas contenido seguime en instagram:

author: d79002d89ce058dca8aed55bd435be63
content:
Let me start off by saying that I'm a huge Persona 5 fan, having played the base game several times and Royal twice. I went in to this game only seeing the trailers when they first came out. I'm not big on games similar to Dynasty Warriors, but I still feel like the gameplay was fairly enjoyable for the most part. My biggest issue comes from the story. Sometimes the story can feel touching, but other times it feels so bland and generic. Dialogue got SUPER REPETITIVE, by the end of the game I was skipping parts of the dialogue because it was unnecessary filler. The crashing was also a bit of an issue I had, but it was pretty minor. It only crashed like 4-5 times during my playthrough, so just make sure to save often just in case.

Characters-
Since this game follows the events of Persona 5, the characters are something I need to talk about. They had their moments, but they felt nothing like the characters from P5. They all felt a bit 1-dimensional at times, like they had a single character trait and that was it. They ended up feeling more like cardboard cutouts than actual characters. Even some of the new characters fall into this troupe, some more than others. I will say that I enjoyed Zenkichi and Sophia quite a bit in this game. Zenkichi and Sophia almost always had meaningful dialogue that added to their character or those around them. Even though the characters can feel stale at times, some of them had their moments that made me smile or laugh. 

Recommendation-
I don't recommend it, but I'm not entirely against it either. 

I would only recommend this game if you:
-Are a big fan of P5 or the Persona franchise as a whole
-Aren't playing for an immersive story(at least on the level of P5)
-Are a fan of the Dynasty Warrior genre
-Don't mind repetitive dialogue/gameplay
-Just want to play it for the gameplay/characters
-Just want to try it for yourself

author: ef57458537285c6b894e71cecaab43c0
content:
i haven't had this much fun with a game in a long time

i was skeptical about the game when it was first announced - it seemed flashy and energetic, but i wasnt sure how the game could marry musou combat and a megaten fusion/affinity system together
but i was wrong lol
gameplay is exciting and oozes the persona 5 flourish, while never feeling too visually overwhelming
i was surprised to find that the general musou focus on slaughtering thousands of enemies isn't super potent here - there are moments of cathartic release where you can wail on waves and waves of shadows, but strikers does a great job of giving you more complex fights with interesting minibosses
each fighter has something interesting to offer mechanically, which makes it more fun to switch out your party members - even characters i dont like as written are fun to mess around with in dungeons
the game isn't incredibly strong narratively, but there are plenty of good character moments over the course of the story to keep you invested - though some may be predictable to those already familiar with neo-persona
the new music tracks fit the game well, and the dlc legacy music pack is a welcome addition. getting the innocent sin music to play during fights pumps dopamine directly into my brainstem

the camera can sometimes be a bit of a pain - not enough to knock points, but something to note
it's most notable in certain boss fights, where the enemy is moving very quickly around the stage and the camera has a hard time following them around if you're trying to lock on
some enemies are also a bit spongier than they really need to be - certain bosses make sense, but some fights feel like they go on longer than they deserve to, and become less a test of skill and more a test of endurance

that said it's an incredibly solid game
i hope this pc port sells well - i'd love to see atlus be more willing to port their games over to more platforms
plenty of games like digital devil saga 1&2, the persona 2 duology, and especially ronde deserve to be experienced by a modern audience

author: 2c07df6c55b458bf96d66133fa945d48
content:
A very good P5 Spinoff, the soundtrack is an absolute banger, the characters are amazingly likable, and the gameplay is fun with a little learning curve for figuring out combos and fun ways to tie everything together. i only have a few criticizms of this game, and they are all nitpicks, so dont take them to heart. 

1. certain fusions require the components to be leveled to a certain degree before they can be fused, which has never been done in the series prior, which slows down progression.

2.stat increase bond skills are absolutly useless, because they are expensive... 3-5 points for a +1 is not justifiable.

3. some levels go a bit too fast, but that is more an issue that i fight too well and manage to claw my way through out of sheer determination.

4. the final boss could have been a bit better

overall i love P5, and what they did is they took the criticisms of P5 and acted upon them, all the villains make you feel apprehensive about stopping them, because they honestly have relate able convictions. also as a warning the "soundtrack" is played through an app, so no, you cant slap this shit on your phone... unless you do the same type of techno fuckery that i did and brute force it there, because ill be damned if i cannot listen to the best Persona soundtrack in existence on demand.

author: ce97820ab5915749bbc0d325f617f2ed
content:
This is a MUSTPLAY for every persona 5 fan, yes the gameplay is different and for some it will be repetitive since its a "musou" game, but it still tackles that genre in its own way, ive had a blast playing through all of it, story telling is nearly as good as the original persona 5 Royal story, quick paced gameplay that you can slow down by summoning your persona, it gives you a bit time to breath, 60h for me (grinding and side quest stuff) and nearly 100% it. 

i only have 3 Contras:
 - Persona fusion is different, you have a free option which personas to fuse, but for specific requests you are "forced" to use 2 specific personas to fullfill the request. unless you have a skill card
- Main actor once again only has a voice in VERY few cutscenes.
-Last boss on HARD difficulty was a walk in the park (There is new game + on a way harder difficulty)

All in all i had a blast and do recommend it whole heartedly!

author: e2e0bd81671453c5ad308f0fa06995c6
content:
I went into this game thinking I was going to hate it because I have never liked the Dynasty Warrior games, or anything similar, but this was honestly a pleasant surprise.
This game is a direct sequel to Persona 5 (nothing from Royal is referenced) which is sadly not on PC as of this review. So you will need to have played that to understand what is going on. 
Story wise, it is not as good as the original, but it definitely has its moments, and I think its a good sequel that doesn't feel forced.
As far as the combat, at first it can feel really off putting because of the Dynasty Warriors style, to remedy this, you can bump up the difficulty to hard. the mini bosses and bosses are actually pretty fun this way and the gameplay elements blend together pretty well.
Definitely give this a try if you enjoyed the original Persona 5. it is well worth it.

author: 32cebe13c0cd54f98dffa845ccd862f5
content:
Comme beaucoup j'ai découvert la licence Persona avec le 5 en 2017 et j'ai eu l'occasion de me prendre une gifle que je n'avais pas pris depuis longtemps en jouant à un JRPG. En sortant du jeu je n'avais qu'une seule envie, me replonger dans cet univers avec ses personnages et sa narration aux petits oignons. 

Avec ce Persona 5 Strikers mon souhait a été exaucé, certes on oublie la formule JRPG pour se concentrer sur un musou, mais que ce soit au niveau de l'aspect graphique du hud, comme de la trame principale on est complètement dans ce qui faisait l'essence de P5 avec une option tour du pays nippon qui n'est pas négligeable.  La ou Persona 5 était innovateur dans l'optimisation de ses commandes de combat pour éviter aux joueurs une navigation dans les menu laborieuse, P5S réussi à adapter ça au cadre du Musou, les enchaînements se font très naturellement passé quelques heures de jeu et le sentiment d'anéantir des dizaines et des dizaines d'ombres est grisant même après 40h de jeu.

Pour les amoureux de la B.O de Persona 5 vous avez avec P5S l'occasion de vous remettre dans cette ambiance avec de nouveau thème et certains repris directement de P5.

Petit bémol cependant si vous souhaitez réaliser tout les trophées, l'un d'eux demande un grinding assez lourd qui n'est pas forcément très intéressant. 

Mis à part ça le pari P5S est une réussite selon moi, il a réussi l'espace d'une cinquantaine d'heures à me transporter dans cet univers que j'avais adoré il y a 3 ans, avec un réel plaisir de revoir Joker et son équipe reprendre du service !

Enfin est-ce que ce jeu peut être intéressant pour quelqu'un qui n'a pas touché à l'épisode original mais qui aime tout simplement les musou ? Selon moi oui, bien sur il peut être intéressant de regarder un résumé du 5 avant car il y a très peu d'explication sur l'histoire de P5 originale dans ce jeu. Mais d'un point de vue gameplay pur ce P5S introduit des mécanique nouvelle dans ce genre de jeu qui selon moi subit beaucoup de reskin mais évolue rarement !

author: f08f85d0139a5f489c860ff0842bb325
content: Sophie觉醒那段感动哭了

author: 51ee914847895de6beead222cc02f692
content:
Some things to know: 
If you haven't played base game or Royal please do yourself a favor and play them. This is a direct sequel so reasons are obvious as to why you should play the base game or Royal. Even though this game is technically a spin off it still has its own full story and new characters. This game if you don't know is a warriors game meaning hacking through a lot of mobs, so no turned base combat.

The Pros: 
-The cast is back and they are just as great as base game. All feel exactly the same as they did from the end of P5 and they retain their growth from the previous game. The interactions with them are all great and that alone was a massive selling point for me.
- The fighting system is fluid and requires you to think especially in later encounters making combat not just button mashing. 
-All characters are very distinct in their fighting styles and all feel really fun to play.
-Zenkichi and Sophia are a great addition to the cast and fit right in with the thieves.
-Haru gets some well deserved screentime after what she dealt with in base-game. 
-Jails are similar to palaces yet unique in their own rights making exploring them feel nostalgic and enjoyable.
-Music is really good and I still find myself listening to the tracks even after playing.
-The Va's did an amazing job especially under the restrictions of covid and each character sounds amazing and never really took me out of the experience.
-Merciless is a great edition and makes the game much harder than before making combat require even more thinking especially for certain combos/ making broken personas in the velvet room.

The Cons:
-The first couple of jails fit the same exact formula which is understandable for plot reasons however, it does make each one feel less unique.
-The game will crash rarely when entering new locations which of course can be not fun especially when you did not save prior. This seems to be a PC problem only.
-I occasionally received some frame drops in later encounters especially with fights with lots of effects but it runs very well everywhere else.
-The requests can sometimes feel very grindy and menial which of course can be annoying especially when they are required to fight the reaper and unlock new-game+/merciless.

Conclusion:
This game is great and I will wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who played persona 5. It has its flaws for sure but this game is still amazing. It carries a lot over from base-game which I don't mind but does make the game feel more like an extension rather than a sequel. Its an amazing experience and to all those who haven't gotten into the Megaten series you definitely should these are some of it not the best games ever made.
Score: 4/5

author: 70b50b97a745531286b6032ae58ba311
content:
Okay, so for a PC port this was really good. 
My only problem with the game itself: 
The one major problem I had was the game randomly crashing, which was a rare occurrence ( happened only like 2-3 times in the 60+ hours i've played) so as long as you've saved regularly, it shouldn't be a problem. What I can't quite figure out is why it crashed? One of the times it happened I was just walking from one area of the real world to another, it wasn't even if a particularly crowded area with a lot of NPC's. The first time it happened it happened during a dialogue scene (the one in the attic towards the start of the game), which should be even less likely because it wasn't even loading anything at the time. Of course, I am hyping this up to be more of a problem then it actual is, and there is a chance that it may just be something my computer is doing. 

story wise:
Honestly, I don't know what to say that hasn't been said. This is a sequel game, if you played the original, you'll like this one, if you haven't you'd probably find a lot of the character beats uninteresting. The sole exception to that is the two new thieves, one of which is just adorable and the other of which is one of the funniest characters in any video games I have ever played.  Also, keep in mind that this game is a lot shorter then the original, which to be fair was a long game, but even beyond time spent, the first couple of dungeons were fillery, not bad, just not particularly important. I still had fun with it though.

Game play:
No, it is not turn based, and yes the new combat can take a little bit to get used to, but its fun in its own way and I really enjoyed it and it makes this game feel like its own distinct thing and not just Persona 5 expect smaller and a tacked on story.

author: 7b409a57abe653f4b41476a1373a2152
content:
While this is a longer review, this does not talk much about any combat/spoilers present in the game. This is instead a look at the game from a series perspective, so there may be other reviews more suited to your taste if this is not what you're looking for. I am not including a TL:DR because the review is a little scatterbrained despite it's length. If this helps even one person then I'm glad.

In many ways, Persona 5 Strikers is like a sequel to Persona 5. This isn't an original statement, as many describe the game this way, but the fact that it can be described as a sequel speaks volumes for one simple reason: P5S is just a spinoff. Atlus, along with the other studio that helped produced this work, were so bold as to mix ideas from the long-standing Persona/SMT with combat likened to Nier:Automata and Devil May Cry. It's very well done; the aesthetic that makes 5 stand out is still present here, and it is very faithful to the original game. I wouldn't say that it follows up perfectly after the release of Persona 5 Royal, (because this game released in Japan about a month before Royal went worldwide) so don't expect any of the characters/content from Royal here. I will say that a lot of the ideas for Royal were taken from this game, such as the thought process behind the Showtime! mechanic, so if you're familiar with some of the more recognizable content they added in Royal which was not present in the base Persona 5, you'll be glad to find it here. 

Persona 5 Strikers does contain some slight spoilers for Persona 5, so be warned if you haven't experienced 5 that there may be some things that are present here which could surprise you. I want to mention one key aspect that this game made me constantly think about though: the only thing holding Persona 5 Strikers, a SPINOFF title, from feeling like a main series game, was the lack of any confidant/social link mechanic. While this is disappointing, the fact that this can even be considered a downside should speak volumes for the game itself. There are only two instances in the game where any activity related to hanging out with a friend from the confidant/social link mechanics in other Persona games exist here. However, it should be considered greatly that following the events from Persona 5, you should not even need a confidant/social link bond with the characters in this game, considering that aside from the two new additions, you've already met and experienced hardship as well as friendship with every other character as the Phantom Thieves. 

Another major advantage this game has is replayability and content. In your first playthrough, if you are even just a little adventurous, you will likely fuse most of the personas and have done just about all of the unique mini bosses present. Although, unlike in base 5 and Royal, the hardest difficulty for this game is locked behind a first completion of the game and then the completion of the post-game content. Let me say that if you're like me, and want a challenge from a game, the hard difficulty from a generic playthrough provides more difficulty than Persona 5/Royal's hardest difficulty. The hardest difficulty in this game is much, much more difficult than that. So trust me when I say that this game has enough content and replayability value, especially for those who want the challenge and unique achievements you can only gain through a merciless NG+ run. 

As a final statement for this review, which has been all over the place, there is one more thing I want to mention. Fans of Persona 5 love the game for a lot of reasons; it's not a huge stretch to say it's a masterpiece in it's very flooded genre, which happens to be one of my favorite game genres. In my (and many others) experience, the music for Persona 5 is the one of the best parts of the whole experience. I am especially happy to say that the new music found in Persona 5 Strikers, be it the new battle themes and remixes of old battle themes or the background/tone setting music, is fan-fu**in-tastic. My personal favorite songs are "Crossover" and "Counter Strike", so be sure to check them out if you love the music but aren't sure about getting the game. Thanks to anyone who happened to read through this, and sorry for not having a TL:DR. If this helps even one person make the decision either to or not to buy the game, then that is enough for me. Let's hope for more PC releases and ports for this series and SMT!

author: 0b3b347d68f05eb09248ea8806bad0b1
content:
The game is great.  A perfect balance of Musou style combat and plenty of breath takers between missions.  Story so far is good, but I am still not too far into it yet.  I have actually never played P5 before, so I will wonder if I will be able to follow all of the elements of story well enough.  So far, so good.

I do hate that you now HAVE to be online to play the game.  I know, it isn't that big of a deal, but it is a restriction I can't stand.  I guess that is the Denuvo talking.  If having to go online just to play a single player game is a deal breaker, I would suggest moving on from this.  

Other than that, if you like Musou or want more Persona 5 content, this is a great addition with great gameplay and an excellent soundtrack.

Ogni prigione che si va a fare è strutturata, usando le debolezze e le capacità dei nemici, in modo da incoraggiare l'utilizzo di uno specifico ladro fantasma (nella prima Panther, nella seconda Fox, nella terza Noir...) e ciò rende il sistema di combattimento più piacevole, dato che ognuno dei ladri fantasma ha un suo modo di combattere differente dagli altri. author: 65c840d13de752ee9e48815126b1d1ef
content:
For the people who played the Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal this game feels like a treat to the fans of those games.
Persona 5 Strikers is a spin-off sequel of the original Persona 5 which takes place after the events of that game.
This game keeps the awesome and flashy art style of the P5 and tweaks it's original soundtracks to fit in this fast action based game, making it a joy to both see the stunning visuals and listen to the amazing "new" soundtracks.
The battle system is not the classic Dynasty Warriors system, it's more polished and with a lot more tweaks including the "Persona" skills. That battle system and the amazing soundtracks combined make battles a lot more fun and addicting to play.
Also the game runs smoothly, 60 fps and well animated character models makes it pleasant to the eyes, ALTHOUGH I have experienced a lot of random crashes during loading times, making hours of playtime go to waste because there is no auto save feature which can make you pissed off.
This game is a solid recommendation to the people who enjoyed P5 and P5 Royal and want to see more of the Phantom Thieves.

author: 5a73f43bf61151f9817f0621ca6c3d29
content:
If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona you enjoy the game. I'd give this title a 3.5 out of 5 being honest. It's like the best of both worlds but it does everything slightly worse. Example:

Persona 5: Confidants, city activities, new game plus upon completion of the title. 
Persona 5 Strikers: No confidants (replaced by team friendship or whatever its called), all of the previous confidants are gone on vacation in the city and you will never see them. New Game Plus is only unlocked after 100% the game.....which removes the purpose behind the new game plus. I'm not going to play through again for 1 persona.

Dynasty Warriors: Large Uninterrupted battles
Persona 5 Strikers: Have to enter battles the persona way by ripping off the opponents masks then attacking. 

Nice addition/subtraction: The negotiation system is gone. While I eventually got good at it in 5/R, the minigame was kinda pointless. Just collecting a persona via battling is a welcomed changed.

Good: Can enter/exit dungeons without day constraints. It doesnt pass time. There isn't much to do outside of missions anyways but hey at least they removed this as well. 

Combat system is fun. It's not a straight up ripoff of Dynasty warriors and all of the characters feel unique. 

Story is meh, predictable, and kinda wears out its welcome. For the first time ever playing a persona series I found myself wanting the game to end. I always loved the story telling between P4G, P3P, and P5/R. When you take away the great story, complex palaces now replaced by really large prisons, and confidants, the game doesn't feel the same. 

I was pleased with amount of Persona available and some actually have unique moves. Would I recommend full price? Nope. But do I regret my purchase? No. 

This game's sweet point would be about 40 bucks for someone who's a die hard fan of Persona. I also almost forgot, the performance on this game is wonky. Sometimes it's amazing then sometimes things just break and I just don't get it. I've occasionally seen the shadow on the table of your vehicle doing weird things that snatch your attention. I was in the city and it turned black multiple times and I couldn't see anything. And frame rate randomly drops. I have a 3090 playing between 1080p and 1440p.

author: 20bf392988da505a97aeea1f618dc8a7
content:
The short review was that it was quite good and I encourage you to buy it.

Longer answer follows.

Combat is snappy and fun especially as you get good at it, navigating the jails is interesting and never tedious, I find Persona really works with a more open dungeon system and non turn based combat. I would genuinely be fine with more of these going forward.

characters were well written, old characters get more depth and new characters are great, even those with little screen time.

There are a decent variety of Personas, not as many as in the main game but that’s to be expected and never feels lacking.

I do have a personal gripe however, one contains spoilers for Persona 5: Royal and one does not.

non spoiler: Why is Joker’s trauma never explored in this? it would make for great character depth, I know I know protag for people to put themselves onto, but what about the interrogation room? being responsible for the thieves? more? these things are traumatic and deserve to be explored

Spoilers now so continue to read at your own risk ————

Hey Atlus! So! why’d you take Akechi’s backstory, traumas, and aesthetic and give them to anime tony stark instead of just including Akechi!

The end of P5R shows he lives. And this shit is so...Glaring. You guys even basically gave him Akechi’s sword along with everything else like how blatant can you be.

Really holding out for a P5R: Scramble because it’s a slightly irksome blemish.

author: e37c6194b96e52b4b559aedc5e3822ad
content:
I usually don't like musou games. To give you an example, I didn't like Hyrule Warriors even though I love the Legend of Zelda (it's my favorite franchise) so I was unsure buying this one.

Welp, just like Persona 5 made me like turn based RPGs, Persona 5: Strikers made me like musou games.
Really, there's everything you need, the fighting is dynamic and unlike in Hyrule Warriors, you don't have to run around the map to capture objectives and hope you'll be there on time. It's like in Persona 5, you see an enemy and you choose to engage it or not.

The story follow the one from Persona 5 (not royal though, no Kasumi here :/) and it's really interesting to follow the phantom thieves continue there journey. They really worked on it, and I'm glad it's not just a quick cashgrab.

Minor spoilers ahead
[spoiler] I was really glad that the game made you go on a road trip around Japan. Being someone that fell in love with the country, discovering more about it was a really good surprise. [/spoiler]

Overall I'm 35 hours in, didn't finish it yet (I'm doing all the side quests) but I'm apparently pretty far so you'll maybe have for 45-50 hours of playtime before finishing it totally which I consider pretty good, not at the level of Persona 5 but I was expecting way worse.

So, should you buy it ?
If you already played through Persona 5 or Persona 5: The Royal then yes, it's worth every penny.
If not, you'll have trouble with the story, it's not the most important thing but it's like beginning Star Wars at the fifth one.

Edit: Finally fully finished it, more than 70 hours of playtime, this game is definitely worth it.

author: 5c5ecded3d465ffe94793f4db4244d23
content: Honestly I liked this game way more than regular Persona 5. It felt more meaningful and less just take out the bad guy to change their heart. The characters felt so much more alive and the new characters were so loveable. Gameplay was the by far the best in the series and the jails had such fun creative designs. The soundtrack is incredible, the story felt more impactful and it got me so hooked ever since the 4th jail. The ending was beautiful and the graphics were just stunning at times. It makes me so happy to see how far persona has come and it is by far my favorite game series. This game is worth the 60 dollars completely. I wouldn't even hesitate  to play it again.  I really hope Persona continues to grow as a series and reach more people as it really is special.

author: 356b5c5d7a4a5ff9b3b8990e248b0688
content:
[h1]Persona 5 Strikers gives us a completely new experience from the developer's past games.[/h1]

48 hours and one game clear later, I [b]finally[/b] feel qualified to write a review.
I walked into Persona 5 Strikers thinking it was [b][i]yet another musou game.[/i][/b] I have never been so wrong about a video game in my entire life.

[h1][b]Omega Force[/b] changed the traditional [i]"Clear this area, go to outpost A, defeat enemy B" [/i]and crafted a new experience that made sure the game [i]remained[/i] a [b]Persona[/b] game before it is a [b]musou [/b]game.[/h1]

The combination of both a captivating story and involved button mashing combat (it makes sense if you think really hard about it) results in the [b][i]ENTIRE[/i][/b] Persona 5 Strikers experience.
I honestly thought I was going to open up this game and be put in a menu-based system where I had to select my destination to move from point A to point B. I didn't expect a well-written story, or lengthy, enjoyable cutscenes, and map areas that were more than just [i]"Go[/i][b][i] [/i][/b][i]here! Your ally is being attacked! Help x! Don't let y fall!"[/i]
If you look at all of the past musou games, they are all the same copy and pasted formula. Same map layouts, different textures and models. The only thing that's probably different in each one are the characters and stories. Persona 5 Strikers, by definition from experience, broke free from this category.
What the game has retained from Omega Force's past games was the combat system, and that's about it. We are granted an enhanced combat system that allows usage of Personas, Ambushes, and Phantom Dashes. The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.

[h1]The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.[/h1]

The story is incredible. The characters are incredible. The music is incredible.
We are allowed time outside of jails to do.. [i]Persona[/i] things. Our Personas level up, we play with their skills and passives, and we continue on.
The request system grants us access to new challenges that give us items and xp. Some of the requests pose more of a challenge than the main story, and the rewards are all the greater for it!

[h1]You are rewarded as you play.[/h1]

At a glance this can sound confusing. Most games have an ending point as far as content and unlockables about halfway through their playthrough. Even when you thought you unlocked everything and can just farm stuff, the game gives you [i]even more[/i] as you progress through the story; it never feels like it dries out, because the timing of everything you get is well placed throughout the key points of the game.

[h1]Aside from a few bugs, this game is a MUST play.[/h1]

I didn't finish the first palace of the original Persona 5. The game did not captivate me as much as Persona 4 Golden or this game did. But after playing this, I wouldn't mind playing the prequel game and treat it exactly as such. You can enjoy this game even if you haven't played the first game. It's definitely a new experience for the genre, and I highly recommend picking it up to see for yourself!

author: 89968e71e7fa50afa37d0b261584b49a
content:
To be honest; this is a weird one.

You get in this game thinking it is a musou game; so what you do is to mow hordes of generic enemies, and the occasional elite. Not in this game. 

I found myself confused at what this game want to be, and while I recommend this game; I can say that it is not what I was expecting, even after playing the demo. 

The good: it is P5, including all the tropes you already know if you played the P5 or other persona games; but the combat is fundamentally what change things around. In P5 you have turn based combat; you need to be stealthy and can be very strategic; to the point where each game session take hours to go through; because the game is fundamentally a RPG.

Here you have a similar approach; but the combat is a 1 vs many as in other musou games. This would not be bad if the game was allowing you to roam around and just decimate the ton of generic enemies like in other dinasty warriors games; but here you can't do that. First because your health and SP are ridiculously low; so playing a musou game like a musou game would end up in quick game over. So you end up playing a game that is like a light version of P5 and with real time combat instead of the turn based. It is weird, and you can see it once you start to play the game.

The demo does not show you that aspect of the game; so if you play the demo, be ready for P5S to be different from the demo. What bother me the most is the long amount of time needed to play each stage; you need to play this game not like a musou game, and that is what I don't really like.

Also the game is very confusing with the UI and all effects going on. With P5 it is ok because you are in a turn based flow; no need to move the camera, no need to press buttons together to execute a special attack; so the flair of the artistic choices in the UI are welcome.

Here it is a mess; while you try to make a combo; can't see what is going on, and if an enemy is ready for the "pile up" attack you do with the B button; you can't see it unless you rotate the camera constantly to be aware of your surroundings. The combat itself is fast paced and mid tier enemies can mess you up fast, if you don't pay attention. Not sure if it is the angle, the field of view or what else, but this game does not play as well as a dinasty warrior game for sure; so getting a feel for what is going on is really hard.

Other than that, I enjoy the game overall; but if I would know that this game is more like P5 with real time combat and less dinasty warriors, I would probably wait for a sale, instead of buying it at full price.

7 out of 10 for me; lots of hours to sink in; if you can put up with the difficulty and the flashy UI during combat

author: df27b7edd3dc508c80e521d8421c53fb
content:
A direct sequel to the incredible Persona 5. The main star is an awesome action combat system that is extremely faithful to the trademark Persona JRPG combat mechanics. Every single character is very different and a lot of fun to play. It's so good that I'd be happy if every Persona game going forward had it. A bunch of jamming new songs from Lyn, and returning remixed favorites as well. A lot of quality-of-life changes to fusion. The new characters are interesting, likable, and have good character arcs. It's also a much more manageable ~40 hours than the ~100+ of P5.

The story is a little fanfictiony, which is somewhat expected in Persona spin-off games. You'd better like Japanese food, because the game basically revolves around how awesome it is. The main departure from Persona 5 is the lack of a "time economy" (aka limited days) and the lack of social links.

It's pretty mandatory to have played Persona 5 (either version, references to Royal are basically non-existent); it will spoil large parts of the plot (if you care about that sort of thing), but more importantly, you'd have a hard time caring about the characters without the 100+ hours of context from P5.
