author: 8ed8af404fbe52a1aa4d95c3abd6588e
content:
I love the Persona Series.

I love that Atlus is taking PC more seriously.

I hope that SMT + Persona and anything else by Atlus, Sega, and Sony come to PC.

But this game has performance issues on PC. It crashed on me many times, and I thought that I was having issues with my Bluetooth since I was playing on my Xbox One controller via BT. Nope. All my other games work fine playing many hours with my controller. This particular game just keeps crashing during some battles.

The game itself is pretty decent, but not amazing. I honestly take solace in that fact since it's not supposed to be a "flagship" persona game. So don't expect it to be your GOTY or anything. 

Not recommending it due to the performance issues, but definitely a buy for Persona fans.


Edit: I wanna expand on the actual gameplay + story. 

The story is mostly similar to regular P5 with a few 'villains' that need to have a change of heart. As the story progresses, you and the gang find a new one in the same fashion as the games prequel and some of your teammates may play a role in each as it might relate to them in some way. So, don't expect any change to the typical formula. (Atlus, if you're reading this, try something new)

The gameplay is a hack n'slash taking inspiration from some musou games. However, instead of hordes of them attacking you at a time, you ambush guards that spawn a group of enemies for you to fight. You can switch between your party to play as whoever you want and each of them have their own move sets. There are also special abilities that you can use to down enemies that are weak to them(similar to P5). The level designs are ok, but they're kind of a chore to run around in. I do like the dire shadow boss fights, though. The one main boss fight I was in was pretty decent, but nothing that really grabbed me into the fight through some sort of mechanic that would have kept me on my toes.

What could have made it more fun is if they took note from the Batman Arkham games and allowed more freedom of movement. Joker is shown as being gymnastic and a bit of a freerunner. Imo, they should have taken aspect and expanded on it a bit. It doesn't necessarily have to be 1:1, but something more aligned with the cutscenes they show would be welcomed. It's not an open world game, I know, but maybe create some interesting ways to get to the objective?

Overall: 8/10

author: 20b8421e39cc5f148e91eff623ece6b9
content:
[h1]P5天下第一——请务必赶紧让p5r上线[/h1]
评测内容分为三部分：游戏质量、新手上手攻略、购买建议。

[h1]游戏质量：[/h1]

1、玩法：
p5s作为p5后日谈，和本体的回合制玩法不同，p5s是以无双为战斗机制的，是一部试验性质比较重的作品，但是和一般传统的无双不太一样，它有着P系列的特色系统，包括面具、weak等。操作难度虽然不高，但是仍然保持了回合制的策略要素。想要打的很有观赏性的话，什么时候切哪个P，换哪个角色，场景互动，showtime什么时候放，都是有讲究的。个人觉得比光荣的老无双玩着有意思多了，单调的重复割草很容易视觉疲劳，机械的劳动很容易乏味，但是搭配了P系列的策略性，同时操作机制不会出现一招鲜的情况，大大增加了可玩性。


虽然名为无双，但是其实HARD难度还是蛮容易刮痧的，特别是前期，对动作游戏玩家来讲难度不高，但是对不怎么玩动作游戏的玩家来讲还是有一定难度的。单纯想体验剧情也可以easy完事。

本作光荣大大简化了凹P系统，比前作中刷P、凹P的情况轻松了不少，对于我这种前作凹P凹到吐的，不是很喜欢的凹P的玩家来说是一个福音。

本作的战斗节奏我很喜欢，一天玩了十多个小时也不觉得很累，战斗剧情张弛有度，打一会看一会剧情，休息之余看怪盗团斗嘴，打嘴炮调剂一下还是很放松的。

2、音乐：
本作新加入的音乐虽然不及前作那么惊艳，但是也还算不错，welcone to the jail我个人非常喜欢（我太爱这电吉他和贝斯了）。部分是原作战斗曲的变奏，也很不错。Last surprise依旧还是那么燃，听着life will change打一天也完全不觉得腻。只是可惜的是不知道为什么take over没出现。希望能把这首前作经典的战斗曲加回来。

3、画面：
     虽然和前作不是一个引擎，但是整体画风和设计都是原来的味道，细看虽然有些区别，但是比起这个，我更开心的是——没有锯齿狗牙了，当时p5s在ns上登录时的锯齿严重程度真的非常离谱，加上本身720P的画质，实在是有点劝退。这一大问题在pc上基本没有出现，非常舒服。

     本身作品pc优化非常不错，对配置要求很低，即便是1060的笔记本1080P玩起来也没有掉帧情况，画面也不次于ps上的画质。

4、剧情·：
      剧情其实说实话感觉不像前作那么惊艳，最后的boss也是让我有点懵逼，倒是很符合这家伙神经兮兮的设定，比较胃疼。有些地方也有点换皮偷懒的感觉，[spoiler] 但是我估计不止我一个人会觉得第二个boss像肖战割割吧[/spoiler] 。本质上还是基于荣格心理学，反应社会现象、社会问题，虽然不及前作，但是单独拎出来看还是值得一看的。
[h1][quote=]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]　欢迎关注 [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38287879]网易UU鉴赏家培养计划[/url][/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [th]　来这里找优质游戏、开黑日友、白嫖UU时长卡　[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [th]　和小伙伴开黑Among Us记得用UU哦_(:з」∠)_　[/th]
    [/tr]
[/table]
[/quote][/h1]

[h1]新手上手攻略[/h1]

1、勤存档、勤存档、勤存档
目前pc的p5s仍然会时不时因为不明原因而突然闪退，个人20h档炸了3次，近4、5个消失的努力直接消失，加上探索监狱期间不能随意存档，必须到检查点才可以存档，探索时如果不在检查点勤存档的话一旦炸了基本几个消失的努力就白费了。

2、关于输出

前期本身P（面具）就不多，sp的上限和回复（基本靠药）都很少，基本不够，所以主要靠搓招（C技），即XY(C1:Y,C2:XY C3:XXY依次类推)，最后一下可以发动当前面具的一个技能切不消耗sp。

前期主要的输出其实更多的依赖于龙司和狐狸，龙司特点在于其每次C技都可以蓄力，输出主要靠一个C2的蓄力，X按下后Y长按，蓄满之后伤害非常可观，最强的一点是，蓄力期间他是可以翻滚闪避的（虽然闪避期间无法增加蓄力时长），简直梦回魔女1修罗刀蓄力offset，基本joker成型之前就靠他来打输出了。狐狸fox则是强在其破盾的能力，它的C3是一个百烈突刺，破盾效果极佳，同时C3之前可以先C5上一个增加连击数的buff可以强化C3，破盾奇快，但是由于本身需要大量的时间来释放，所以非常依赖队友的控场和本身的冰冻技能，所以一般建议是先C5buff，然后冰冻再C3破盾。

莫纳和杏组合在面具达到一定等级后可以迅速吸收sp，本身杏的面具就具备一个对敌人造成异常恢复sp的被动，搭配异常状态强化后在面对大量敌人的时候那个sp恢复远大于消耗。莫纳舔猫本身其实主要是担当奶妈的一个作用，但是如果搭配杏则可以配合其自带的超绝技巧被动和风属性打出非常可观的输出，并不比后期的joker差太多，但是对于弱风和火的敌人效果才会比较明显。

真和春我个人不是很怎么用，不是很清楚。，

新增的Sofia是一个比较万金油的角色，本身主要靠C3的·debuff和C4的祝福光柱来打输出，特殊技配合目押还可以强化本身的攻击和技能输出和范围。

3、关于凹P

本作的P的技能继承主要是靠合成来完成的，给P升级主要靠pp点数来进行，而点数则除了本身获得p时给的一点，主要来源其实是分解。

接下来是关于如何获得快速获得pp点数，凹出你想要的99p的方法：

第一种方法：选择一个初期的P（1w块左右的就行），把他升级升满（把点数全用了），然后把这个P登录（重点！一定要登录），接着把它分解掉，我们就能获得比直接不升级分解多得多的pp点数，这个时候我们再去登录那里，用钱买（直接就可以买到我们之前升级完成的P，且价钱比我们之前买的时候也贵不了多少）一个我们刚才分解的P，再把它升级，这样循环往复，直到99级，然后继续买——分解——买就可以获得大量的点数了。当然，这个方法依然需要钱，但是比其他方法刷pp点数要快的多，把刷点数的事转化成了刷钱。

[spoiler] 第二种方法：风灵月影yyds！[/spoiler] 

与sp的恢复相关的凹P：（重点！）
这作的sp恢复很少，后期主要依赖面具的被动——灵魂窃取（重点！）靠施加异常状态来吸sp，前期最快获得这个被动则是依赖那个南瓜灯笼（重点！），然后通过合成来继承这个技能，这样在面对复数敌人时我们就可以迅速恢复sp。

[h1]购买建议：[/h1]

P5s虽然是一部非常优秀的作品，但是也不是适合所有人。
两个问题：

一个是价格本身，如果你有PS的话，现在PS盘的定价比这便宜不少，玩完后还可以出掉回血，pc目前400+定价确实不占优势。

二是游戏本身，p5s作为后日谈，是和前作p5剧情联系很紧的，如果没有接触过前作很难看懂剧情细节，如果没玩过前作建议至少去看看视频补一下前作剧情再玩s。再者是类型本身，由于s和前作不一样，不是经典回合制，所以如果感觉难以接受无双为核心（其实无双也做的很好玩），建议慎重考虑入手。

author: a86a5676adf55f35b4e10b3946b06a23
content:
I was a bit worried at first that this game wouldn't live up to Persona 5, and well, I shouldn't have been. This game is fun. It's a lot of fun. The combat is so much fun, it's fun to go looking for it instead of avoiding the JRPG vanilla Persona 5 which gets tiring after 100 battles of grinding. It also doesn't take itself too seriously, I mean, you can ride a skateboard and run over shadows with it. You get to do realtime combat with all-out attacks, follow-ups, one-mores, technicals, persona skills/swapping, baton-passes, etc etc. It's a blast to play. I HIGHLY implore you play the game on Hard for your first run. This game NAILS hard mode so well. Unlike other games that make their higher difficulties bullshit and unfair, this game makes it fair. Not only are the enemies tougher, but so are you. You do more damage as well. Combined with dodging and countering, it makes for a super fun combat experience.

The story is pretty damn good so far too. It feels like a proper sequel to Persona 5, though any part of the game like the base game does feel a bit more empty / simplified. Keep in mind that this game is a sequel to the vanilla Persona 5, NOT ROYAL. All the characters are the same as ever and enjoyable to watch and interact with. While Confidants/Social-Links are not present, you still get to bond with your friends a good amount not only in combat but in the real-world through events; reminiscent of Persona 4.

The biggest complaint you'll probably hear from this game are the bugs. The game has this weird tendency to crash whenever you leave/enter the Metaverse. I'm unsure why. You can luckily save a lot in this game, especially right before you load a new area so it shouldn't be that much of a hindrance as long as you save. The game also has a 60fps cap and some poor Anti-Aliasing which I hope will be fixed with a patch. It's not enough to make the experience any less enjoyable, I just hope it's fixed soon because it may be more buggy depending on the hardware.

Overall, very fun game. Definitely worth the price. It's around 50 hours I've seen from other playthroughs. Not too far off from the length of Persona 4. There's a good amount of fan-service here. I highly would not recommend this game if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal yet, as you probably won't have as much of an emotional connection with the characters / plot as you would with. The DLCs aren't very worth it in my opinion, unless you get them from the Deluxe version. The All-Out Attack Pack seems to be relatively worthless, while the Legacy BGM Pack is a bit pricey and only worth it if you're a big Persona fan. (Or just like Mass Destruction)

author: 9de426fe652d57b78d8491e31e44315b
content:
Persona, and Shin Megami Tensei by extension, have a pretty sizeable barrier to entry when it comes to engaging players. Turn based RPGs have their fans, but there are many people who find their gameplay loops to be unengaging. Persona 5 Strikers does an amicable job of bridging the gap, bringing classic persona tropes and mechanics to a more action oriented gameplay style. 

This is no Musso/Warriors game, at least not in the same style of Hyrule Warriors or One Piece Pirate Warriors. If anything this plays more like a faster paced Kingdom Hearts game, for better and for worse. This game oozes with style, and its gameplay mechanics are just deep enough to be interesting while not going too deep into combo centric button strings. 

That said, it's far from perfect. First and most glaring are the crashing issues. This game needs you to save often, and a mistimed crash can erase a good bit of effort since saving while dungeon crawling is limited to checkpoints. A saving system like this is fine, but when your game will crash without warning- it makes the checkpoint system feel less like a stopgap and more like a slight to a player who lost 40 minutes of exploring because they didn't save. 

Beyond that, it's a direct sequel to Persona 5, which is not available on the PC. This doesn't make the game unenjoyable to new fans, but it does throw you right back into the action assuming you know most everything about the Phantom Thieves and their six months at Shujin Academy. Despite the gameplay being a perfect way to introduce someone not usually into RPGs into Persona- the story is perhaps the exact opposite. Although for those who played 5, or at least read some wiki pages to get some backstories, the story is a fun romp across Japan with some touching moments. 

All in all, Strikers is a good game. I hesitate to call it great for I believe a lot of my personal enjoyment comes from getting to see these characters again and a drive to 100% the game. Be wary of glitches and crashes- they will ruin some of the fun and you need to be prepared for that. But if you want some fun action combat drenched in Persona 5's signature style with some more of the Phantom Thieves: it's certainly going to scratch that itch for you. Whether that itch is worth scratching is up for you to decide.

author: e0110b9cb3b15034b2628bb05602f353
content:
[h1] this is a direct sequel to P5. newcomers will be lost [/h1]

non gameplay stuff:

this is like persona 5 2. it's another one of persona 5. all of the RPG elements are basically completely gone but the story and structure is the same (if not better and improved!), sometimes i can forget it's even a different game. i'd even say the plot seems stronger here than in persona 5 (dont get me wrong, P5 is one of my favorite games ever). it does start a little bit slow but not nearly as slow as P5.

the "real life" activities seem to have been greatly reduced, exploration of the city is marginal. however animated cutscenes and story moments have been really increased. what follows is a far more linear game where you get to have more contact with the story and the plot. the scale of strikers is smaller in terms of systems but it's also more focused.
so although i sometimes miss having extra optional activities i'd say it was a worthy trade off for having a more linear story focused game. that being said: if you are looking for a lifesim this is not it.

gameplay stuff

[b] playing on hard mode is essential [/b] although it may take a little getting used to. it might feel clunky and overly punishing until you reach the first proper bosses. but when you do whooo boy. it's great. i seriously wasn't expecting the game to be this much fun. i went in expecting the gameplay to be something i would have to grind past and overlook so i could get to the "good bits" and boy was i wrong. the gameplay is one of P5 strikers strongest aspects.

i typically don't like dynasty warrior type games but this right here is pretty darn good. standard enemy fights are really fun when their numbers are really large and there are lots of interactable objects, however, that's rarely the case. around half the time you will fight small groups, which is a little bit repetetive. that i have to admit. however the other 50% of the time it is a blast. especially in those amazing boss fights like i said. ([b]reminder to play on hard mode![/b])

oh, and frequent use of baton pass increases enjoyment by a lot! however don't expect to like every party members playstyle right away! a lot of important moves are locked away and they all take some getting used to. in many cases i disliked playing as one but then i unlocked a new move and it all clicked. (pro tip: there are really great playstyle tips for all the characters in the tutorial menu, as well as the base combo moves listings)

speaking of which when playing on hard you will have to change your party composition constanty, which is definitely a hassle i do admit. basically since you can change party in between fights it's important to cycle out those who are low on health and SP. this also helps keep the XP distribution even.

i will probably update this review when i have played more. i can't really put an arbitrary number on it but i can say that fans of persona 5 will definitively like this one. even if you don't like the gameplay (but i have a feeling you eventually will!) the story is enough to carry the experience.

i was worried that although i  would like the game i wouldn't like it enough to feel i got 60 dollars worth. i can now confidently say that my fears were unfounded. thus far the game is going above my expectations and it seems to be a worthy 60 dollar title.

author: c8eaf38cca6050b4b01d1b22ac6b2d2c
content:
[h1] Building up on its predecessor... [/h1]

Persona 5 Strikers (P5S) is best enjoyed if you played Persona 5 (P5) as it is best described as an amplified P5. The character quirks are more prevalent, the humour is more prevalent, many of the reused songs of P5 got more intense, and whether intentional or not the dialogue got A LOT more fellow-kiddy which only adds to the hilarity of it all.

Much of the music originates from P5 but they are complimented by just as many new songs for the new shop, activities, fights and metaverse locations so this is as solid as you would expect it with an added increased variety in music genres.

Finally, while mementos do not exist anymore, the game has its own grinding mechanic affiliated with new requests awarding much more interesting rewards than the simple XP and money of memento requests of P5.


[h1] ...yet also losing some of its original charm [/h1]

The social gameplay feels like a P5 lite with some systems absent, most notably the time management of activities, the levelling of social stats and the school in-class questions and exams. The absence of those systems also leads to a poorer diversity in world activities with shopping being the only real activity left. Even then, the majority of shopping is done in an all-in-one online shop with magic instant delivery (the game fails to provide a legitimate explanation for this although it tries to). It is a bit disheartening, but the new shop UI and song make up for it to some degree.

Cooking becomes a much more important part of the game, becoming more diverse and more invested with you being encouraged to scour all shops to find new recipes and ingredients and now contributes to the bond system replacing the P5 confidants.

The bond system allows for a certain level of customisation of your experience as instead of linear confidant progression, you can invest your skill points however you want, specialising in certain areas in the order that you want. 
The bond progression is also more gameplay inclined, progressing as you play like a glorified XP bar, and while friends will give you missions to somewhat enrich their personality, those will have a much stronger “RPG side quest” flair to them rather than the personality or story focus of P5’s confidant system.
However, the gang evolves as a complete group more often and with significantly more voice acting than P5, you get to see a lot more chemistry between the different members than you did in the previous game.


[h1] Combat, a successful conversion that stays true to its origins [/h1]

Making up for the less diverse real world, the metaverse has gotten an upgrade with a more vertical level design and Joker having gotten a lot more agile. Many more objects can be jumped on and off from but can also be interacted with in unique ways which will tie directly into combat.

And combat is the biggest change of this game, switching from turn based to a hack and slash which is, overall, a success. Everything you learnt from P5 is still here: personas, all out attacks, knock downs, elemental affinities and weaknesses, gun special attacks and the new animations, combat sounds and of course the UI are all satisfying and switching between powers, combos and characters is as smooth as can be.

The system can feel overwhelming at first to someone new to Persona as you are being given access to the full cast of P5 right from the start which is a lot of combos and a lot of persona powers to learn.
Once you figure it out non-boss enemies will very quickly fall into the "one shot combo" area which can make the game feel a bit repetitive and/or grindy; something P5 already suffered from but P5S is at least a lot faster to switch in and out of combat.

However, while you will be facing several dozens of enemies at once quite early on leading to a lot of visual mess (albeit good looking mess), the game remains fairly forgiving and will let you get through a few levels with simple X and RT smashing while you figure out your combos.

Afterwards, the game will nevertheless throw significantly more mini-bosses your way than P5 did which makes for more interesting combat; although the danger of those mini-bosses is damaged by the leniency of the game. Indeed, saving spots have become much more abundant than they were in P5 and without the time management component, the game encourages the player to jump in and out of the metaverse to get a complete free recharge of HP and SP before teleporting back to the save spot with no downsides whatsoever, making the game devoid of resource management if one makes use of this mechanic. 

Master Arts are a new system in P5S which are awarded for directly playing a character. After playing a character for a sufficient amount of time additional combos are unlocked and that amount of time is arguably too little. However, it is an interesting mechanic to reward players for sticking to a character with some additional toys.

Finally, the bosses. Transforming turn-based boss mechanics into hack and slash mechanics is no easy task and P5S does not really succeed at it...or maybe it chose not to and that's a good thing.
Bosses go through different moves and phases and the ideal strategy is often to learn their sequence of action, wait for the sequence to end, exploit their weakness, and blow your combos during their break between two sequences and repeat. This is in essence a turn-based system, except you get to press the dodge button to avoid damage during the boss' "turn".
It's however not a bad system, bosses in P5 were very enjoyable and they are just as enjoyable if not more in P5S. While they get away from the hack and slash fast paced power fantasy and fall more into a the calmer strategically turn-based realm of things, this change of pace in combat approach is most welcome and still manages to capitalise on some of the new aspects of the combat.


[h1] A great sequel yet a questionable first release [/h1]

Overall P5S is a great game for people who wanted straightforward easy fun with more of the P5 characters' personalities and interactions with some extra new gameplay ideas which all work well. 
However, with the removal of much of what made P5 such a unique and interesting adventure, P5S fails to exceed its predecessor, although it also does not feel like it is trying to and is content with being, in essence, a high-quality expansion.
While newcomers to Persona or Persona 5 might be able to enjoy P5S as a standalone, the game is unquestionably a better experience by having played the original Persona 5 which makes the release of this game on steam before a potential Persona 5 Royal port questionable at best.

author: 32daea7c89b05bef9f9232c53667fa01
content:
Once again great to see the Phantom Thieves in action especially on PC. If you plan to play this game and haven't played Persona 5 (Vanilla or Royal), this may give away some spoilers from them and you may lose context on certain things. 

Game is real fun. Combat is typical of Musou/Warriors games with the Persona style twist. The new characters are amazing. A several scenes alone (if you had played P5 prior) remind you why you loved Persona in the first place. 

On the technical side of things. In the beginning of the game there are a few issues with audio. Mainly on the English dub end. Characters sound lower in several sections of dialogue. For example Yusuke, sounds lower than the rest of the group in the first few scenes of the game. I think that's due to the situation the English cast and crew were placed in mixing audio because of COVID

Second, some stuttering issues at 60fps on 3D cutscenes at times. I'm on windowed mode. Haven't checked at full screen and/or 30fps.

Thirdly, I have experienced I believe one or two crashes already. This was on windowed mode too. Luckily I wasn't too far from certain checkpoints so I didn't lose alot of progress. I recommend anyone else to continually save.

author: 765d611750e35a49a88db2a31b072360
content:
I just couldn't wait for this to be released.

The game follow up Persona 5 greatly, with fresh stories (without spoiling too much from the base game) and concepts, whilst keeping the core of the game. The fighting got a new dynamic to it, and is entertaining throughout the whole game. 

Now the negatives:
-The gameplay is a bit tedious. (Like you can't check side missions in palaces, so you have to get out. You can't shop from anywhere else, but from the base even though you do shopping on your phone. And you can just leave and rejoin jails to regenerate without any penalties)
-The jails (dungeons) are just a tad bit repetatives in it's objectives.

That's it. Not the perfect game, but worth it non the less. I reccomend you to play the base game quickly (with it's 150 hours of gameplay :D) before buying this game, so the story fascinates you even more.

author: f5a7c8f74e275283bbd00e7dd9fc05dd
content:
Technical:
Atlus did a great job in porting that game. It runs smooth with the occasional framedrop below 50 during the animations and cutscenes. I didn't experience any framedrops during battle, which is the most important part to me!

Graphical Setting: Everything on high, resolution scale = 1.5
PC specs: Intel i7 6700k (not OC), NVIDIA RTX 2060 (not super), 32GB RAM, game runs on a SSD.

Loading times are almost non-existent and I haven't experienced any glitches so far.

Gameplay:
That's the other point I can imagine most of you are wondering. Especially since it isn't a turn-based RPG anymore.

I was not sure if I would be able to enjoy P5 Strikers. Especially since I am used to turn-based battles in general.
FFXV really gave me a hard time trying to find some love for the game, without success.

So, here we are at P5S. I started it with the horrible experience I just explained in mind. Watching out that I would still be able to get a refund if it doesn't suit me....And what can I say? Without realizing I already player for 18 hours! :) 
I hope this encourages anyone with a similar experience to mine to give P5S a serious try. I am pretty sure you won't be disappointed!

Edit: After some more playing I can call this game "Japanese food guide 2021" for sure. Every time I play this I get hungry AF.

author: 41b99a4226ab54aa9d91230961721479
content:
比起曾经无脑割草的无双系列，P5S的战斗可以说是超乎我的预料。兼顾策略和爽快度的连招打法配合P5拽到亲妈都不认识的BGM，真是嗨到不行。剧情情怀满满，UI设计更加炫酷，可以说是原作粉丝狂喜的无双续作。
不过社（jiu）群（jian）系（ti）统（du）的删减让这个游戏除了战斗部分的日常生活比起原作差了不是一个档次，同时很多剧情和梗如果不是原作玩家也会get不到。迷宫的设计水平比起原作更是相差很远，颇有光荣风格。
综上，如果是原作粉丝，那么在不考虑价格的情况下非常推荐入手，不仅是原作剧情的补全，同时也能体验和回合制有所不同的战斗体验。如果是久仰P5大名想要入坑的玩家，那么我并不建议先入这一作，价格是一方面，更希望这类玩家能够先去体验原作本身的魅力。

最后，新岛真天下第一

author: 69deb3d86db25b3e8b0f0d814a7839bf
content:
For someone that's never played a Persona game in my life, this one is pretty decent. The RPG hack 'n slash feels much better than the turn based gameplay that the others have, which is the only reason I bought and played this. However after 20 hours of gameplay I feel like the fun is over, the story is good to an extent, go and rescue people from being brainwashed, yada yada. But that's the extent of the story and gameplay. 

I also feel like the everything revolves around the gameplay rather than story. Up to the third dungeon you are doing the same thing you have been doing for the previous two, maybe it's just me but going and getting [x] but you have to do [y] before being able to do [x] three times over seems monotonous and boring. There's nothing unique that changes in the dungeons that makes those aspects better, it's just the same gameplay loop and I personally got bored of doing the same thing to go onto the same thing again, but in a different area with different enemies. 

As I stated previously with the game feeling like it revolves around doing the same thing to progress the story. It would've been better for me if to progress the story you wouldn't have to do the same thing you did in the last dungeon, but it was a bit different. Instead of go to three bird cages, fight mini boss, which then allows you to fight the actual boss, there could've been other ways to lead up to the final boss fight, such as puzzles, or do some task that isn't in the metaverse that unlocks a path to [x] that helps you get to the boss. 

The gameplay however is good, being able to create persona's, you have bonds/ skill tree, different characters you can play as e.t.c, it's very fun. I enjoyed playing as much as I did, but after doing the same thing for the third time, it just felt repetitive and less engaging because you already knew what you had to do,  you already knew what was going to happen. But hey, maybe that's the whole point. I just didn't enjoy that aspect.

---

After being told that the game actually gets good after the third dungeon I decided that I would give the game one last shot and well finish it, I can say for sure that I was not disappointed. Albeit what I said previously and parts of that review still holding up, the game is spectacular. Gameplay does get better after the third dungeon and it is a great story driven game, apart from spending most of it with dialogue, cut-scenes, etc. But that might just be the point of a story game. 

Some things I wanted to address though is the frequent random crashes and the inconsistency between cut scenes.

Firstly crashes, this game has crashed *a lot* for me and when I say a lot, I mean hoping for the best the game doesn't crash when you're on the last boss fight, all items used up, 2 team mates down and hoping it doesn't just seize up and tell you "no". I say this because it has happened to me at the end of boss fights where you finish a boss off, goes to a white screen, then the game crashes, very infuriating and needs fixing. 

Secondly, the cut scenes and dialogue are just inconsistent. I don't know why it's necessary for 3 types of ways to display something happening, you have the first way of just showing it via the just dialogue bars and the characters talking, you either have to progress by clicking or having it automatically do it, then there's it being rendered in the engine and an actual cut scene AND THEN there's it being an actual animation. What. The. F*&k. There are some parts in the game where it will progress in the order and it just doesn't make sense, just show me it in one way! 

But those are just some nit-picks. Great game though and introduction to the series, at least for me.

author: 0f21d13a016a55a19738fc4c9535a43c
content:
It's a sequel to Persona 5 on PC, with a new action combat system still utilizing the main loop of collecting new Persona's then fusing them to make even better Personas. You can also level up your Persona's with "Persona Points" earned through battles. It retains the amazing style/music and slick ass menus.

If you like Persona 5, buy it. Its really great for fans of those characters and seeing where this new journey takes them. The PC port has been flawless for me, 60 FPS 1440p and no slowdown or crashes yet. I really like it a lot.

author: 8e44bb5f4e205d56801a62967599e98d
content:
First of all. [h1] Hoooooo boy [/h1] Props to Omega-Force/Koei Tecmo, and P-Studio for making this game happened, and to Atlus for publishing this game to steam (praise be to Atlus). I will gladly buy any MegaTen related games.

Okay so, I'll make this as concise as possible.
The story (although a direct continuation from the base game) is basically a reimagine of Persona 5's with a bunch of changes specifically for this spin-off. I'm just gonna say it follows the same structure, that's it (for those who have played, you'll know what I mean). It actually reminds me of the movie called HER because of how the plot heavily uses artificial intelligence as its main topic. Expect a lot of dialogue since this is still a persona game.

The gameplay is good no doubt about that, actually great. Who knew that a game that uses the combination between musou combat with persona mechanics would actually work wonders, I never thought it would be this good. Each character you control has different combat style and special ability. It's really the highlight of this spin-off.

Probably the complains I have are the price and possibly, the end game content (I have my doubts on this one though) since when you finish the game, the only replayability value that this game will give you after finishing it are new game+ (you can totally 100% achievement in the 2nd playthrough) and a new difficulty. I really hope Atlus will update this game with new content, although it's unlikely to happen because this game was released in Japan a year ago and (to my knowledge) there had been no update since then.

All in all it's a good game, as expected of Atlus. Even though they really milk this series hard, you can bet the spin offs of each game are done and polished really friggin well. A definite must have for those who enjoy both persona and musou combat type of games.

author: 44fb399d20b75eca97ac72025c7ef047
content:
Why are you reading this review? It's Showtime!

Before getting into the actual review, you should understand that this is a direct sequel to Persona 5 which is a Playstation exlusive title. 
If you didnt play the original game or at read the manga or watched the horrible anime adaptation, you propably wont enjoy this game if you give any hsit about story. The game treats use as if you already know what happend, which is nice for people who actually do, but not for you if you have no clue whats going on. 
Also, I think you will find it hard to care about the characters if youre not familiar with them already, since we spent over 100 hours getting to know them and their quriks, so a scene of them hanging out and having fun is propably pretty boring for somone who doesnt know them. Unless you are somone who just mashes the "skip button" as soon as text appears on the screen, go and play Persona 5 Royal first(improved version of P5)

Now for the actual review:
This game is an absolute Banger. It really embodies the spirit of a sequel. The story is new and intresting while your previous knowledge is still helpful. The Dynasty Warrior gameplay combined with the Persona 5s unique style could have turned around really messy but they NAILED it! I have a lot of respect for creating a fun action RPG that still feels like Persona. You will still find yourself scrolling through your Persona skills to exploit your enemies weakness, All-out attacking and batton passing but now you can dash around and do cool combos and use your surroundings to your advantage. I think it goes wothout saying that all of this looks amazing, as expected for Persona 5. 
There is a good mixture of new music that bangs just as hard as the first soundtrack and old tracks (remixed or not) that make the game sound familiar. 

The game only crashed only once on me in 14 hours of gameplay, which really isnt a big deal. I cant imagine this game letting me down, thats why Im confident to write this review already, unless it isnt edited or deleted after I finished it, I stand by every word that I said :)

Go out and steal some hearts!

author: e7138892acda51f0b38b1031e36da160
content:
优化和帧数算是不伤眼睛了。
3d建模基本符合当下水准。动画也不是五毛特效，该有的都有。
特别是暂停菜单设计的挺有创意的。苏菲的购买菜单也是蛮有意思的，一个游戏的菜单都比正经的购物网站的有意思。

剧情还算一环扣一环没有特别水。
立绘也算挺好的，配上live2d的动作，总体来说还行。但是地图假大空，本来就不是无缝地图，除了监狱模式还稍微大点，日常模式很多地方都去不到。比如札幌的天桥旁边的椅子后面那么大的地方不能过去，空气墙差评。完成度一般。加个偏贵
400多太贵了贵的。这游268还算差不多。

额外吐槽就是，4代基本就是老日漫套路，转学交朋友，朋友变多，一起合作，超能力，打坏人，学园祭修学旅行到处吃喝玩乐解决些身边人的生活烦恼。有一多半都是在打里人格。
5代画风突变，立意不说但是够黑暗的。打完老师打名流，打完名流打首相。还有就是坏人基本都是劝说打倒悔改，基本直接秒的很少，看着觉得折腾来折腾去的不麻烦么，日系游戏日漫什么的也多是这种情节。不过可能这就是和超级英雄的区别，因为超级英雄是秒人的。还有期待6代，期待5本篇和p5r的上线。
we need p5r!!!!我想玩5r啊！！！！我要攻略学生会长！！！！！
推荐手柄游玩，毕竟日厂的键鼠对应做的是一如既往的比较糟糕。比如同期发售的仁王2就是。

author: 8a522e1efe825530b93f9c65b0bf62f6
content:
[h1] Persona 5 Strikes czyli Persona 5 jako mix gry akcji i jrpg. [/h1]

Jako osoba która ukończyła Personę 5 Strikes muszę poprawić tą recenzję. Persona 5, czy to wersji normalnej lub Royal, jest dla mnie grą wyjątkową. Chodź nie miałem okazji zagrać w nią osobiście (przez brak konsoli) to szansa na poznanie nowych przygód jej bohaterów podczas trwania Persony 5 Strikes ([spoiler] Gra jest kontynuacją Pesony 5 [/spoiler]) jest miłą rzeczą. Gra jest intuicyjna i po krótkiej chwili bardzo łatwo połapać się w sterowaniu i mechanikach gry. Jednak polecam zaopatrzyć się w pad - co prawda sterowanie na PC za pomocą myszki i klawiatury jest zrobione dobrze, to łatwo można zamotać się w klawiszach (szczególnie, że gra w podpowiedziach i komunikatach pokazuje sterowanie klawiaturą a nie myszką). Polecam tą grę z czystego serca. Polecam zagrać też w niedawno wydany port Persony 5 Royal.

author: db1f8fe6e17e5f7ea4f1cd8a53fc89b8
content: As someone who hates JRPGs and turn based combat, playing the original game was an uphill battle for me but in the end Persona 5 still got me to play it twice totaling over 250 hours of gameplay. Persona 5 Strikers has that special feeling that got me hooked on the original and now it's also free of the turn based combat's shackles! Combat, although hectic at times, is never a chore and the story doesn't feel forced at all, everything flows perfectly! BUT if you are looking to play this game without prior experience in the Persona 5 universe i think it might become a bit confusing and little too much to handle, at the opening hours especially. As the game's treated not like a new entry but entirely like a sequel to the original.

author: a70938e4bf885f178ddae2f85de078d3
content: It's definitely not going to be the most enjoyment you get out of a persona game, but it's a decent game overall. However, their are a few issues on PC that just are saddening. The Default controls are AWFUL. they're really bad, so I recommend using a controller, or changing them. I decided to play with a keyboard just to get the default experience. Their is a lack of multiple aspects from the original persona 5 that I wish were here, but this is a spin off game after all. The game plays well enough, their is a few minor odd things that happen (that may happen on console as well) but it isn't anything game breaking. The one thing that really makes me upset is when I alt tab, and go back into the game the dodge button (alt) will start making windows noises if you press it over and over again. (and you'll basically be using dodge alot). I hope to see more persona ports on steam! These games are great, and I'd love nothing more than to play them here, even if their are issues. I just hope some of this stuff gets patched out, or fixed in some way shape or form, and I want to look forward to some nice ports in the future!

author: e09aa7d2ae265ea2bd6c2ea424f55c3e
content:
[b]作为一位已经在PS4上白金了P5和P5S的玩家，我双手双脚支持Persona全系列登录PC。[/b]事实上，P系列在平台上的割裂使得Steam版本如今登录的P5S并未有太多的购买价值，P5正传的独占使得新购买P5S的PC玩家（以及一些NS玩家）一头雾水，不明就里。而原作的游戏流程又长达上百小时，不亲自去玩一玩，只看实况视频的话很容易睡着，挺折磨人的。索尼出于自己的机器售卖利益而独占作品使得其跨平台的衍生作玩家无法享受任何游玩体验，P系列也不应当只被“有PS4的玩家”所喜爱，如今很多没玩过原作的玩家不喜欢P5S而给差评，就是独占策略带给我们的最坏恶果。[b]玩家应当是玩游戏而不是玩平台的[/b]。

但与此同时，这款登陆了Steam端的第一部P5系列作品仍然值得所有人游玩。Persona 5的这一代作品拥有着游戏史上不说最好但绝对独一无二的游戏艺术风格，也可能是这个世代最好玩的JRPG作品。这个漫长的故事成功地把玩家的“少年心气”和严肃的“社会现实”进行了有机融合，创造出了一个异想天开但设定合理的现代世界。原作中触及的一些社会议题，在去严肃化的当代娱乐产品中是难以见到的，主角团一行人的行动，也是对目前我们社会确实存在的一些严肃问题的理想化反抗。最令我赞赏的是，P5（特别是无印版）创造了一种全新的游戏表现方式，为“游戏如何具有艺术性”或者“游戏为何是第九艺术”这个热议不衰的议题做出了自己的回答。只要你不厌恶日漫，那么P5系列绝对是值得去游玩的，会带给各位很棒的游戏体验。

而登录多平台的这部P5S，是一部非常出色的[b]后日谈[/b]，在保持了原作高质量且讨喜的画风下，给所有[b]玩过原作[/b]的玩家带来了绝佳的游玩体验。这部游戏非传统无双的战斗方式，搭配Weak系统十分有乐趣，是继FF7RE后比较让我满意的战斗系统；故事上每个“监狱”都与原作的每一章一一对应，对原作中因为篇幅限制而刻画较少的奥村春进行了非常好的形象完善；新加入的几位角色形象也十分讨喜，着墨不多但令人印象深刻。在已经玩过原作的情况下，P5S是一部不会令人失望的作品。

不过，这部作品如今的处境也略有一些尴尬：PC端售价比PS4光盘和NS卡带高了接近一倍，在没有打折的情况下绝对是毫无性价比的买卖；在没有玩过前作的情况下直接上手这部作品会味同嚼蜡，毫无游戏体验。光荣特供的刷刷刷系统使得你想要全成就就要耗费大量精力在无意义的机械劳动上，比守望先锋逆风局坐牢还累。如果你是闻P5大名而来，却完全没有对这部作品有任何了解的朋友们，购买这部作品前仍然需要谨慎。

[b]综上所述，我不太建议目前在Steam上买这部作品。[/b]有条件的玩家，可以考虑在PS4上先游玩原作，或者在视频网站上观看原作有关的动画或游戏实况。同时我也个人希望，SIE能够在未来的某个时间点，把P5以及其他更多优秀的独占作品带到更多平台，让全世界更多热爱游戏的玩家能够有机会玩到他们优秀的游戏作品。

author: 22d84ce4e6495fc2ad0817686f5e1be3
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game. If you're into that, then you'll like this game. THOUGH, nothing on this page will tell you that. BUT as soon as I saw the Koie Tecmo logo followed by Omega Force, I got a sneaking suspicion this was a Dynasty Warriors game. THOUGH, as someone who's only played a handful of these and 3 of their off shoots (including this one), I kind of like this one the best. Yeah, you can button mash, but this and Hyrule Warriors was better at forcing other actions. I've played Persona 5 for a few seconds, but got SUPER bored with how story heavy it is, and how awful the story is, this has a bit too much for me. It's a neat and faithful melding of Persona and the DW formula. Visually this is the best Dynasty Warriors has ever looked. Clear that Sega/Atlus seem to be very protective of this property and were very hands on with it. 

If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona then this will definitely scratch that itch. I'll stick around for the battles, and just blow through the story, even though I know from previous attempts of getting into this series (P4 Golden) it means I'll probably get a bad ending, oh well. I'll look up an FAQ if the alternative endings are better or if it prolongs the GAME play. I like it. 3.5 out of 5 for me.

author: d3b676d73251561db47dcc802d76345c
content:
Pros:
- Frame rate and performance are very smooth and the graphics look really sleek and clean
- More Persona on PC is always a plus
- The fantastic voice acting

Cons:
- The game play; I really thought I could push past the Dynasty Warriors style game play and continue the game but I found it way too tedious and boring.
- The story is fairly weak compared to Persona 5 Royal; it just like anime filler and has none of the same charm as Persona 5 Royal. Also has missing plot points from P5 Royal AND a fairly major character that was introduced in Royal.

author: e1151ba31f8d54538527d9c325cb0dab
content:
I love this game.

TL;DR: Story feels samey from the original game but it's still enjoyable. Gameplay has no social sim aspect but the transition into action combat was really well done, higher difficulties alleviate the button mashing issue.

I won't deny the story does feel like a rehash of the original Persona 5, but out of bias I'm fond of that familiarity, and some characters that did not get much of a spotlight in the main game such as Haru finally get a moment to shine here. You see way more group interactions in this game and I wish we had more of that in the original. The two new main characters, Sophia and Zenkichi, fit really nicely into the cast without altering the dynamic of the group that much.

Gameplay-wise I will admit it is not going to be everyone's cup of tea. The affinity and 1 More system from the series' turn-based combat was translated incredibly well into an action format, but it can still carry that notorious Musou stereotype of just mashing buttons in most normal encounters. For that reason I'd suggest playing on Hard for the best experience since it makes the benefit from exploiting affinities greater.

Also worth noting the entire social sim aspect from the main games is not here. It's pure dungeon crawling and platforming with the real world only really being used for story purposes and buying items. The Confidant system is replace by a secondary EXP bar named "BOND" that works as a sort of skill tree.

author: 9f35406eb51b5aab820a098a0ece9e32
content:
24 Hours into the game and I feel confident I have gathered enough information to provide a fair review.   Gameplay wise this feels like a love child between Persona 5, and Kingdom Hearts.    Many people try to compare it to a warrior game, but its battle type is much more like Kingdom Hearts,  yes there is tons of enemies but the RPG elements and interactions push it more toward the KH battle system.     Over all if I ignored the crashes  this is one of my favorite games.    However due to how often it crashes  even on a high end machine like mine.  I cannot possibly recommend this game to anyone.     There is 2 major crash types I have encountered,  First is the blackscreen.    This one happens when first booting up the game and in order to force it to close you have to open a new instance of windows and close it from there.    It usually only happens every other load.      Second crash happens during the course of gameplay and happens during loading screens which there is ALOT of.    There generally is alot in persona games but there felt like there was more in this one then previous.      Every 2-4 hours of gameplay you can expect to crash while transitioning between zones.     So if you do buy this game always save before you move from one zone to another in order to save frustration.        

That said,  the gameplay is over all pretty excellent the new way they handle bonding is interesting I liked using them as skill points.    And the persona point system is pretty grand too.   But the game is poorly optimized.


Edit:   Just made it past Kyoto boss and it seems after the load screen it goes to infinite black screen as others have reported.     This product seems to be faulty cannot even finish the game.

author: bc5590cd6d98564b8845376066def2ac
5aa24e7e16255862aa2639ed2866b74f
content:
Let me preface by saying I’m a big fan of SMT 1-3. I played Persona 4 shortly after it released on PS2, Persona 4 Golden when it ported to PC and of course P5 and P5 royal on PS4. They’re all amazing games that all fall within the same idea of combat, time management and Social links, but for some reason atlus decided to make this one a hack and slash. The combat feels mashy and brainless compared to what I would expect from a Persona/SMT game. I don’t doubt for a second that it’s a great game within its genre but the style of combat turned my immeasurable hype into disappointment. It just doesn’t feel right. 

Edit: 
I want to point out that when I wrote this review I had 1.5 hrs and the game had crashed once, regarding it as an anomaly. I thought perhaps I was being rash and gave the game some more time. I stand by all I previously said. Additionally the game crashed a further 3 times forcing me to replay the same scenes over and over.

If you are a Persona fan this is a must buy, especially if you really enjoyed Persona 5 and it's characters, it picks up 5 months after the end of Persona 5 and it does a great job at making you feel right at home when you start it up, it goes from it's turn based strategy gameplay to a more hack and slash action game, the combat is fun, the characters all have new and amazing outfits and the story is back to what you're used to...changing hearts as the Phantom Thieves!

author: c0adecd408f853e1be2e8d421cc5c4bb
content:
*IMPORTANT* 
This game crashes ALOT, at the worst time possible. I'm not sure why; to make things worse, the checkpoints to save the game are quite far in between so uhh, the anxiety of hoping the game won't crash while you're far away from a save point is stressful. So if you're playing, remember to save as many times as possible. Redoing what you did from the past 3 hours is not fun. 

Anyways, Persona 5 Strikers is a nice sequel for fans of Persona 5 (Royal). However, the combat is a musou-type game, being completely different from Persona 5's turn based combat. Although, it is very interesting to see how they incorporated hack and slash with the tactical use of personas & baton passes.

The overworld exploration is satisfying, being able to walk around Shibuya, Sapporo, Osaka, and so on with your pals is a nice feeling. 

One thing to note is how the new Velvet Room functions. With the removal of social links, you can't get bonus exp for your personas from social links. Instead you can level up your personas through the use of PPs (Persona Points) which is a little disappointing but it's fine.

To further explain on the removal of social links, Persona 5 Strikers introduces a mechanic called Bonds to replace it. With bonds, you may unlock certain bonus perks like "Extra Money Dropped Per Battle" & so on. You can get bond points from playing through the game.

It's a game to play if you're interested to see what's up with the Phantom Friends after the first game. Not so for the depth of the combat/gameplay, Persona 5 (Royal) still triumphs on that part. 

Some mechanics from the first game were revamped or changed to be better/worse. It's up to you to make your own opinion on it.

author: bd37c1a9055e50f59e283fb4d02180c8
content: i really like this game it is kind of a like a continuation from persona 5. i have seen some people say you can play this game even if you did not play persona 5, but in personal opinion i would recommend against that as you most likely will not understand majority of the things they bring up about what has happened in the past aka Persona 5.  I was really happy to see this game out as i am a huge persona fan and have played person 4 golden and persona 5 royal and i was really sad to have beat the game and of the ending being a sorrow goodbye. This game is a lot like persona 5 but with the formatting of Fire emblem warriors or what others have said dynasty warriors. You can use your persona in this game but there is more hand combat rather then only using your persona or automated bullets like in persona 4 and 5. i love that you can also be the other characters and walk around aka yuskue and ana and etc, that is one of my favorite things as i am a huge fan of yusuke and i love being able to explore the jails as him and use him more!  I do really enjoy this game and got it the day it released but i will say there is a ton of glitches going on as the game tends to crash in times where you are unable to save and have to restart again. That can be a real pain in the butt especially when your grinding or in the middle of a movie scene. But i overall really enjoy this game and would recommend it to any persona fan and CAN NOT WAIT FOR PERSONA 6 TO COME OUT! SOLID 9/10.

author: 27b37590523e5fcb98069b3358142ef0
content:
As a hack and slash enthusiast, I knew I had to buy this game. I had no previous experience with any Persona or Shin Megami Tensei media, but I believe this might change. Anyhow, the combat system is surprisingly very satisfying. Sure, it does not have the complexity of DMC5 or the absolute fluidity and smoothness of the original Bayonetta. However, it does not take away from the core hack and slash experience, in fact, the combo system reminds me a bit of how combos are handled in Metal Gear Rising Revengeance as you can, in theory, keep comboing endlessly, granted you don't get staggered, which, to me, is somewhat satisfying.

Overall, it's a 9/10 game for me.

author: 8531460de9b651769106ee069866d821
content:
[b]Disclaimer:[/b] this isn't a full review of the game I'm currently on the first jail, so think of it as a first impression.

[u]PROS:[/u] 

[list]
[*] Great UI design and super vibrant presentation
[*] Better Music than it's predecessor
[*] The cast really felt like they matured from the events of the og P5
[*] The battles feel like they go at a natural pace.
[*] The story overall better pacing than P5 and is more engaging
[*] Everything even remotely related to Sophie
[*] It's nice to see that Atlus has come a far way from almost incomprehensible online lingo from Personas 3 (especially the Hermit s. link) & 4 to more modern online lingo used more sparingly, and for now it won't age the games dialogue
[*] It's not Game over if Joker get's KO'ed
[/list]

[u]CONS:[/u]

[list]
[*] Horrible ridges on the modes at first (Can be fixed in settings so no biggie!)
[*] Suffers from what newer Persona games, way too easy, even on the hardest difficulty, not brainless though, you will die
[*] Gets a little repetitive but it's not painful since the story updates often and has near perfect pacing
[/list]

[u]TL;DR[/u]
This is a great game that deserves your attention; If your not super into to action and prefer the more methodical day-to-day life of the first one you probably should wait for a sale if you weren't to big on the story of the first one.But if you're iffy then give it a shot! the prologue is quick and the game-play comes in relatively early so if you don't like you could probably refund it. 85%

เพลงประกอบ ใครเคยชอบ Persona เพราะเพลงประกอบ เกมนี้ก็มาครบกันเลยที่เดียว

กราฟฟิค สวยงาม สไตล์เกมการ์ตูน อนิเมะ

เนื้อเรื่อง สนุก ดราม่า ได้ครบทุกรสชาติ แถมยังเปลี่ยนเสียงพากย์ได้ทั้งอังกฤษและญี่ปุ่น

ความยาวเกม ณ เวลาที่เขียนรีวิว 30hrs ผมยังเล่นไม่จบ เกมยาวในระดับนั้นเลยแหละ

สรุป 9/10 เกมดี มีคุณภาพ ถ้า ATLUS เอาภาคก่อนหน้ามาลงก็น่าซื้อมาเล่นอีก คุ้มค่ามาก

author: 545e4789607956ffab0513f693c6769a
content:
海外党ps4不在身边，没想到竟然上pc了，我tm玩爆！
--------------------------------------------
p5粉丝：10/10          一般玩家：8/10      喜欢无双游戏的玩家：9/10
没玩过p5会少很多乐趣，但如果你喜欢p5，这游戏你是绝对不能错过（不过p5玩家应该没什么人和我一样，被困国外1年没有ps4的吧）
对p5粉丝来说，能和朋友们环游日本，度过一个暑假，真的是十分快乐的。
--------------------------------------------
作为一款无双游戏，战斗还是很有难度的，对我这种动作游戏苦手的人来说，我是过了第一个监狱才把难度调到normal的。
战斗极其时髦，人物技能各有特色，地图设计虽然比不上p5，但也还不错（joker能跳了！）
--------------------------------------------
ps：我现在只希望7月放假能自由出入境，回国玩p5r（这玩意都在我ps4里待了1年了)！！！

author: 84b1a74c10ed55ca8090f83665636d69
content:
ＰＳ４からずっとやってるのに何周しても飽きない！！多分PS4含めて３００時間とか遊んでる。
１週プレイ後にもらえるペルソナで「スリープソング」「コンセントレイト」「[spoiler] 明けの明星 [/spoiler](これ言ったらネタバレかな？)」が癖になってやめられない。
忘れたころにまた起動して最初からプレイして・・・みたいなのもうずっとやってる。
後日譚だから先にロイヤルをプレイしたほうが楽しめるとは思うんですけど、これ先にやって「そもそもこの人たちはなぜ怪盗団になったんだろう？てか怪盗団てなに？」みたいな状態でロイヤルやっても十分に楽しめると思います。
・・・いやそのほうが絶対楽しめそうな気がしてきたこれからやるひと本当に羨ましい・・・。
全部が全部フルボイスってわけではないけどほとんどがボイス入ってるので物語に感情移入してゲーム進められると思います。
キーマウでの操作はまったくおすすめできないのでコントローラー推奨です。

author: 1370cea8041257fa809b71aa1c30159b
content:
Este juego es maravilloso. Consigue juntar la mecánicas de los "musou" con la fórmula de persona y el resultado funciona sorprendentemente bien. Jugarlo es muy placentero, y cuando se desbloquean todas las mecánicas el combate gana muchísima fluidez y combinado con la tremenda banda  sonora que tiene da momentos divertidísimos.

Es una pena que el el port sea regulero (cap a 60 fps, fallos al jugar en modo ventana). Si ese fuera el único problema tampoco pasaría mucho. Lo que es inaceptable es que el juego crashee a menudo (sobre todo durante la primera mitad del juego). Se podría arreglar con un parche, pero ya son varios los usuarios que han reportado el problema, y han recibido como respuesta que no habría parches. Esto es muy decepcionante teniendo en cuenta el soporte que recibió P4. 

En resumen, muy buen juego que se ve perjudicado por un port cutre. Y Denuvo. Y P5 o P5R siguen sin estar en Steam.

EDIT: Parece ser que se han puesto a arreglarlo un poco. Se supone que crashea menos.

author: de0273f7376252aa91ef806848359188
content:
16 hours in so far

Did not enjoy the combat at first (I'm not a fan of Dynasty Warriors) but it soon grew on me since it does still feel like a Persona game but I would not consider this a sequel like many say it is and more of a spin-off. It does not contain any turn based combat which is a staple of the Persona series nor does it have social link (I assume it's because it takes place after P5, maybe it also assumes all links are maxed?). It's a sequel in terms of the story only. 

I would recommend this game if you're a big Persona 5 fan (like I am) otherwise I'd probably pass on it unless you're really into Dynasty Warrior type games. A lot of the references in game won't be understood by someone who has never played Persona 5. Also Persona 5 royal characters are not in this game so maybe that game isn't considered canon? 

In terms of technical issues I haven't had any gamebreaking ones so far. I did have my game crash once during a loading scene after a big fight 5 hours into the game. I haven't experienced another crash since then. Just remember to save often because there is no auto-save so you could potentially lose hours of gameplay if it does crash on you. 

One annoyance I have with the game is it forces you to exit the dungeons at the checkpoints to refill your hp/sp. It literally makes no sense to add that annoyance since it just adds on another 10s to watch the loading screen. The dungeons this time around are a lot more linear compared to the P5 and that may turn some ppl off. It was alright for me. 

I haven't finished the game yet and I'm still guessing who the antagonists are but so far I'd give the game a solid 7.5/10.

edit: 40 hours and I finally finished the game, the story at the end becomes very predictable and pretty disappointing but the main issue I had with the game was still the random crashes which happened me right after the last boss fight which was a bit of a slog as you can imagine. It was a terrible feeling to have to redo the entire fight again even though I thought the design wasn't bad compared to other jrpg final bosses. It pulls the common jrpg trope I hate the most where it splits the party but this time around I felt it wasn't super imbalanced unless you basically never play your non-main party members. I can't recommend this game until they patch the crashing issues which they have refused to even acknowledge on their official forums.

author: 4f4a17495d7559da9dcc141b7115fc88
content:
You can tell it's a spin-off because Haru gets screen time. 

I kid. Game's incredible, and way higher budget that you might expect from a Dynasty Warriors / Persona mash up. The review is mostly semantic - Persona stans have already bought it, and if you aren't part of the crew yet this might be a weird place to jump in. For what it's worth, the game is respectful of spoilers to the previous game, and was made before Royal so you're safe there, but you probably want to wait for P5R to get ported to PC before diving in. 

And Atlus, I'm ready to throw money at a Sophia figure whenever you're ready to make one. I'll mail you a blank check, write down what you think is fair.

author: d6d617cfa33a5561b71159b2fcccb7cc
content:
Spoiler Free!

-Story: This is basically Persona 5-2. The story is a direct continuation of P5, and so if you haven't played the first one, you'll definitely be lost in this game. The writing quality is on par with if not better than the original. 
-Characters: There are some points where the original Phantom Thieves feel exaggerated, but for the most part they're very strong. Not nearly as flanderized as previous Persona spin offs. The new cast members are excellent additions. It's impressive that even with 10-ish characters, no one feels left out of the story. Also Haru got her screen time.
-Gameplay: The combat is simple enough to get into, but has enough elements to make fights feel like more than just button mashing. Weaknesses, One Mores, Environment attacks, etc. all help keep you thinking about how to attack.

Aside from a few nitpicks here and there, I would say this game is excellent. Very fun combat and a great sequel story. The main limiting factor is if you haven't played P5. If you haven't played it, I wouldn't recommend this game. The combat is fun, but it's not enough to sell the game if you're not also interested in the story. Play P5 first so you'll understand these characters and what they're talking about when they mention past events.

author: 4e381790823e57f08ba86dd4754957f8
content: Not as content-rich as Persona 5 Royal, or even the original Persona 5, which is frankly to be expected with a spinoff. The roster of available personas is rather small, the game basically tells you what to do and prevents you from doing anything else, and the social link/confidant system present in the main series is replaced with a watered-down bond system. However, the flair of Persona 5 remains, and it's very flashy, especially with the hack-and-slash gameplay. All-Out Attacks, Showtimes, and the series's signature "persona eyes" all add to this game's style, without the need for much graphical power, allowing this game to run on lower-end or older gaming PCs. Fair warning: the plot will not make a lot of sense without the context of Persona 5. As I do not have a PS4, I watched a let's play of the game instead (I am told the anime sucks). If you have a PS4, or are one of the lucky ones to get your hands on a PS5, I recommend you play Persona 5/P5R first, otherwise you won't have context. It is unfortunate that P5 or P5R are unavailable on Steam, but it is understandable if Atlus signed an exclusivity agreement with Sony. Overall, If you enjoyed Persona 5, you will likely enjoy this, and I recommend the digital deluxe edition, since for $10 more, you get $15 worth of DLC in addition to exclusive bonus content.

content: The game is phenomenal. Fun, nastologic if you're a P5 fan, immersive, and the combat system is a lot more fun once you get use to it than the traditional turn base. However, do not make the mistake I did of trying to play it with mouse and keyboard. I typically prefer to play everything m+kb, but this game made me switch. Even after rebinding all the keys, the combat is still a nightmare on keyboard. It's very fast paced, so I always hit the wrong buttons, it's difficult to do follow up attacks and showtimes, and switching characters is way more effort than it needs to be. It's playable with m+kb but the experience was infinitely better when I switched to a controller. I'm sure people can do it, but I would recommend using a controller.

author: b0aae372191d562c92e70375459e937e
content:
This review is from someone who also played the original Persona 5 game as well as P5 Royal.
It's good for what it is, which is a game in the genre of Dynasty Warriors. In my opinion it is best played on the harder difficulty. That being said for some fans of the Persona series who played and loved P5 and Royal, this might be a bit disappointing. It feels like a slightly gutted version of P5 unfortunately.

There isn't really any sort of Social Link/Confidante mechanic. As such there's zero instance of the archana system for fusing Personas and the strategy behind it. There is also no real time constraints like in P5/R (which might be very welcome to a lot of people, I get it). For me, those were some of my favorite aspects of P5/R as it allowed you to really get to know the various stories of many great characters.

The game's story so far is enjoyable though, having taking place I think half a year after P5/R. There is no canon choice for things like romances, Royal's characters, etc. The style is still there and amazing as always in the new and changed environments and characters. The soundtrack is great like usual.

All this being said, even though I'm disappointed in some aspects of the game, it's still very enjoyable so far for the genre it's in. I don't usually care for Dynasty Warrior-type of games. If I had to give it an arbitrary rating out of 10, it'd be a 6 or 7 out of 10.

author: 159b8f7a25c05bb9b549fc5942ef9d29
content:
A fantastic game and a brilliant followup to Persona 5. By far the best Persona spinoff we've had yet.

The fusion of Persona with Warrior style gameplay works great, the presentation genuinely makes you feel like you're playing a mainline title, except it's an Action RPG instead of a Turn-based one.

The story is very similar to Persona 5's, but with enough differences and additions to make it feel like a fresh experience. Definitely not as deep as some other Persona stories, but still a good one.

I played on Hard difficulty, and battles rarely felt "tedious" or "boring" like a lot of people often accuse Warrior games of being (the only real exceptions being some optional bosses which act a little too much like HP sponges for my liking). I did find the difficulty jumped around a bit for certain bosses, where the boss of the semi-final dungeon was brutal to defeat, yet the final boss itself was a complete joke.

The music is, as you'd expect from a Persona game, absolutely fantastic. Lyn Inaizumi returns to sing for an almost entirely new soundtrack, as well as doing some Warrior's style "Rock" remixes of Persona 5 music ("Last Surprise" and "Rivers in the Desert").

The graphics aren't exactly stellar or anything, but they work well enough for what the game is going for (considering this games is also on the Switch). The art direction is as amazing a P5's was.

Apart from some HP sponge bosses and some occasionally crusty visuals, my only other complaint with this specific port is that I experienced quite a few crashes while playing. These usually occurred after long play sessions and weren't super often or anything, but still very annoying when they occurred and can potentially lose you a lot of unsaved progress.

I'd also say I'd HEAVILY recommend playing the original Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this, as there's numerous characters and references to them that first time Persona fans wouldn't understand.

Overall I'd give the game a solid 8/10. It's fantastic experience that Persona 5 fans will love, despite some difficulty and crashing issues. I hope we start seeing more Persona games being ported to other platforms now, specifically Persona 5 Royal and Persona 3 FES (hopefully a remake for the latter!).

content: A Hideo Kojima Production

author: 19ba85cec62c5380acf3f24046f7ccbf
content:
Purchased: 53 Euros (Voidu.com)

It's pretty simple, if you've played and enjoyed either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, I recommend this game.
If you have not played any of those, I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game.

This game is for fans of the original who want more of the story. It's really a direct sequel to P5 rather than a standalone spin-off. The game takes place after the events of P5 and with the characters already having gone through a year of knowing each other, so it would feel more than a bit weird to be told 'welcome back' if its your first time there.

BUYING IT NOW: So I ran into two problems that stuck out when playing. One was that the game crashed to desktop. It happened three times in the first 10 hours, but then never again, so theres maybe something buggy in the early locations? Or I got unlucky, either way, something to look out for early adopters. Second was that the game lagged quite a bit when multiple skills were used in quick succession, but by turning off ambient occlusion this problem seems to go away entirely and I got buttery smooth framerates.

DELUXE EDITION: So I dont buy these normally, but I thought 'what the heck' for this one. So you get to play the game early (moot now), the 'all-out attack pack' which is just a bunch of starter items (little time saver but otherwise ignorable), and the legacy BGM pack (which I think is really worth it, one song from every prior persona game is included and the randomise function is customisable).
Theres also the digital bonus content, which launches as a separate app from the game. The app itself is a little janky, but the soundtrack and art book are cool to have. Depending on how much you pay, might be worth it.

BUT WHAT OF THE GAME ITSELF? 
Its a Dynasty Warriors style game. I have never finished a single Dynasty Warriors game but I liked this one from start to finish. The visual style of Persona 5 is carried over, along with a lot of the gameplay concepts. Yeah, now its a real time action game, but you still strike enemy weaknesses into baton passes into all out attacks. That part is still pretty satisfying. 

The music is pretty great. Some pretty bombastic pieces to match the faster pace of the gameplay. 

When I finished Persona 5 and Royal got announced, there were 3 things I was hoping for. More Akechi, more Haru, and more hang out time with the gang. With Royal, I got more Akechi but I was still wanting for the other two. In this game theres more time with the phantom thieves and Haru gets some satisfying screentime. So Strikers essentially satisfies my desires. 

The stakes definitely never felt as high as the original game, but its overall also a lot shorter than the original game. I finished the main story in 26 hours, but that might be an underestimate for the average. Theres still bonus bits to do in the game. Overall, its a fun add-on to Persona 5 that extends the story out further by one road trip.

Maybe Persona 5 Royal will come to PC huh?

author: a7b8b638ce175038bcbc05a812eb9030
content: You ever thought how it'd be like if Persona 5 was an action-style game instead of turn-based? This is the answer. While not as good as the main games (P5 Vanilla and P5 Royal), I guarantee you'll still be in for a good time. If you're afraid that it's your typical Musou game, I'm telling you that it's not as it retains all the battle mechanics that originated from the main games; weaknesses, buffing/healing and even min-maxing your Personas in the Velvet Room to their highest capabilities. I recommend not getting it if you're new to the Persona 5 story as the it takes place right after the main games and this won't be the "authentic Persona experience" if you're looking to get into the franchise. All in all, it's a fantastic game. Here's hoping Persona 5 Royal will be released on Steam!

author: 5562c4d67c495d9b90c42817b811d354
content:
GROS GROS GROS plaisir de retrouver le crew au complet + de nouveau personnage !
(Zenchiki et Sophia sont carrément cool, et bien développé en + je m'attendais pas à ce qu'il est un bon développement de base)

Pour ce qui est du jeu en lui même et bien on a un pot pourri de Persona, Musou, et de A-RPG. On ressent clairement l'ambiance Persona, on est en terrain connu, on a du plaisir à retrouver les perso et la quête de rescousse  du monde grâce à notre force intérieure.

Qui plus est le jeu nous fait voyager dans tout le japon ce qui est grave sympas, l'ambiance road trip ressort aussi bien dans les lieux visité que dans les donjons ! 

L'ost est propre, c'est du persona.
Scénaristiquement parlant c'est très sympas, je m'attendais à une grosse déception de ce coté la mais non ! Alors on est pas sur un 'Vrai' persona, c'est sur. (On ressent que l'aspect amitié est ultra forcé, comparé à persona 5 qui fait ça plus subtilement).

Pour ce qui est des point faibles : et bien c'est simple 6 crash en 30h de jeu, des temps de chargement qui peuvent excéder les 2 minute chrono en main, et un bug qui empêche tout progression après le 5ème donjon....
C'est clairement pas bon du tout ça.....
J'ai du aller me casser le cul à trouver des solutions sur les forums et faire des incantation magique avec mon clavier pour pouvoir débuger le jeu, j'suis pas sensé faire ça en 2021 SEGA.....


Donc bon, j'suis un grand iencli Atlus, donc je le recommande.. Mais si vous pouvez vous abstenir en attendant que les bug soit réglé, faite le.



Concernant l'histoire de le faire avant de faire Persona 5... je serais vous, j'attendrais de pouvoir faire le 5 avant celui ci... En étant honnête, sans l'attachement émotionel que j'ai au personnage et à l'univers.. je trouverais le jeu moyen voir correct tout au mieux. 
P5S assume que vous avez jouez au précédent donc, faite vous une fleur, jouez à Persona 5 avant celui ci ! :D

PS : Qui plus est sa spoil clairement sans vergogne le précédent...

author: 609e6e9d8e685a2d853bb966f21b0be3
content:
Some tips for new players:
- Save your SP. And buy the SP recovery item every instant you can. 
- Go into jail then leave it let you reset the vendor items. So you can use this to stocking your Healing/SP Recovery Items. Cooking Ingredient also.
- Combo let you use persona skills without spending SP. It's weaker but it'll save you alot of SP.
- All teammate have their uses, But Sophia & Haru is highly recommend from how good they are. ( Just don't use Haru first boss ) 


There're many downside for a console main game publisher/developer to be try out on PC, but i am truly welcome it. For i am a fan of Persona series for 10 years. Hoping for more Persona game to be release on PC.
After 50 hours, i still want to play more and waiting for more things to unlock. It's a musou-like game, but is it felt like one? To be honest, no. I actually love the battle system more than vanilla P5. Despite being a fan of the combat system of Persona, it just hit me right to see your favorite characters combat in real time with flashy and REALLY EXTRA moves. I'm all about that extra moves.
But.
There're downside that i'm hope Atlus can fix and improve, i love the game, but it NEED TO BE IMPROVE.

- Anti-alias is a joke.
- Horrible basic keybinds. I change it the instant i am possible to. I don't blame them for how this is one of the first game they port to PC ( P4G don't have real time combat so the keybind don't affect this much and it quite alright. )
- The game will crash from time to time, I crashed like 4 times in the past 4 days while in loading. Sometimes it could be truly horrible for how you're not saved after finish all request and going to the fight the Jail Boss. Cause we have to do it in one sitting. PLEASE FIX IT !

I'll rate it for now, 7/10. If they can fix those that i said i would totally give it a solid 8-8.5/10

PLEASE GIVE US DLC ! I buy the game pre-release full price AND I STILL WANT TO PAY MORE TO GET THE SKINS AND PERSONA. :( It's been a year of japan release but i still truly hoping for it.

author: c711cce17bb55446a804fa813cc70d2a
content: Following Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5 Strikers comes to Steam with everyone including me who has played the original Persona 5 crying for joy. P5S continues the story of the original Persona 5 game based on where it's left off but has a twist that none of it's predecessors saw coming. It plays in a Musou fashion where you smack and annihilate enemies in real time combat. It borrows the same concept as Persona 5 where you can use your skills in the midst of combat. Being in constant 60 FPS, the game runs smoothly and feels natural to the touch. The story and voice acting is as superb as usual and it doesn't stray far from the original Persona 5 despite being a different type of game. To Atlus, Don't be afraid to release the other Persona games onto Steam. Many people look forward to it for multiple reasons such as not owning the specified console or in this case, introduces a lot of newcomers into the series. Persona 5 Strikers is definitely a game that's going to do very well so as for other future games that's to come.

author: ccb1ed4cf14a5a38bdcb57cd8bb82681
content:
A shallow spin-off that fails to combine different gameplay mechanics into one solid experience.

There's no depth to anything. Characters, like the friends of the protagonist, are mainly there just to serve as gameplay pawns. They don't have many meaningful conversations or social events like in the main games. You cannot talk to very many NPCs and the different locations serve just as backdrops. So you strip away everything Persona games* are known for and what you're left with is... a hack and slash grind that doesn't even offer the risk and reward of Persona's time limited dungeons.

I was actually planning to get further in the game before posting my review, but then I lost a hefty amount of progress because the game crashed. So I also recommend you take a look at the community discussions to see how many people are having issues with the port, random crashes seem to be really common.

It's not an awful game per se, it's just mediocre at best. If you need more of the Phantom Thieves and you're fine with the hack and slash type gameplay, then go for it.

* = at least the newer ones

author: 774e32555caa5284adae79e2c5749141
content:
Игра не плоха, но уж точно не шедевр.
В своё время прошёл оригинальную Persona 5 и Persona 5 Royal, и искренне считаю её лучшей игрой на ps4, ради которой не стыдно купить консоль. И когда услышал о портировании на пк её продолжения (хоть и в другом жанре), то не раздумывая предзаказал. Ну и то с чем я столкнулся стало для меня, как для фаната, настоящим разочарованием, но обо всем по порядку. Далее пойдет моё, сугубо субъективное мнение.
Во-первых сюжет. Действие игры разворачиваются после событий оригинальной игры, не учитывая событий в Royal, и отсутствие некоторых, довольно важных персонажей выглядит крайне странно. Сам же сюжет клеширован до безобразия и выглядит как какой то фанфик. 
Во-вторых игровой процесс. В плюсы и минусы мусоу я вдаваться не буду, если вам близки dynasty warriors, то и местные "зарубы" вам придутся по душе. Но такая боёвка ломает игровую логику и явно не вписывается в сеттинг.
Практически все механики социальных взаимодействий были упразднены, и по сути остались только захват дворцов и просмотр катсцен с диалогами.
Хотелось бы отменить, что стилистически и художественно игра выполнена бесподобно, но от этого вдвойне обиднее, ведь  игра выглядит и звучит как персона, но персоной по сути своей не является.
Итог. Если вы ярый фанат серии Persona и Persona 5 в частности, и вам невыносимо интересно продолжение оригинальной истории, то скорее всего вы даже не дочитали до этого момента, а пошли и купили игру и получаете от неё удовольствие. Но если вы хоть на секунду засомневались, то рекомендую дождаться скидок, так как велик риск разочароваться от увиденного.

author: f5f471d456f950c88c82362b0d9b7d7f
content:
Fans of P5S will dig so much about this from the rejoining of some great characters, music from P5 and other Persona games, and re-exploring the themes and ideas that we found so interesting that we didn't just put 100 hours into P5, we put another 130 into P5R. However, I can't recommend this game because I just don't think it's very good on its own. I will probably play it to completion, but not because I think it's actually worth my time.

There's a scene early on where the old crew goes to the old hangout at their school and one comments about how it hasn't been that long, but they still feel a sense of nostalgia and I think that sentiment just about sums it up. I enjoy P5S only so much in that it reminds me of a game I rather enjoyed more and would likely have more fun replaying than honoring it in a sequel/spinnoff. P5S is weaker in just about every way. The story is rushed, the villains lack any depth, there is no buildup to the events that occur, and both dungeon crawling and combat have baffling design choices.

Koei Techmo appear to have sort of mashed the Dynasty Warrior and Persona engines together, though one is custom and the other based on Unity. Combat plays like a DW game, but you are a team of four and enemies have the abilities and effects of Persona, at least for the most part, and theoretically this should work. One problem is that all the magic is range-based and so if you're attacked, it's usually from off-screen, and even weak enemies can have powerful effects. I spent an hour on one encounter because I had to fight alone and Pixies kept casting zio (lightning bolt) which caused stun and the duration was long enough for other enemies to punch me from full health to zero. I eventually learned that hit and run is the only way to survive.

I am not a DW fan, but the combat just doesn't feel right in other ways, too. The camera is slow, controls sluggish, visuals to chaotic to be easily readable while being swarmed, you deal very little damage, and you're constantly switching between different characters with different control priorities and play styles. This could work if switching were seamless like Marvel vs Capcom, but it's not, or if each character was deep like and interesting enough for their own game like DMC5, which they aren't. 

To be clear, I'm not trying to say the combat is terrible, it's just not great. It's not a refinement of a good idea, nor a remarkable innovation. Okay, passable, not great.

Dungeon crawling is passable, functioning like in P5 with pseudo-stealth mechanics and platforming, though is mostly held back by long load times, even on my SSD. Whenever you find a checkpoint, you should leave the dungeon to heal up and immediately return and the only reason you won't is the loading screen on exit and reentry, even though each scene is fairly small and constantly reuses assets. This almost feels intentional because otherwise they could have made checkpoints heal you and you'd never have reason to leave the dungeon.

Finally, the story: I won't go into what it's about too much because I routinely finding myself lose focus as dialogue flies by without developing much. The story is a thin wrapper around finding excuses to throw the team into dungeons and go on a road trip to find more dungeons. Learn that bad person exists, go to their dungeon, get blocked, defeat a mini boss, go back and defeat the real boss. Same formula as P5, just a lot more trimmed down. It also all takes place over a summer vacation road trip so you don't have any worries aside from someone being a bad person.

Verdict: P5S is a toned down imitation of P5 that at times feels lovingly crafted, but mostly just a cynical cash grab made for fans and only fans.
