author: dc92805068a754659ba48618bda07857
content:
I absolutely fully recommend this game, it's a fun and great sequel to the original Persona 5 and I can tell you, you'll have a blast. Sure, the combat is different from the original but I promise you, if anything, the change is nice. 
This game still has an absolute bunch of story and cutscenes for you to enjoy, just like the original game. I was surprised, I didn't expect it to be very story driven and expected much more of a dynasty warrior style all the way through, I'm glad I was wrong on that one though. While I recommend playing/watching the original Persona 5, you can still play this game without knowing it, you'll just be a little confused or oblivious to some references.
I'd say if you want just story, it's about 30-ish hours but to complete it (achievements, etc.) would be more like 50. Less content than in the original, but expected.
The new characters that are introduced fit the team perfectly and I really like how every single member has their own unique way of fighting, it's fun to change it up here and there. One of my favourite parts is that you can play as any of the cast (you'll always be Akiren/Joker for the social stuff and for main story, though) and they all have their own unique animations and cutscenes, it's just a whole lot of fun all the way through.
I am the same as everyone else hoping that Atlas decide to port P5/P5R to steam, but for now, this is a really nice way to scratch the itch for Persona players and fans alike.

author: 3a43f99e0d7e54d99a2cc5c67e5e57e9
content:
[h1] 讲了一个完整的故事[/h1]
刚通关一周目特来评价
    作为后日谈一作，内容确实足够大了，当初无印一周目打了八十多个小时，S只需要四十个小时左右。
优秀的战斗设计，每个角色都是有用心设计过的。
    第一个监狱Life Will Change响起来的时候确实起了一身鸡皮疙瘩，真的有当初打无印的感觉。
    但前期的关卡过于相似，非常的容易犯困，前15个小时都是玩几十分钟就下，确实很搞心态
    我是一直normal难度打的一周目，整个流程下来就是前期这就是无双，中期我被无双[spoiler]被第三个boss开始往后就疯狂摩擦，强度直接拉满[/spoiler]，后期果然这就是RPG。
    所谓的日常实际就是小地图中逛逛商店，触发一些事件，还有专门用来拖时间的支线属实有点故意恶心人了，在中期被无双的阶段，跑图跑的头昏脑胀的，很打击人积极性。
    [spoiler]在打伪神的时候，真的感觉不到一点压迫感和拯救世界的感觉，这和无印那集合所有民意来搓元气弹一样击败神差的太多了，全程就是嗑药丢技能破防到没蓝在磕药重复，属实拉了大跨 [/spoiler]。
    只要等到中后期开始展开，确实有着无印的感觉，非常的畅爽可以让人投入进去[spoiler]到大叔觉醒就彻底燃起来了 [/spoiler]。
    是P系列铁粉无脑入，P5S确实是一部非常顶的后日谈，毕竟就是冲着会动的JOKER来的，别的都是意外收获非常不错。
    [spoiler] DLC的BGM包永远滴神 [/spoiler]
我永远喜欢P系列

author: 46a3d34aaed852b5bebe50e909db6c68
content: Absolutely incredible. Loved every minute I played and it was well worth every cent I spent. It felt like a true sequel to the first game in every sense, minus the combat. As someone who generally prefers turn based RPG combat, I have to say that playing this more real time action combat was a nice change of pace and generally a great time. The characters are as lovable as ever, the story is gripping and intriguing, the soundtrack and art is absolutely phenomenal, and the game play is a total blast. I would absolutely recommend picking up this game, it's well worth the price, and if you're a fan of the Persona series or action RPGs, I can almost guarantee you'll love it.

author: ed61345bb50d59edb8eb61bfdb274250
content:
Obviously if you dont play P5 or P5R first, a lot of dialog will be lost to you and youll feel like you dont get a lot of things that the game is bringing up. But if you have played, then this is a great game to continue the story. 

combat is a bit different obviously but it is not welcomed. theres still the hack and slash element (which is ok but for me can get tedious) but the persona element that made combat interesting in the previous P5 titles does the same for this combat style. in my opinion, it makes the combat that much more interesting to me. combine that with combos that differ from each character, i defintely am a fan of this style of hack and slash combat style.

only cons that ive found is that you dont see many characters from the previous game (which i get because this is technically a brand new game but come on, we get to walk around town a bit, i wanna see some old faces!) and dialog is pretty linear which is everyone's main complaint im sure (i just want to romance Makoto again - big sad). but other than that, the story is interesting and the new characters are as well!

anyone who buys the game, the only recommendations is git gud at the dodge mechanic and really play into to weaknesses of the enemies. do that and you should be golden!

First Impression

Review 8/10
Pros +
- Interesting story (so far)
- Amazing Soundtrack (as usual)

- Still feel like persona game

Cons -
- Less Complexcity compare to main game
- Lesser Past NPC Participation

BUY if:
- Persona fans
- You like Anime Style Action RPG
- Enjoy Single player Story based game

Don't Buy
- Follow the hype of persona without research 
- Don't like story based game
- Don't like game with anime style
- Expect for Riot Musou type of game

Conclusion: Recommend to Buy for persona fans or Anime Action RPG fans especially on SALES

author: 7928c564417757f8ab6513ca924526d7
content:
[h1] Persona 5 Strikers completed review [/h1]

[h1] Disclaimer [/h1]
This is not a spin-off of Persona 5, this is a sequel. For any newcomers on Steam looking to enter the Persona series, I do not recommend this game as an entry point. The game assumes that you've played Persona 5 and understand the group's dynamics and past because it does not explain it to you and constantly references the OG Persona 5 game. So this is a review of Strikers from a fan of Persona 5 instead of a newcomer.

[h1] Story [/h1]
The Phantom Thieves goes on a trip around Japan! Strikers does a great job in giving the player more group interactions and is also an excellent tourism advertisement for Japan. Not much to say here without spoiling the story, but any Persona fan who wants to see more Phantom Thieves will get their money's worth.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
This is the part you're probably looking for. The collaboration between Omega Force and P-Studio brings the Warriors gameplay to Strikers. However, unlike Hyrule Warriors, this game does not utilize the same overall gameplay as the Warriors series. You will not be going around a big map fighting generals with your army. Instead, Strikers plays [b] exactly [/b] like Persona 5, but it's now an Action RPG. You navigate the map similar to Persona 5, slowly approaching enemies to ambush them. Using Personas, you target weakness to down your enemies and execute an All-Out Attack. Show Time also makes its return from Royal. This core gameplay loop will be familiar but now it's cooler and more fast-paced because it has action elements in it. If you love the gameplay in Persona 5, you won't have a problem here.

[h1] Music [/h1]
Because it's an Action game now, the Strikers remixes have more electric guitars in it and sounds 10x more energetic. It's amazing. I'm listening to it on repeat already. If you love the Persona 5 OST, you can add the new songs into your playlist and jam out even more.

[h1] PC Port [/h1]
The PC port is pretty average. Nothing significant to note of its settings; it's the same settings you expect from a typical PC game. The game also caps at 60fps, so no unlimited/120/144 fps. One important thing to note is that this game does experience some random crashes when loading a new area/going into another menu, based on mine and my friends' experiences. Save often to ensure you don't lose much progress when one does eventually happen.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This is definitely a game you will want to play as a Persona 5 fan. By no means is this some insignificant spin-off, it's a sequel that Persona fans will want to play like how Royal is. I'm happy that Atlus (probably with help from KT and Omega Force) decided to put this game on PC and I hope that it's a continuous sign of more Persona games coming to PC. Also, after finishing this game, if this game gave ideas to P-Studio to make future games as Action RPGs, I'm [b] all for it [/b]. HEE-HO!

author: 06d5b9b5afaa5328bd88fd8bd783a960
content:
All the charm of Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal with a new and flashy combat system, some may compare this to a warriors game or even refer to it as a warriors game because it is done by Koei Tecmo but honestly in my experience its more of an action oriented JRPG, it has the familiar attacks/personas of previous games but this time its all done in real time combat opposed to turn based.

Although i'd highly recommend playing the original Persona 5 first before playing this the story thusfar seems to only have a few callbacks to events that happened in Persona 5 but that could change further in, if you wanna know the cast of characters you're playing as and get accustomed to the Phantom Thieves and what they do I think its crucial to play Persona 5 to have a better understanding of whats going on as they might throw around some unfamiliar terms or even reference characters/themes that only appear in Persona 5.

I hope that the success of this on PC will convince Atlus to port Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal over so that you can experience its story in full as this is technically a sequel to Persona 5 and as a PC player there really is no official way to play those games.

Overall i'd give this game a 9/10 and I hope if you do decide to pick this game up you enjoy playing it!

このレビューの執筆時点で3回ほど落ちた

クリアまでに計6回のクラッシュ

難易度リスキークリア　計20回近いクラッシュ

author: b864df54d1fa56cab3cbf1c91e96ac35
content:
Wow.  I just...wow.

Let me be clear.  I [B]DESPISE[/B] Persona 5.  As a huge fan of Persona 3 and a "meh" fan of Persona 4, Persona 5 felt like a straight up slap in the face, doing everything in its power to irritate the player.  Cats forcing you to go to bed, a bunch of time management worse than your day job, less-than-memorable cast (this is mostly due to the padding which was another issue), etc.  Royal comes along - I skipped it due to censorship (yes, it's censorship).

I was on the fence with this.  But I watched someone play briefly and was intrigued that it seemed to better respect the player's time than Persona 5.  What I didn't expect was to walk away feeling so energized from the experience, start to finish (mostly).

[h1]What I Liked[/h1]

✅ It's not going to win graphics awards, but it's good for what it is, and (with the exception of transition screens) runs at 60fps.

✅ It's a [B]MUSOU[/B] game.  Some will say "no it isn't!" - because they don't understand the true intent of a Musou game. It's to clear out enemies.  That's all you do here.  No school, no chores at home, etc.  Just clearing out enemies and doing events to unlock the next area.  The thing is, Omega Force did an AMAZING job with the skin this time to basically make a "role playing Musou" game.  That's what this is, and it's pulled off so well I was shocked.  The characters in P5 "felt" like they should be in a fast-paced action game rather than a turn-based slog, and here we are.  It just feels like a perfect fit; battles are fast and furious once you master the various mechanics.

✅ You can use all of the previous (non-Royal) characters.  There are also two new ones you meet along the way.   Each has a different and unique play style, from melee to Persona spells to even guns (slingshot, for Mona).  This lets you basically create your own fun, choose your characters, and have at it.

✅ Absolutely NO padding.  None.  There's nothing to sidetrack the story and nothing to distract from the storyline (which is a sequel...more like an epilogue...to P5).  The result is, you're looking at 30 hours if you rush.  Which is actually a very good length for a game of this style.

✅ Pacing is near perfect, as things progress when you want them to, and you're given plenty of warnings when things are going to be missable.  It never feels like a slog.  Also, despite the fact this is essentially a road trip, you'll not be seeing irrelevant nonsense like Final Fantasy XV, so even there it's got it down pat.

✅ Challenge is decent without being ridiculous (see below for a note though).  Here's where they do Musou right: enemies will actually make an attempt to kill you, but it's usually the larger enemies that are hiding partially behind the mobs. 

✅ The last boss and final sequence requires a bit of belief suspension, but given this is Persona, I'm willing to give it a pass.

[h1]What I Didn't Like[/h1]

❌ It is true that you should AT LEAST watch a "Let's Play" or read a synopsis or something before playing this, because it throws you right into the action.  There should have been a recap cutscene at the beginning.

❌ I'm not a fan of some of the sidequests/Requests, because they fall into the "Dragon Quest IX" pitfall.  For those that don't remember that terrible game, it would have a quest that says " kill three Wolves".  You're like, easy work....but then it's like "ahhhh, but wait...you must use this technique that fails 95% of the time to  stun them.  Oh and they only come out at night.  Good luck!!"  In other words, BS requirements.  There's a number of those, mostly from the Velvet Room (make this Persona with this spell where you have navigate through a clunky UI to even find it).

❌ It will intermittently crash.  It seems to be very memory picky, because every time I experienced a crash it was when memory was challenged (due to other things running).

❌ There are a lot of places that have a prompt (sign, whatever), where you can't actually ever go there.  I can't stand when games do that.

❌The AI tends to be a bit stupid sometimes.  More often than not, I'd look over and see two out of three of them dead for no clear reason (Mona should heal, but doesn't consistently).

❌ Some of the Jails are a bit irritating to navigate simply because they require you to do a lot of backtracking for switches or whatever, which I also can't stand.

I say these things but I'm serious when I say, this is SUPERIOR to Persona 5 or Royal.  From a presentation perspective, you expect the Thieves to really be in an action game, and that's what this is.  But it's also a role-playing game.  Don't overlook it because it's got Musou applications.  If you enjoy role-playing games with some action, this is worth your time and money.

author: 30ca633e3b3e5b9a954472fb199f0b58
content:
To start off let me get my thoughts on the game out, this game is great. It's not amazing, but it is great. I am not a fan of the dynasty warriors type of game play usually, however this game re-imagines that concept with the different characters and abilities in a way similar to Hyrule Warriors. The story and characters are just as lovable as they are in Persona 5. A small issue that many people have with this game is the lack of social links and confidants seen in previous entries in the series, but this game makes up for it in its fast game play. This game is not the same game as Persona 5, it's its own game. The fact that you can exit and re-enter the jail to fully replenish your health and sp on the same day without being forced to sleep is a great part of this game and the jails are absolutely massive. You're given access to almost all the characters right out of the gate and introduced to both of the new members of the group very quickly. At the moment, I am close to completing the first jail and am thoroughly enjoying the fights and have yet to feel the fights as tedious. The boss fights are especially fun as they require you to use a little bit more strategy instead of just spamming X X X X X Y. 
Overall at the moment, I give this game my rating of a:
8.5/10

author: 1c002f59b4b05ba7b4c0339419d96194
content:
[h1]一次看着不错，实际上比较糟糕的尝试[/h1]

 [b] 前言 [/b]
去年本人亚洲版首发就用PS4Pro通关了，总得来说这游戏在P系列历来的奶粉作里面算素质较高的。但是这游戏如果从类无双游戏的角度看，却没有正统无双那样多的人物和技能可用，而作为Persona来看，核心系统大砍甚至根本就没有。当然往好处想就是又有无双气息并且兼具Persona一定特色的游戏，反正体验确实是一言难尽，接下去本人会慢慢剖析。


 [b]1  剧情 [/b]

一开始这游戏在宣发阶段就一直强调剧本是老P组写的，光荣方面只负责打工制作，所以可能剧本质量应该是有一定保证的，毕竟P5本体和另一个评价颇高的P4G剧本也都是他们写的，而实际上笔者只能说期待过大真的会失望越大，如果你没玩过本体P5，那么这个衍生作的剧情你基本上只能半懂半不懂，而如果你玩过原作，你可能会感觉这游戏虽然情怀卖的不错，但是实在是老套，因为这游戏主线剧情就是把原作的剧情乃至最终BOSS换个皮，加个其他套再来给你重复说一次，可能会让部分玩家觉得比较无聊，最起码我和我几个小伙伴都觉得没意思[spoiler] 剧情好屎啊 [/spoiler]，而且莫名其妙洗白这个游戏的伪最终BOSS真的是令人云里雾里的，或者说这个人不是洗白而是被当做无事发生过了，如果你真的去思考真的会有智商被侮辱的感觉。

[b]2 画面[/b] 

本作从放出实机开始就一直被诟病狗牙的问题，并且这个游戏由于为了在本世代主机上达到一个稳定的帧数，使用PS4pro也运行1080P 60帧的方法，而Switch则运行在720P来尽量达到。和原作区别很大，虽然美术相近，但是毕竟引擎和制作都是光荣，所以看视频可能区别不太大，但是一玩就知道区别还是挺大的。个人是感觉画面完全没有P5R这个原作加强版看得舒服。

而对于PC版，本人配置是I7 10700K + RTX 3090运行在索尼X900F上，开4K全高并且渲染2.0情况下，画面感确实比我以前用PS4玩时候强多了，但是帧数基本上在50+帧左右浮动，偶尔60帧。虽然4K外加2.0渲染，基本上是8K游戏了，但是未免优化方面有点差了吧?而且关键如果以1比1比例游戏，那么锯齿依然有点，也就是这游戏如果只有原生4K，那么依然摆脱不了少量锯齿。不过如果只是原生4K的话，2070S的GPU就足以承担起60帧了，1080P或者2K的话肯定就更低了，所以配置需求个人认为还是不算高的。我认为主流大众都不会有配置问题。


 [b] 3 战斗系统和游戏总体玩法[/b]

老实说我真的觉得不好玩，前期基本上是在刮痧，而且你会发现SP一下就用完，就更是刮痧，开简单难度又过于无双了，虽然我觉得这游戏简单难度速通也不错，看看剧情看看老人物情怀一把。主要作为无双人物又只有那么几个主线人物，甚至连出DLC卖点前作人物或者来自皇家版的学妹都不愿意，就更容易让人无聊了，并且监狱的探索设计你可别想有P5原作殿堂那个水平，基本上水平只能略高于通常无双作品，个别设计还可以，但是至少一大半监狱跑图都是大同小异的内容，所以就当无双玩就行了，而对于Persona本身来说，一般来说捉P，凹P，合P是系列一个很大的乐趣，但是本作大幅度削砍了原作的全书，也就是被砍了很多P，而养P方面则变成光荣传统无双刷武器那种刷刷刷，有的人可能会喜欢吧，反正我是直到通关都没去特意刷多少。但，值得一提的是，其实有几个BOSS设计的还不错。

[b] 此外，本作的日常基本上是直接和主线相结合，短，少并且内容一般，或者说根本没有日常，就是一些主线过程的小互动。当然这个游戏也不是说就完全没有优点，跟随曾经的怪盗团一行人周游日本以及show time什么的做的都还可以 [/b]


[b] 4 音乐 [/b]

新加的音乐质量算中等，跟原作肯定没得比，有一部分是原作改编的曲子。不过好在战斗曲可以选择历代战斗曲，不过要注意Steam版被阉割了P5和P5R的战斗曲，这点我个人是挺蛋疼的，因为在PS4玩时候我就是基本都是听Take Over通关的。我觉得真的很可惜，这首歌真的很棒，希望后续通过DLC更新回来吧。

[h1] 总结 [/h1]

虽然算还可以的粉丝奶粉作，但是实际上不该上Steam，或者应要不把P5R一起打包送上来，一个衍生游戏居然出在两个没有原作的平台，这种事情是真的挺少见的。加上本身游戏体验我不是很满意，我个人不是很喜欢这种既不够无双，也不够Persona的游戏，这就是我的不推荐原因。

author: ff08ee4172dc56b5a2e0b1bab212a776
content:
For any Persona fan, this is a must-play. Even if it's on Easy so you can random-button-mash the combat, it's worth it just for the story alone! This is a direct sequel to the original Persona 5 (not the Royal expansion), and it takes place a year later. The music, as usual, is fantastic from the moment it starts, and jumping back into this world feels like reuniting with an old friend! 

I'm an avid mouse & keyboard gamer but I would definitely recommend connecting a controller for this game. I used a PS4 controller and it was extremely easy and streamlined, just plug it into the computer with a micro USB cable and you're ready! The game switches seamlessly between mouse/keyboard and controller input & display depending on the last input it detects.

60fps Persona is a dream; this and the P4G PC release are both proof that this game series deserves simultaneous PC releases from here on. One downside right now (as of 2/23/21 at 10:52PM) is I've had a handful of crashes, usually on loading screens. Be sure to save frequently!

If you're not a Persona fan because you hate fun or you have bad taste, then this game might not be for you..,

content:
Got this early with the Digital Deluxe Edition and I've got to say I've only really encountered two issues in my nearly 20 hours of game time. I've had one Crash to Desktop after a save, thankfully it loaded me into the next cutscene when I loaded it back up, and sometimes the background music breaks up a bit. Other then that, it's a decent Warror's Lite game that I would say is actually more Persona instead of Warriors to the point I can actually tolerate it a lot more then a traditional Warriors knockoff game.

EDIT: By the time I finished the game at 45 and a half hours with no real grinding, I had a second CtD that occurred under similar circumstances as the first time. Game had a lot more content in it then I was expecting and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I hope we get some actual DLC for this game down the road! Oh I had also played with Borderless Window on a TI 1080 card.

author: 9610683b491d57d3b8c0aaf0ba9c2f5e
content:
Things to do before playing: Play either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this game, trust me the game is better knowing the events of Persona 5.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story: Amazing, always had me engaged, but at times it dragged on with Jail Scenes and made the game feel a bit slow at time because of it, but not too much of a gripe to be too mad about.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Gameplay: Addicting and makes want to keep playing. You will struggle with this game if you button mash, which I like. It 
makes you learn when to use certain skills and when to use just the character's base attacks.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Replay Value: Great replay value for 100% completionist and people who want to do Merciless Difficulty. (i'm doing that rn and it's really fun so far! Just make sure you prepare for it before going in.)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post-Game: Persona 5 Strikers can offer around 5-10 hours of post game content before NG+ is unlocked, and I actually really like it, it gave me something to do even after you beat the Final Boss. The post game can challenge your skills with the game so far and really put you up to test with some of the content they give you during post-game.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
PC Port: This PC port is not great at all, through out my 55+ hours of this game, the game crashed many times and even set me back 3 hours one time. It could've been much much worse, but could've been so much better. I think Atlus should work on this field alot more in upcoming PC Ports of their games.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion: Persona 5 Strikers is a great sequel to Persona 5 and continues great story telling even if feeling slow at times with some pacing issues in the Jails. It also offer a lot after you beat the game like, a new difficulty, Merciless, a Post-Game that keeps you playing and improving your abilities, and overall is a great experience for those who have played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal. (Atlus port these please)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Score: 8.5/10

Great game so far, kind of weird playing a Persona game that isn't turn based. There were some minor issues upon first launching it but they disappeared after restarting. The default key bindings are also very disgusting, definitely change them before starting the game as you can not change them while playing on a save :/ I ended up locking myself in the tutorial mission because I had "gun" assigned to Tab and "lock-on" assigned to Alt...yeah you can probably see the problem there.

Other than that, just like every Persona game the characters/soundtrack/story are amazing! It's a lot of fun being able to play as other characters aside from Joker. There's a fuck ton of new mechanics in this game compared to all the previous games so you will have plenty to do/work on.

However...from what I heard there is one major downside to this game...[b]why can I not romance best girl Makoto?? or any character for that matter?[/b]

author: 43df048fbab65eb4b3235591ac3acd9a
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a pile of trash that attempts to cash in on the Persona branding while ignoring pretty much everything that made Persona 5 what it is. 

Allow me to explain. Strikers has a very strange sense of 'balance', where most random encounters can be solved in a single hit by ambushing the enemy and immediately going into an all-out attack that just clears the screen. About the only time you'll ever get hit is if you don't pull off an ambush - which is common because the "ambush" button is the same as the "power attack" button and so half the time you'll wind up shooting the enemy instead of ambushing. You also more or less lose the ability to ambush enemies from behind: you pretty much have to be in a hiding spot and the range from which you can ambush enemies from a hiding spot is greatly reduced from what it is in Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.

Then you have the boss fights, in which all sense of balance goes out the window. Most bosses can and will kill your party in one or two hits even if you're the appropriate level to be fighting them, and the party member AI is simply not equipped to deal with them. For me, most of the boss fights consisted of having my entire party die immediately followed by me taking control of whoever was left and alternating between mashing the dodge button and getting in one or two physical attacks before repeating the process.

Gone is the ability to creatively use spells or Persona fusion to address the difficulty: spells cost several times what they do in Persona 5 and your party members have less than a quarter of the SP they normally would have. The idea is that you're supposed to do attack chains that end in your Persona casting a weaker version of a spell for free.. except there's no easy way to control which spell it casts if it has more than one. I believe it's based on the number of times you hit the light attack button before hitting special attack, but it seems random to me.

Fusion is also significantly nerfed - there are fewer Personas in the game and a lot of them have been nerfed to the ground from P5 or Royal. There's no opportunity to get creative with fusion the way there is in the real game, where you can make a Persona specifically to address certain situations.. meaning that there will be situations where you simply do not have an answer to what the game is presenting you with. 

The game tries to address this by giving you frequent save points, from which you can go through multiple loading screens to recover your HP and SP by leaving for the real world from the dungeon and then coming back.. instead of having, I dunno, a button that you can just press at the save point. Considering that you can use maybe three heals on a full SP bar (and each one heals maybe a third of your HP) this means you'll be seeing load screens a lot.

Then there's the frequent issues linked to this game's poor implementation of Denuvo: random crashes, hanging on loading screens, slowdowns and frame lag. 

Give this one a pass until it's on deep discount.

author: eae367b9b37558fc9ef01f7e85fadd01
content:
O melhor Musou que já joguei e ainda por cima um Persona, com a continuação direta da estória, expandindo ainda mais o que já era fantástico! Excelentes mecânicas de jogo, gráficos excelentes, apesar de algumas vezes sentir os personagens um pouco serrilhados, mas nada que o deixe feio e nem nada do tipo, apenas um detalhe, uma trilha sonora espetacular, que sempre foi um dos pontos mais altos da franquia, excelentes controles, interações entre personagens também está magnífica, ou seja, se você já amava os personagens antes, terá mais oportunidades para amá-los ainda mais. 

Se você é fã de Persona 5 e Persona 5 Royal, esse é pra você, com certeza, mas se você nunca teve a oportunidade de jogar os 5 ou o 5 Royal, ainda assim, pode assistir o Persona 5 anime nos streams da vida e jogar o Persona 5 Strikers, sem problema algum!

O que pega um pouco, ou muito, é o preço, mas é exatamente o que estão cobrando pelos títulos AAA pelo mundo a fora, o que é o caso aqui, ou seja, é muito caro, mas tá no preço.

Bem, Sega e Atlus, com esse título vocês já viram que vale a pena lançar mais e mais títulos da franquia Persona no PC e, se Deus quiser, também, da série Shin Megami Tensei, portanto, bora viabilizar os outros Personas pro PC? Do 1 ao 5, incluindo o 5 Royal?! Bora, né?!

author: 4d42dd9cd3a455bc82dd1d693cf344b4
content:
Strikers is a very welcome surprise. While it may look like a simple Dynasty Warriors clone with a Persona skin, the reality is that this game has a LOT of depth behind it.

The action-based combat retains a lot of the systems at play in P5 and P5R - elemental weaknesses, technical attacks, status moves, buffing and debuffing, 1-More attacks, All Out Attacks, Baton Passes - you name it and Strikers has most likely implemented it in some fashion. In addition to the core systems, each character feels fantastic to play - each boasting unique movesets, abilities and progression paths, as well as displaying a lot of their personality in their fighting style. To put it simply, there's a lot more to the combat than meets the eye, and those who have previously played the original Persona 5 or Royal will appreciate the small details here.

The story so far (around 16 hours in) feels very lively thanks to the strong returning cast of characters as well as the two great new additions, Sophia and Zenkichi. The English version brings more fantastic performances which give the game a unique charm, and while the stakes don't feel too high at the moment, the relationships these characters have with each other make each moment feel endearing.

The music, my god the music. Straight up bangers everywhere. Do yourself a favour and listen to one of the new battle themes, Daredevil. If that doesn't get you excited to beat up some demons, I don't know what will.

A caveat I will mention and the one gripe I have with the game do far is that ultimately it is a sequel, meaning it's difficult to recommend to new players who didn't experience the original game. You could probably enjoy Strikers by reading a synopsis of P5's plot and characters, but really you would just be doing yourself a disservice. As great as I've found Strikers as a massive fan of its predecessor, the lack of a PC port of the original makes it a very hard sell.

If you're willing to look past that, or you've already a fan who has played P5 / P5R, you will most likely fall in love with the Phantom Thieves all over again in Strikers.

author: 93e4bce789585d68b40118a7c5d518c2
content:
Wait a minute. Atlus released a new Persona game on PC? And it's day in date with PS4?! What is this madness?!

But it's true. If the message to Playstation fanboys didn't come through that Atlus PC ports are here to stay, this does now. This is now Atlus' second PC port they've done themselves fresh off of Persona 4 Golden (which they did a fantastic job on and you should go buy and play that game now. Do it.) Now Koei Tecmo did codevelop the game, but the good news is they had no part in the port at all. It was all Atlus. KT only made the combat mechanics, while Atlus made the rest of the game.

So how does the port fair? THEY MANAGED TO MAKE A PC PORT BETTER THAN P4G, in such a short amount of time too! Atlus is a newcomer to the modern world of PC gaming, and they're already making ports like seasoned vets. Everything is fast, smooth, and fluid, and runs amazingly. If the port for Strikers is this good, then the eventual port of Persona 5 Royal will be even better. (Seriously Atlus, get on that.)

So, what is Persona 5 Strikers? Well, it is the sequel to Persona 5, only instead of a lifesim turn based JRPG, it's a musou, but don't let that discourage you. It's a musou designed for people who don't like musous, like me. It plays less like the traditional Warriors games and plays more like a Persona game that's real time action instead. And man they nail the power fantasy. You feel like a slick badass as you slice and dice through massive hordes as your favorite Phantom Thieves. One thing to note: If you're expecting the social life and RPG mechanics the Persona series is known for, you're gonna be sorely disappointed. Strikers is action and action only. Don't let that discourage you from buying it, because when going through the massive levels it plays like a big action oriented Persona game. That's not a complaint, it's a warning.

Storywise, it's really big for what is on paper just a musou spinoff of Persona. The game is a sequel taking place six months after the events of vanilla Persona 5 (so storybeats from Royal will not be present. However the playable Phantom Thieves from Royal will be making an appearance as DLC later in the year.) It is summer vacation and a new threat emerges as wicked evil people are mind controlling people by stealing their desires, and it's up to you to beat them up and all their endless hordes. If you haven't played Persona 5 yet, do so before playing, otherwise you're gonna get spoiled hard, as well as lost on what is happening.

But that brings me to my biggest complaint of the game, and it's not the game itself, but the release. The Persona series finally broke free from Playstation exclusivity, and everyone is hype off the heels of Persona 4 Golden wondering what's next? Would Persona 5 come next? That's a logical move since Persona 5 is the hot new game everyone's raving about. Well instead, the game we got was the sequel to Persona 5. People really want Persona 5 Royal and have been begging for years to come to other platforms especially PC so we don't have to emulate vanilla P5 through RPCS3 anymore and could support the devs. But instead we got this game, a game that probably won't sell well on PC since we don't have the first game to go off of. My only guess to this is SEGA wanted Strikers to get a PC release first since it was coming out next, and they're basically playing catchup. But man, does it sting STILL not having Persona 5 especially since they know we want it after they made that press release about the emulator C&D. All I can hope is that Royal gets a PC port announced soon, similar to the missing Yakuza games getting announced for PC a month after Like a Dragon released. We need Royal on PC ASAP, especially for this game.

author: c11fe6b669d251a48973ae6611d58e43
content:
This is a direct story sequel to Persona 5. Do not play this unless you have played Persona 5.
If you have played Persona 5, I don't think you need me to tell you why I'm recommending a direct story sequel to it.

Slight performance issues with the PC port. The framerate is capped at 60, and game logic is tied to the framerate. There's two modes: 30fps mode and 60fps mode. On 60fps mode with my GTX1060, I can't even maintain 10fps on medium at times, whereas on 30fps mode, I'm comfortably locked at 30fps even on high graphics. It's very bizzare. The default keybinds are not super logical but the kb+m controls are otherwise fine. Generally an okay port overall; definitely playable, if not entirely ideal.

I giochi Musou non mi hanno mai preso particolarmente, ma persona 5 strikers aggiunge una grande varietà di meccaniche al combat system che rendono il gameplay  il più variegato e divertente possibile. Interessante la storia. I nuovi personaggi, i nuovi dialoghi, i nuovi luoghi hanno sicuramente dato una ventata d'aria fresca a ciò che era l'originale P5.

Oh and Makoto is best girl.

author: 139ee8e791e7571985f1f8c222e429e0
content:
Tutto figo, tutto colorato, tutto ben ottimizzato, tutto interessante e intrigante, tutto tradotto bene, tutto Persona 5, tutto 'taccivostraAtlus&SegachemettetesuPCunsequelanzichéilgiocooriginale.

Se avete già giocato Persona 5, comprare e pappare Strikers immediatamente è un obbligo.
Se non avete ancora giocato Persona 5 (Perfettamente comprensibile purtroppo, vista l'esclusività PS3/PS4), non dico che non potete affatto giocare a Strikers... Ma perdereste molte cose importanti e potrebbe intaccare il vostro giudizio su questo gioco.

Non posso *non* consigliarlo perché (finora) è un sequel coi fiocchi che riesce a redimere il tipico gameplay dei musou aggiungendo molte meccaniche dei Persona principali, però è obiettivamente una mossa abbastanza meschina rilasciare un sequel in una piattaforma che non ha il gioco originale... E poi, immagino, usare le vendite di questo sequel per giudicare la possibilità di rilasciare il gioco originale.

Vi meritate i soldi, ma allo stesso tempo no. 
Non so come siate riusciti a farmi scrivere una frase simile.

content:
A good persona 5 mini sequel with great new characters/ plot/ music.

Exploration/combat gameplay is fast and fun; it's different but takes far less time than regular persona so it doesn't overstay it's welcome if you don't like it. 

The phantom thieves strike fast and are gone before the enemies know what hit them, which feels appropriate for the phantom thieves being really good at their job by the time this game takes place.

content: Ein geniales Spiel, das mehr Fortsetzung ist als ein einfaches Spin-off. Es gibt zwar einige Änderungen, vor allem was das Kampfsystem betrifft, doch ich finde es wahnsinnig gut gelungen. Es sei natürlich gesagt, dass das Gameplay Simpler gehalten ist als im Original oder in Persona 5 Royal. author: 148b926d590a5456ab2f96cfa1fac111
content:
Bof, d'abord très content de retrouver cette ambiance Persona, super musique et super histoire.
Je suis très déçu par le nouveau système de combat. Fini le tour par tour qui faisait le charme du jeu, maintenant on a un hack and slash bien pourrave  avec des myriades d'ombres monstres qui déboulent à 360 °. On y voit rien et pas le temps de choisir tranquillement la stratégie comme avant et sélectionnant quel membre de l'équipe attaque quel monstre avec quelle attaque pour viser les faiblesses. 
Donc bien déçu oui...   je regrette déjà persona 4 et 5. Pourquoi changer une recette qui marche ? Dommage... je l'ai pris sur instant gaming, si je l'avais acheté sur steam j'aurais pu demander un remboursement.

(GUARDEN A CADA RATO QUE A MI SE ME HA CRASHEADO 6 VECES Y NO, NO LO ESTOY CORRIENDO CON 2GB DE RAM NI CON UNA 1050TI XD)

Si eres fan de la saga y te echa para atrás el hecho de que el combate sea como los Dynasty Warriors pues aquí estoy yo para decirte que el juego tiene un 80% de Persona y un 20% de Dynasty Warriors. Si no aprovechas las debilidades o si descuidas el medidor de SP estás bastante rip. Ya no hay social links pero aún existen los eventos sociales con los personajes del grupo los cuales llenarán un medidor para comprar habilidades o pasivas y así enfrentar mejor las dungeons.

Historia: De momento 9/10, bastante Personalike
Gameplay: OHHH ME VENGO
Banda sonora: OHHH ME VENGO X2
Personajes: OHHH ME VENGO X3
Estilo y estética: ¿Hace falta que lo diga?

9/10 mi gente, apoyen el juego para que nos saquen el Vanilla o mejor aún el Royal.

author: 5bd7e4a7d1225d80878daaed4ac69692
content:
I'm only 2.5 hours in, but as a Persona 5 (and Royal!) player this is definitely worth it if you loved those games. This is basically a sequel. Seeing these characters I love moving around in 4k at a silky smooth 60fps is a dream. 

The biggest problem with this game is the story pacing and the battles. Honestly I wish they would have just made this with the regular battle system. It is so much better than this musou stuff. So far the battles have been kind of a joke. I was over two hours in before I had even taken any damage. There are also some REALLY long cutscenes. Much longer than the original game(s).

If you aren't a fan of the previous P5 games I don't think there is much for you here. 

DEAR ATLUS PLEASE PORT PERSONAL 5 ROYAL TO PC!!!!

author: 7ea89f140e2154f58862ef58ad6c405c
content:
If you haven't played Persona 5 (Royal) yet, play that first. It will come to the Epic Games Store in March.* The game takes almost no time to explain who the characters are and what the story is from the first game, so you'd need that knowledge before stepping into this game. And don't just watch a video online explaining it, I don't think the characters are as likeable as they are without the proper context.

I had already finished this game on my Switch, but it was the Japanese version (since that was already released a year ago). And let me tell you, the ability to play this in 60 fps just makes it so much better. That and I can actually understand what I'm reading. I already enjoyed my time on the Switch, ignoring the 30 and under fps and long loading times, I'm still glad I bought the Japanese version. But I know for sure I won't be coming back to it for a long time.

*The article lied to me.

author: e1b490b3173657c6b30a8ffcf7f62c99
content:
TLDR: you'll probably like this game if you're a Persona fan. 

Update #2 (20 hours in): The 2nd "dungeon" wasn't all that interesting, but the combat continues to be fun. The story is definitely getting more interesting at this point.

Update (13 hours in): The story is picking up now and the enemies are getting tougher. It's ramping up like a typical Persona game.

Review in progress: 

As a Persona fan, I can tell you this truly FEELS like a Persona game. 

That means you get the best and worst of Persona in every form. I'm about 7 hours into Strikers, and the pacing is incredibly slow, just like Persona 5. This game mirrors Persona in the sense that it really doesn't respect your time, but it also mirrors it in having an interesting story, fun new characters that expand the Persona lore, and all of the usual hijinks you expect from the series. 

The gameplay here is very novel and repetitive. They've adapted pretty much all Persona mechanics to a third person action game format, and that's rad. You get to play with the whole cast and level up their abilities. If you find the style of game fun, you'll have a great time. If you get easily bored of beating up large groups of mostly weak enemies, you'll probably get bored of Strikers. 

So far, I feel like I can recommend this to Persona fans. There are some crashing and black screen issues, but you can work around them. 

P.S. it's still really cringy how sexualized some of the characters are, just like in every Persona game. If that cringe is enough for you to not like a game, Strikers won't be for you.

author: 94cba35b06df5fe084eae394e9a757f8
content:
Great game so far, make sure you also spend an extra $600 on Persona 5 Royal and a PS4 because otherwise you'll have no clue what's going on.

Seriously though, if you've played Persona 5 Royal/Vanilla P5, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It recaptures the same charm of the original while changing the genre entirely. If I had to pick out a flaw, it's that the dungeons, or "jails" feel very repetitive. They all have the same structure, unlike Persona 5's structure which usually included gimmicks.

TL;DR:
Play the game, make sure you've played vanilla Persona 5 first.
(Not saying you *should* emulate PS3 games, but persona 5 is technically a ps3 game and there are ps3 emulators online...)

content: Gameplay is incredibly easy to get into with some more complex mechanics hidden behind the surface if you wanna optimise, the story is fairly cliche of a JRPG but it isn't badly written and I found myself quite invested from the start. Overall it's a pretty great persona spin-off that still manages to keep the charm and love that goes into the persona games as a whole.

author: 55b2da28c3655bd8bad2a7f3d33f0a2f
content:
I honestly was a little worried for this game. I enjoyed P5R, but I felt it leaned a little too heavily into fan service, and as a result wasn't as good as just regular Persona 5 (that and I'm still mad about how broken Okumura was in that game, but that's a different story.) This game though - I might actually like it more than Persona 5. The combat is fast paced and intense, where you're swapping between characters rapidly for follow up attacks, hitting weaknesses, and using environmental objects to beat down shadows. I never thought I'd get to play as a cat wearing a bandit mask on a skateboard running over Jack Frost, but here we are.

The social aspect of this game is definitely [i]different[/i] than in Persona 5, though I wouldn't say it's worse. It's a lot more based on exploring cities for cool moments with your team and building the team skills you want out of the social points you earn for spending time with them. The time system is also very different than in P5. Though the calendar still progresses, it moves with set story points rather than each time you leave a palace or spend time with a friend. Again, this isn't [i]worse[/i] than P5, it's just different. Strikers is trying to put a pretty decently sized game into one summer vacation, so they only have what, six weeks to tell their story? I think it took me more than six weeks to get my first confidants to max rank in P5, so I have to admit that this system works a lot better for this setup.

The real highlight for me so far though is honestly the characters. Persona 5 had some great villains, but most of them were irredeemably awful people, end of story. This game though is willing to tread into grey area a lot more willingly. You're going to face off against objectively bad people - but you'll also see why they became this way, how they're real people tumbling down slippery slopes of mistakes and bad decisions.  Without getting too much into spoiler territory, the two bosses I've gone against so far have had a lot more dimension than the earlier bosses of P5. This entire tangent is also ignoring the new NPCs who are on your side. I've found these characters to be quirky, interesting, and willing to add some life and spirit to an already vibrant group. Even the Phantom Thieves' dynamic feels a little more polished than in P5; The team, while still up to their usual antics, are calling out great kills by specific members, appreciating even Ryuii's accomplishments. I know, people not making fun of Ryujii. Who'd have thought we'd see the day?

Also, the soundtrack is a mix of funky new jams and the original P5 soundtrack on steroids. What's not to love?

TL;DR: A sequel has a lot to live up to, especially if it's changing genres, and this absolutely exceeded my expectations.  I paid 10 extra dollars to play this game four days early and absolutely regret nothing.

author: 4ce04d3b397258ef88b4f17197e89e34
content:
Story Wise - I'm done with the first "Jail/Big Bad" of the game. Having about a couple of hours of grinding and stuff the game is exactly what I wanted and hoped for. Taking 6/7 months after the events of Persona 5, the Phantom Thieves are back in action! The gameplay is a mix of the general warriors style combo (2-6 light attacks followed by 1 or 2 strong) mixed with persona elements. Such as certain Combos like (2 light - 2 Heavy) casting a persona's skill. However if you are looking for more Hyrule Warriors / Dynasty Warrior game this might not be for you. Strikers is more Persona than Warrior. The RPG elements shine through with the different personas, cutscenes, and story. In reality if you changed to combat to be turn based again it would be almost a lightened version of the original, which isn't bad. It's really nice and the two styles of game blends well. If you like Persona 5 and want more story and willing to learn the combos and controls, I recommend it. If you like Warrior style games and want more of a JRPG elements, I would as well. 

For instance, with most warriors games it's action, pick a level action, while with Strikers it's more here a  bunch of story, motives, and planning followed by encounters. The encounters are like standard JRPG run into an enemy and the fights start. The tutorial itself, took about 5 / 6 hours to get to the point of listening to all conversations talking with team-mates every day (Which can give items). 

I'd recommend this game in a heartbeat for anyone wanting more persona or a warrior style RPG. I never got around to finishing Persona 5 and watched a quick 3 minute lore video on Youtube. I'm in love with this game and can't wait to play more!

author: c59741cff5905795af2bee85e64de2f1
content:
Wow, So, you get THE TEAM. You know? THE TEAM! Joker, Panther, Haru, Morgana, Fox, Queen, Jail Bait who is still unplayable, and the newly added Jail Bait v.2 The game is flashy and STYLISH in the typical persona fasion except brought to us in the form of a musou game. So you can hack slash bomb and punch your way to the new world without having to press X to guard the next attack. It mixes up the typical musou formula by adding elements that were present in p5 and takes on a truly unique spin to what a musou fan would be used to. What more could a fan want? This is the team we know, This is the team we love.

Well...

I cannot recommend this game to either a persona fan or a musou fan, If you are coming from a game like DW or WO where you get 50+ unique characters with different personalities, unique skills, unique weapons, and unique abilities to attach to those weapons you are going to be left wanting because here all you get is about 6 characters with unique personalities, Personas (skills) and Weapons. They have shrunk the formula here and made things much simpler in order to appease the original fan base (presumably, there is no document stating that) which failed in my opinion. Reason it failed is because the original fan base is still left wanting as well. There was so much potential to introduce new phantom thieves with this "sequel" The Doctor, The GunShop owner, The Teacher, Lavenza (who is actually 2 people)  all of them could have been included or added later and present a unique set of weapons and game play elements. The game is EXTREMELY repetitive which is typical for a musou, HOWEVER, usually you get bored try a new character from a roster of 50+ people and here you get to get bored and try a new character about 6 times, if you get bored beyond that you are SOL so you better REALLY enjoy a particular move set. 

Honestly...

I could go on but that's about the gist of it. They tried to merge two different worlds and ending failing both of them. Which is sad cause i really do love these phantom thieves.

Thanks & Good Luck

author: 65aa79dba8005d918f7545633857ee5a
content:
If you liked the persona 5 jrpg you're gonna like this game most likely. The gameplay and the mechanics are pretty tight and i didn't feel bored at any point except for when the game crashed on me but i played it from day one (or day -4 actually) on fairly old hardware and atlus and project omega are working on the game to rid it of bugs. On the story side it's not as good as was persona 5's but it's still alright, the comedic moments are still as well written as ever and the characters are ok. I didn't have as big a connexion with the new thieves as with the original ones for the obvious reasonthat they are exclusive to this game but they get a fair bit of character development and were still pretty endearing. The villains were a bit more basic this time around but still did the job right. This game really feels like you're going on a roadtrip with your fellow Phantom Thieves and i often found myself enjoying the dialogs and thinking what i was gonna cook for the group (even tho it has no actual implication further from getting healing items). The story is a bit predictable wich is a bit sad though i didn't mind it too much as i was too engrossed in this summer vacation with the team. On the music side i didn't verify if it was just my deluxe version but i had access to the fight musics from persona 1-4 and remixed versions of base p5 music. The original music is of course amazing and i did like the remixes tho i personally preffer the jazzy feel of the original p5 music instead of this more rock version. If you have played and liked persona 5 it's worth buying and playing this game and if not this gameis still more than ok but you'll miss the refferences from quite a few jokes and you won't get everything from the story as some things are only explained in the jrpg like the story of the phantom thieves for the most part plus you won't have as deep a connection with the characters. I would reccommend playing p5 or p5r before playing this game for full enjoyment. p5 is less expensive and is accessible on ps3 at the cost of graphics and on ps4 and p5r is only accessible on ps4(i don't remember if the ps5 has backwards compatibility). if your budget is tight i would still reccommendplaying p5 first if you like jrpgs as it is absolutely excellent and if you don't want to play it or don't own a ps3/4 then you might want to watcha let's play of it on youtube tho i don't recommend it as these games are way better when played first hand.

 Overall i'd give it a 9/10 because i'm fully biased for the persona series and i think you should absolutely try this game and the series too.

author: 77a0f3145a4152e4b7f8fca048ef89b9
content:
Если вы играли в оригинальную Persona 5 (или Royal) - эта игра идеальна для вас. Ребята из ω-force, при помощи Atlus, смогли создать игру, которая ощущается, как настоящий сиквел. Стилистика, музыка, персонажи, разные мелкие детали и некоторые элементы геймплея безошибочно выдают в Strikers ту самую, любимую многими, Персону 5. Изменения претерпела лишь часть игровой механики - теперь вместо классических пошаговых боёв у нас экшен-боёвка в слэшерном стиле, но даже при этом разработчики умудрились запихнуть в эту концепцию максимальное количество "фишек" из оригинала - сами персоны, их специальные приёмы, слияние и улучшение; система слабости врагов к стихиям и разных статусов типа заморозки, сна и т.д.; all-out атака и showtime; скрытые атаки, которые дают преимущество в бою...перечислять можно очень долго. Да, порой "мусоу"-корни пролезают, и приходится молотить несколько десятков однотипных врагов, а затем весьма сложных мини-боссов, но всё это ощущается органично. Пожалуй, единственное, что не понравилось - это вырезание социальной системы, или системы "конфидантов" из оригинальной игры. Конечно, с нашими друзьями мы уже отношения прокачали ранее, но ведь есть и новые герои...
Сюжет неплох и интересен. Да, он не дотягивает по глубине и смысловой нагрузке до номерных частей Persona, но в качестве спин-оффа серии - это, пожалуй, лучшее, что есть на сегодняшний день (лучше, чем в Q/Q2, и в танцевалке и файтингам по P4).
Техническую реализацию можно назвать приемлемой. Она не идеальна - лимит fps ограничен 60-ю, случаются очень редкие вылеты (у меня за 8 часов был один вылет), но при этом у игры хорошая оптимизация и вполне нормальное управление как с геймпада, так и с клавомыши, с возможностью менять назначение кнопок.
ОДНАКО. Предупреждаю всех ПК-игроков. Если вы ещё не играли в саму Persona 5 или её переиздание Royal - воздержитесь от покупки Strikers, пока не восполните этот пробел. Чтобы получать удовольствие от Strikers, вам нужно пережить все те приключения, которые выпали на долю героев в оригинале.

author: 60830bc01c3254ed88642cf86e1dd8ce
content: Only like 6 hours in the game and can tell you that this game is truly a work of art. The gameplay is very fun and what makes it even better is the fact that they made each and every character's kit and moveset completely unique on top of the mindblowing soundtrack (which is basically a given in any game in the franchise) and design. I am playing on hard difficulty just because I didn't want to blow through the game in a day and it pretty tough for me, as someone who hasn't really played this genre of game at all. But despite that, I've never once gotten irritated at failing multiple times in a fight, rather I think about what I could do differently until I figure out what works and what doesn't and amidst that, memorizing the movesets of the enemies until I eventually complete the encounter, feeling a sense of accomplishment after several failed attempts. That however is only the tip of the iceberg, it takes some of the core things from vanilla P5 and incorporates it quite smoothly into itself, which in turn makes it feel like a true successor to vanilla. For 60$, I honestly believe that this game is worth every cent. 10/10 would cat van again.

author: 6af5fad9bb4552a0a18c8d24ab7742af
content:
Спасибо, Атлус! Надеюсь, скоро они портируют все свои игры на ПК, ибо единственный их минус - как раз необходимость играть на консоли. 
P5S, несмотря на отличающийся жанр, вполне заходит как веселенький спинофф, при игре в который улыбка не сходит с лица, а ностальгия приятно греет сердце. Однако играть в него не пройдя оригинал крайне не рекомендуется - игра не собирается многое объяснять и большая часть шуток и забавных деталей просто пройдёт мимо. Боевая система неплоха, но это всё, что можно о ней сказать. Конечно, большая часть "залипательности" гарантируется стилем, что, как в любой персоне, прямо-таки сочится с экрана.

Так же, порт, как всегда, не идеальный. За первые 7 часов игры было 3-4 вылета при загрузках. С тех пор, впрочем, всё спокойно.
Играть без геймпада или не пройдя оригинал крайне НЕ РЕКОМЕНДУЕТСЯ.

author: c00b4956a9e25557928714ea93d7a1d8
content:
This game is absolutely stupendous! A MUST buy for anyone that loved Persona 5! If you did not play the original game, then you will have absolutely no clue what's going on, and I appreciate that. They don't spend any time going over past events and treat the player with respect that this is a sequel and prior knowledge is necessary. 

The gang is back together and they are just as charming as they ever were - arguably more so because no time needs to be spent on introductions, so they can just leap straight into playing off eachother as close friends. Just seeing these characters reunite brought a lump to my throat. So far, the writing has made each character actually feel slightly more impactful than in P5 as they seem to be all pulling their own weight in conversation and nobody is getting left behind *cough Yusuke/Haru*

The style is BACK, BABY! The menus are still incredibly satisfying to flit through, the all-out attacks feel better to enact than ever, and the new additions are all extremely welcome. The combat feels absolutely joyous and I have zero complaints about the change from turn-based to frantic hack and slash. 

My only recommendations to the devs would be A: add widescreen support and B: give me better sound mixing as the effects seem a little too loud and drown out the music and VA which are both exceptional.

Thank you Atlus for bringing this game to the rest of the world and to PC!!!! Keep this up!

content: Barely plays like a Dynasty Warriors spin-off, and for me that's a great thing (feels much more like a successor to the Raidou Kuzunoha PS2 games than it does that series, with an emphasis on vertical movement). author: 0fd10a6488555aebb63202438829b630
content:
After only 14 hours of play, I can safely say this is the most fun and rewarding Warriors style game out there, and it helps that it's linked to one of my favorite games of all time. The music rocks, the gameplay is surprisingly engaging and somewhat difficult. The style helps encapsulate a feeling of badass combat. And the story is fun, nothing mind blowing from what I've played, but it doesn't have to be, it knows what it wants to be, and I think it achieves what it sets out to do very well. If you like P5 and fast based combat and exploration, get this game, it's just more time with your favorite characters with a new gameplay style that kicks ass!

*Update* I think most of what I said before stays true after finishing the game, my only new statement is that I think the game lasts a bit too long for a sequel spin off, and that the new characters sell the story the most out of everyone in the cast. I still recommend this game

author: a429a6d8a7fd553683ec891d23049643
content:
Cleared the game (as of 03.25.2021) but will keep the review spoiler free.

Pros
- A legit continuation of P5 (not P5R). The story illustrates the growth of the Phantom Thieves and is fantastic. 
- Killer soundtrack. My favorite is Blooming Villan, River in the Desert, and Counterstrike. 
- Doesn't chug on 60 FPS. 
- The new characters, Sophia and Zenkichi, are a fantastic addition to the cast. Usually the new characters tend to hog the spotlight or something but not too much with these two. 
- A Musou game that blends P5's style and system very well. 
- The right amount of difficulty. Once you cleared some hurdles, the game offers you the Merciless option (Risky in JP) and that'll definitely challenge the player's skill (to illustrate how hard Merciless is, you might die in the tutorial if you think you can just waltz in and tank everything). 
- New game plus option.

Cons
- Map navigation might be a bit disorientating at first since you'll be going up and down and all over. I definitely got disorientated at the Shibuya Jail.
- Inventory management could use some work. You'll be spending a good minute looking for the right recovery mid-fight. 
- You can't jump between Jail to Jail. This might be a bit tedious when you're trying to clear some requests. 
- The chaotic nature of a Musou game might catch some people off guard if they never played one. 
- You won't be able to swap out members mid battle like you did in P5 so if you run into a mid-boss that your not prepared for, you'll have a hard time. 
- A lot of Persona's were cut. This includes the awakened forms of your teammates. 
- Though your main attack is physical, physical Persona moves were nerfed. In P5S, the cost to use the physical Persona moves are based off your total HP and the skill that mitigates the cost of physical Persona moves isn't available. So yeah you can't go mindless and spam Yoshitsune's Hassotobi to decimate your foes. 

Mix
- A lot of the P5 casts won't be returning here.
- Morally gray bosses.
- The game doesn't really teach you some crucial tips. For example, you can use your items to recover during combat. I did not realize that after a couple of game overs. 
- The bosses are paired with one of your party members for story (for example, Alice and Ann). However, there are two characters that don't have that kind of scenario which is a bummer. However, those two shine throughout the story in general so it's not a total loss.
- Though it said you'll be going all over Japan, it's more of a slice. I did wish we could explore real-world Kyoto.
- No DLCs. This isn't a deal breaker (and it's not like DLC = win button) but I did wish we could use P4's Izanagi or P3's Thanatos and jam to Raidou's battle theme. 
- You won't be able to fight against attendants like you did in past Persona games unfortunately (usually they're set up as a hidden boss). However P5S still does it right and prepared a fan favorite of the Persona series as the hidden boss. 

Conclusion
- This is a game that I definitely would recommend to anyone who loves P5 or P5R and who's into Musou games. 
- Unlike a generic Musou games, it's very story heavy and won't get as repetitive (definitely a fresh take for me at least). 
- You will definitely tumble in the beginning as you get used to the battle system, but once you understand and master it, it's very fun. 

PS
The game definitely suffered a messaging issue upon it's first announcement (a lot of people thought it was going to be a generic Musou game with Persona characters thrown in it). After the first and second PV though, I think Atlus got the messaging issue fixed and assured the audience that this was a legit Persona game.

author: 2c2369a4a0e85a20a89c117a97bccbd0
content:
Persona 5 esta de vuelta para robar los corazones de los jugadores y ahora (al fin y después de tantas plegarias) en una plataforma de PC. Una gran obra digna de suceder a su precuela que ahora sigue con las aventuras de Los Ladrones Fantasma a través de todo Japón.
El juego se siente muy bien, las nuevas mecánicas y estilo Hack And Slash le dan un respiro a las demás entregas anteriores que nos venían ofreciendo el mismo sistema RPG que tanto amamos los fanáticos y seguidores de la saga SMT y Persona. Admito que al principio no estaba muy convencido con el nuevo sistema de juego, pero una vez que te adentras en el es muy difícil que no te sientas cómodo con el mismo.

3 PUNTOS POSITIVOS
* Mimo al alma de los fans: Atlus sabe como tratar a su audiencia. Ahora es posible jugar de manera libre con todos los Ladrones Fantasma y eso fue un punto muy positivo para el gameplay dándonos más variedad y la posibilidad de usar a nuestros personajes favoritos en combate. Cada personaje cuenta con sus propias habilidades y combos además de sus ataques especiales invocando a su persona para castigar las debilidades de los enemigos. En el apartado estético, sigue conservando todo lo que nos gusta reciclando (para bien) los aspectos visuales que nos enamoraron por primera vez con P5. La música es otro punto muy positivo, en esta entrega no contamos directamente con la participación de el maestro Shoji Meguro pero a cambio tuvimos nuevas nombres en los Soundtracks que demostraron estar a la altura del maestro con canciones como Axe To Grind, Counter Strike y, mi favorita, You Are Stronger. En la sección de diseño no se queda atrás para nada. Contamos con nuevos grandes personajes a la vez que tenemos a los jefes, que mas de una vez me dejaron boquiabierto y unos entornos nuevos y atrapantes.

* Combates dinámicos: Sabemos que los combates de la saga se caracterizaban por un sistema estático de golpes y habilidades por turnos al mas puro estilo RPG, ahora con P5S se le dio una vuelta de tuerca muy favorable que nos invita a ser atacantes mas directos y ofensivos en un sistema de combate dinámico y adictivo con muchas mecánicas nuevas, ejecutando combos, utilizando objetos del entorno y magias para masacrar la mayor cantidad de enemigos posibles ganando así más puntos y experiencia. La verticalidad de los niveles y la amplitud del campo de batalla son otros puntos muy acertados, dándonos esa sensación de libertad al moverse por el metaverso como ninguna otra entrega anterior lo ha hecho.

* Narrativa e historia: Si bien se nota a distancia que este juego no fue hecho con el mismo presupuesto que su obra maestra anterior P5 o P5R, la historia de Strikers esta muy lograda. Se nota esa familiaridad y cariño entre los personajes que ya conocemos y los nuevos que se irán integrando poco a poco avance la trama. Realmente se siente como una secuela y no como un Spinoff más de la franquicia como en otras entregas anteriores.

3 PUNTOS NEGATIVOS
* Algunas cosas se extrañan: Si algo se caracterizó la obra maestra anterior fue por tener muchas mecánicas divertidas que aportaban variedad y personajes hermosos que lamentablemente no contamos en este juego. Hay cosas con las que no contamos como el celular, pescar, las quest secundarias o incluso pasear libremente por la ciudad (y no solo en un minimapa con dos o tres tiendas). Y en cuanto a los personajes, podrían haber hecho como mínimo un cameo y no solo cancelarlos con excusas vagas o directamente ni si quiera mencionarlos ya que en la precuela fueron emblemáticos e importantes tanto para el jugador como para el protagonista. Personajes como Igor, Mishima, Iwai o Takemi fueron de los que más se notó el hueco (eso sin contar a Yoshizawa o Maruki sean canon o no).

* A veces se espera un poco más: Si bien el combate es excelente y dinámico como mencione anteriormente, a veces peca de ser repetitivo y termina cansando. Muchas peleas solo se basan en spamear botones a lo bestia y rara vez castear una magia para debilitar a un oponente medianamente fuerte, eso si no es que antes moris debido a la exagerada cantidad de cosas y explosiones que hay en pantalla simultáneamente y que son en extremo molestas. Los combates de la primera cárcel pueden ser desafiantes y hasta exigentes para los mas novatos, pero una vez que aprendiste los controles y sabes usar a los personajes, la curva de dificultad del juego desciende y se vuelve un paseo de golpes sin miedo a perder nada por el camino. Incluso algunas peleas contra jefes están muy chupadas, el mismo juego te dice que lanzarle para hacerle mas daño o cuando hay que hacerle cierto movimiento especial.

* Recorte de contenido: Este es el punto mas perdonable. El juego es hermoso, no me malinterpreten, pero si hay muchas cinemáticas, momentos y transiciones que se notan muy vagas o poco pulidas. Quisiera creer que es por cuestiones de presupuesto y en ese caso es aceptable, pero me pasó en muchos momentos donde los personajes fuera del metaverso solo se limitaban a quedarse quietos hablando sin ninguna expresión o incluso moverse de forma tosca. 

En conclusión, 8.5 de 10
Gracias por leer.
PD: PERSONA 5 ROYAL PC 2021 LO QUIEROOOOO ATLUS LCDTM PONETE LAS PILAS

author: 7901e2bc7f0d541aa06dcfc8dac2dbb2
content:
*I ordered the digital deluxe edition so I was able to play early*

This game has a problem for me on fullscreen mode as the game will not load after launching my save file. So I resorted to using borderless windowed mode instead and it worked. 

So far however, the game has been really fun, sometimes even challenging even on normal mode, and we get to experience a brand new story with our beloved cast of characters.

My biggest gripe probably has to be the dungeon crawling. The dungeon crawling feels a lot "stiff" compared to its JRPG counter part. The camera is very very hard to deal with in tight spaces as well. 

People might be turned off by the fact that this IS a musou game, but the mix with Persona 5's JRPG elements make it so that enemies are not free roaming for you to bash mindlessly, and that enemies are actually more so just encounters you stumble upon. The Persona summons are definitely fun to use, however (and this is just a minor gripe on my half) SP in the beginning of the game is so scarce and that most of the time I am actually fighting SP-less. 

Overall, I am happy that this game is able to differentiate itself from other musou-type games, and it is definitely unique on its own. 

To end off, Sophia is very adorable, and I think she's a great inclusion to the cast so far. I am definitely looking forward to playing more.

author: 0b75ecc9dd1e53a9a77c7fc14047ddc1
content:
17 hours in and I love it. The game feels right at home on PC. I have more than 600+ hours played between Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal so this Strikers was an easy choice. 

The game is new player friendly in terms of gameplay since there are a lot of helpful tutorials. 
The story and character interactions will feel familiar for vets. I think this is one area that new players will miss out in terms of cohesion. The game feels like a true squeal, playing P5/P5R prior does make for a better experience. 

The game doesn't have many bugs, if any. There is an anti aliasing issue with the in-game settings. It just doesn't look sharp to me. But this is easily fixed by disabling the in-game setting and enabling anti aliasing via Nvidia control panel. I recommend upping the resolution scale as well if your PC can handle it. The game looks incredible with graphical tweaks; literally go crazy in the NV control panel. The game is only 60fps so you can tick all the boxes and still performs well. 

Persona 5 Strikers is a worthy addition, highly stylistic, great soundtrack, lovable cast and the new gameplay style just works.

author: 4a492661117a57bba8adb2d88be7faa5
content:
I came in to persona 5 strikers having played persona 5 (the original, not royal) and beaten it on a PS4. While I'm very excited to see more persona titles on steam, such as 4 golden, and 5 strikers, I really hope we see more of the main games ported. Persona 3, Persona 5, ect. If you've played and enjoyed persona 5, you'll probably like strikers. The same characters are back for a "Vacation" story focused around old friends getting back together.  The gameplay is solid, the anime cutscenes are high quality, and the graphics are very pretty! This game is great on the couch with a controller, or with a keyboard and mouse, although I prefer this as a couch title personally. If you haven't played persona 5 yet, you might not enjoy this game as much. I'm sure it would feel similar to joining a well established friend group, and realizing you kinda get most of the insight jokes, but that you also have a sense of loss that you weren't there when they were created. Regardless, story isn't the only attraction here, and the gameplay is solid enough that I can still recommend strikers to someone who hasn't played persona 5. That being said, Atlus, please give us persona 3 and persona 5 on steam. The whole "Steam vs other platforms such as epic" argument might sound shallow on paper, but steam is offering so many wonderful features that no other storefront can. A big example of this is Proton support, which allows windows games to run on linux. Valve is hardware and software agnostic, allowing many gamers to come together and enjoy their favorite titles in the way they'd like. I'm happy to support Atlus on my platform of choice, as it is a platform that supports my freedom of choice. Here's to more wonderful persona games coming to steam in the future. We're glad to have you here! 

Best Regards, -PR0XIDIAN

author: d9a19be5ac4d5af292f8da59bedeb653
content:
You can play as your waifu, turn into vehicles to mow down hordes of cute persona designs, and bop to some solid music tracks from all persona games. I couldn't ask for anything more.


On a serious note, this game brings a trimmed down, but still immensely enjoyable version of Persona 5's overworld, with a twist for the combat. It translates surprising well to an action based hack and slash. There will be an adjustment period for anyone who's previously played a persona game because several of the button assignments are different to compensate for the new combat (like the persona summoning menu is now a special attack button).  The platforming is also no longer on rails for the most part, so movement is a bit more choppy than it was in persona 5.

However, after an hour or two of getting used to fighting, its a surprisingly rewarding experience. It emphasizes reflexes and situational awareness to dodge attacks and use combos to fire off skills seamlessly. As well as rewarding persona building, because having the right set of skills to hit weaknesses or apply crowd control can be the a major factor in how smoothly a fight will go.

Hard mode even provides a pleasant challenge, forcing you to pay attention in most encounters, or else you most likely be overwhelmed by enemy abilities and attacks. Forcing you to really dive into the combat system, and learn to string together combos and dodging efficiently.

I was expecting something good as a spin off, but it went beyond my expectations into a great game to play on its own. A legitimate 9/10 from my time with it so far.
